content.question:
With regards to the 4th segment of the net take-off flight path, which of the following statements are true?
1. Flaps are retracted.
2. Flaps and slats are extended.
3. Take off thrust is set on live engines.
4. Max continuous thrust is set on live engines.
5. It ends below 1500 ft.
6. It ends at or above 1500 ft.

key_points: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, one engine inoperative, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative
On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15 ft
Operating engines are at take-off thrust, the flaps/slats are in take-off configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb
learning.explanation: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, one engine inoperative, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative. On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15 ft. Operating engines are at take-off thrust, the flaps/slats are in take-off configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb. The first segment ends when the landing gear is fully retracted. Begins when the landing gear is fully retracted. Engines are at take-off thrust and the flaps/slats are in the take-off configuration. This segment ends at the higher of 400 ft. Begins at 400 ft or higher specified acceleration altitude. Engines are at take-off thrust and the aircraft is accelerated in level flight. Slats/flaps are retracted on speed. The segment ends when aircraft is in clean configuration and the final take-off speed has been achieved. Once this has happened, thrust can be reduced from maximum take-off thrust, TOGA, to maximum continuous thrust, MCT. Starts when the flaps are fully retracted, the final segment speed is achieved, and the thrust is set to maximum continuous thrust. From this point the airplane is climbed to at or above 1500 ft (depending on terrain/obstacles), where the take-off flight path ends. The climb gradient for this last stage must not be less than 1.2%. 1st Segment 2nd Segment 3rd Segment 4th Segment Starts 35 ft Gear Up > 400 ft AGL Flaps Up VFTO MCT Action Select Gear Up Climb to > 400 ft AGL Retract Flaps Accelerate to VFTO Set MCT Climb to MINIMUM 1500 ft AGL Gradient for 2 Engines > 0% > 2.4% N/A > 1.2% Gradient for 3 Engines > 0.3% > 2.7% N/A > 1.5% Gradient for 4 Engines > 0.5% > 3.0% N/A > 1.7% While third segment is usually flown in level flight, the available gradient must be at least equal to that required in final segment (1.2%). During third segment the high lift devices are retracted.

content.question:
An aeroplane descends from FL410 to FL270 at its cruise Mach number and from FL270 to FL100 at the IAS achieved at FL270. Assuming idle thrust, a clean configuration and ignoring compressibility effects, how does the angle of descent change
(i) in the first and
(ii) in the second part of the descent?

key_points: Descent at a Constant Mach Number in Standard Conditions During a descent, LSS will be increasing, as temperature increases
Therefore, if Mach number is being kept constant the TAS must be increasing (Mach number = TAS/LSS)
During the descent air density increases TAS is increasing and IAS also increases at a greater rate (Dynamic Pressure = 1⁄2 ρ V2)
learning.explanation: Descent at a Constant Mach Number in Standard Conditions During a descent, LSS will be increasing, as temperature increases. Therefore, if Mach number is being kept constant the TAS must be increasing (Mach number = TAS/LSS). During the descent air density increases TAS is increasing and IAS also increases at a greater rate (Dynamic Pressure = 1⁄2 ρ V2). Similarly, in a climb at constant Mach number the TAS and IAS both reduce. During descend with a constant Mach no. the Lift increases as IAS is increasing. Lift = 1⁄2 ρ V2 CL To balance the lift CL is reduced by lowering the aircraft nose. Lowering the nose, the aircraft will have a steeper angle of descent. Flying with a constant IAS, the Lift will remain constant and there is no need to further lower the nose. Angle of descent remains constant.

content.question:
In the OPS regulations, a runway is considered wet when:
1. it is covered with a quantity of water or loose or slushy snow less than or equal to the equivalent of 3 mm of water.
2. the amount of surface moisture is sufficient to modify its colour but does not give it a shiny appearance.
3. the amount of surface moisture is sufficient to make it reflective, but does not create large stagnant sheets of water.
4. it bears stagnant sheets of water.
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

key_points: EASA AIR OPS Annex I to VIII "Contaminated runway"

A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0,125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0,125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice
"Damp runway"
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS Annex I to VIII "Contaminated runway". A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0,125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0,125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice. "Damp runway". A runway is considered damp when the surface is not dry, but when the moisture on it does not give it a shiny appearance. "Dry runway". A dry runway is one which is neither wet nor contaminated, and includes those paved runways which have been specially prepared with grooves or porous pavement and maintained to retain "effectively dry" braking action even when moisture is present. "Wet runway." A runway is considered wet when the runway surface is covered with water, or equivalent, less than specified in subparagraph (a)(2) above or when there is sufficient moisture on the runway surface to cause it to appear reflective, but without significant areas of standing water.

content.question: If an aircraft's performance limited maximum take-off mass is limited by the maximum brake energy speed limit, which of the following must the flight crew do?

key_points: VMBE is the maximum brake energy speed
It is the speed which an aircraft can safely stop from, without overloading the brakes with energy

The brakes take the vast majority of an aircraft's kinetic energy in as heat, so will have a limit on the temperature they can withstand, which equates to a maximum energy they can stop, before overheating and causing effects like brake fade, brake fires and tyre blowouts
learning.explanation: VMBE is the maximum brake energy speed. It is the speed which an aircraft can safely stop from, without overloading the brakes with energy. The brakes take the vast majority of an aircraft's kinetic energy in as heat, so will have a limit on the temperature they can withstand, which equates to a maximum energy they can stop, before overheating and causing effects like brake fade, brake fires and tyre blowouts. VMBE obviously varies a lot on weight, and the heavier an aircraft is, the more kinetic energy it has at the same speed, so the lower the VMBE. VMBE also depends on temperature and density altitude, as the hotter and higher the airfield is, the higher the groundspeed for any value of IAS. It is an upper limit of V1, as V1 is the highest speed an aircraft would begin a stop during take-off. If the calculated V1 is higher than the VMBE, then the VMBE should be used as the V1 speed, and this will cause a reduction in the FLLTOM (Field Length Limited Take-Off Mass). If the aircraft were to use a higher V1 than the VMBE speed, braking could be compromised due to overheating, which would cause melting of the fusible plugs in the tyres, brake fires, and brake fade. Therefore, V1 ≤ VMBE (V1 must be less than or equal to VMBE) The annex attached above is the graph and guidance for calculating if the VMBE will be limiting. You do not need to use the graph at all for this question, but it is good to get an association. There is another speed mentioned in the options, the max tyre speed. This is the speed above which the aircraft's tyres are not rated, and may cause a blowout. This should be higher than the expected speed of lift off (VLOF), and whilst there is an option close to that, it uses a "less than" sign instead of "less than or equal to", and it is not the subject of the question.

content.question: With an true airspeed of 194kt and a vertical speed of 1000ft/min, the climb gradient is about:

key_points: The climb gradient is defined as the ratio of the altitude gained to horizontal air distance traveled (in a still air), and therefore the tangent to the climb angle γ
For small angles, sin γ ≈ tan γ = climb gradient
Therefore Climb Gradient = ((Thrust - Drag) ÷ Weight) × 100
learning.explanation: The climb gradient is defined as the ratio of the altitude gained to horizontal air distance traveled (in a still air), and therefore the tangent to the climb angle γ. For small angles, sin γ ≈ tan γ = climb gradient. Therefore Climb Gradient = ((Thrust - Drag) ÷ Weight) × 100. It is expressed as a percentage. The rate of climb (ROC) may be calculated by multiplying the climb gradient (as a percentage) with TAS (True Air Speed). Best ROC is obtained when the difference between Power Required and Power Available is at its maximum. Power Available decreases with altitude and so does the achievable ROC. Notice that 3 of the 4 forces of flight are used to make the calculation: Thrust, Drag and Weight. Regarding our question: Rate of Climb (ft/min) = TAS (kts) × Gradient (%). Therefore, Climb gradient = Rate of Climb ÷ TAS => 1 000 ÷ 194 = 5.15%. Remember that climb gradients are always expressed as percentage. Alternative: Climb Gradient = Rate of Climb / TAS x 6 000 / 6 080 Climb Gradient = 1 000 / 194 x 6 000 / 6 080 = 5.087

content.question: Standing water on the runway causes the Take-Off Distance to (1)_____ and Accelerate-Stop Distance to (2)_____.

key_points: Even on a smooth, dry runway there will be rolling resistance due to friction
If the runway is contaminated by snow, slush or standing water, there will be additional drag due to fluid resistance
Any contamination will increase the drag and hence increase the take-off distance
learning.explanation: Even on a smooth, dry runway there will be rolling resistance due to friction. If the runway is contaminated by snow, slush or standing water, there will be additional drag due to fluid resistance. Any contamination will increase the drag and hence increase the take-off distance. If the take-off is rejected and braking is required, the coefficient of braking friction is severely reduced on a runway which is wet, icy or contaminated by snow, slush or standing water. Hydroplaning may also occur in different forms when standing water is present. This means that the brake pressure must be severely reduced to prevent skidding. Thus, the stopping distance is greatly increased.

content.question: The crew of a jet transport aircraft is preparing for departure from one of two available runways, one runway is reported as contaminated and the other is reported as wet. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: A derated thrust takeoff is only allowed on the wet runway.
options.B: A derated thrust takeoff is allowed on either runway.
options.C: A reduced thrust takeoff is only allowed on the contaminated runway.
options.D: A reduced thrust takeoff is allowed on either runway.

key_points: Sometimes it is operationally useful to reduce an aircraft's thrust for take-off, in order to run the engines less hard; reducing maintenance costs, increasing engine life, etc
This is possible when the aircraft is neither field-length nor climb or obstacle limited, and there is effectively performance to spare
This does not save any fuel, due to the increased time to get to more efficient altitudes
learning.explanation: Sometimes it is operationally useful to reduce an aircraft's thrust for take-off, in order to run the engines less hard; reducing maintenance costs, increasing engine life, etc. This is possible when the aircraft is neither field-length nor climb or obstacle limited, and there is effectively performance to spare. This does not save any fuel, due to the increased time to get to more efficient altitudes. There are two ways to do this. Reduced take-off thrust (FLEX), or through a fixed de-rate. The main difference being that a de-rate limits the total engine thrust, but FLEX take-off just limits how much of the engine we use, and we could select TO/GA thrust at any time and use the whole amount of thrust. There are reasons that either, or even both may be used. Derated take-off thrust makes the engine behave like a smaller engine. This means that the aircraft does not have to conform to the same minimum control speeds as if TO/GA thrust was used, allowing for lower VMCG and VMCA. Derated take-offs are also allowed to be used on a wet runway and on a runway contaminated with standing water, slush, snow, or ice. Reduced thrust take-offs do not have that luxury, and are not allowed for use on contaminated runways (although wet runways can be used if the take-off performance is acceptable for the reduced thrust in wet conditions). Therefore, a derated take-off is allowed on either runway, but a reduced take-off would only be allowed on the wet runway.

content.question: With which conditions would one expect VMC to be the lowest?

options.A: Hot temp, high-pressure altitude, high humidity
options.B: Hot temp, low-pressure altitude, high humidity
options.C: Cold temp, low altitude, low humidity
options.D: Cold temp, high altitude, low humidity

key_points: VMCG concerns the calibrated airspeed for minimum control on the ground (i
e
using primary aerodynamic controls only to correct the yawing tendency)
learning.explanation: VMCG concerns the calibrated airspeed for minimum control on the ground (i.e. using primary aerodynamic controls only to correct the yawing tendency). We know that flying surfaces are more effective the faster air flows over them so, if the yaw is less pronounced, the required airspeed for counteracting it need not be so high. As elevation and temperature increase (Hot High and Humid) VMCG decreases. In high density/low temp conditions if you fly at your original VMCA you will lose control. To maintain control you have to fly faster. You have a higher minimum control speed. If conditions are hot, high and humid the air is less dense. This reduces thrust and means when you lose the critical engine on takeoff there is less yawing effect from asymmetric thrust than there would be in denser air. The linkage between VMCA, VMCG and VS has to show that in the worst case you can recover safely from an engine failure. Once past V1 you have to keep control while accelerating. By lift-off you have to be able to maintain straight flight. At the same time OEI performance must be enough to meet the required climb gradient, but that is not part of the determination of VMCA, which only asks for a demonstration of straight flight at full power on the live engine(s) If you are flying at or near VMCA it must be with a steady bank angle of about 3-5deg toward the live engine. If you bank toward the dead engine or overbank toward the live at VMCA minimum control speed rises sharply.

125 x D + ½ wingspan - If the flight path requires a change of track direction between 0 and 15 deg then the area reaches a maximum semi width of 300m; - If the flight path requires a change of track direction above 15 deg then the area reaches a maximum semi width of 600m

For aircraft with a wing span of less than 60m semi width of such area is calculated: 60 m + 0.125 x D + ½ wingspan - If the flight path requires a change of track direction between 0 and 15 deg then the area reaches a maximum semi width of 300m; - If the flight path requires a change of track direction above 15 deg then the area reaches a maximum semi width of 600m. content.question: Reduced take-off thrust should normally not be used when:

key_points: Advantages of using reduced take-off thrust Using reduced thrust lowers the jet engine's internal operating pressure and temperature
The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs
Secondary advantages include fuel savings and that, under certain circumstances, it may be possible to increase the maximum take-off weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust profile
learning.explanation: Advantages of using reduced take-off thrust Using reduced thrust lowers the jet engine's internal operating pressure and temperature. The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs. Secondary advantages include fuel savings and that, under certain circumstances, it may be possible to increase the maximum take-off weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust profile. Therefore, the main benefits are: Reduced stress and wear on the engine; Reduced cost on parts and mainenance; Increased engine life; Increased reliability, thus improving operating safety and efficency. As a result of the lower flight path, reduced take-off thrust may increase the airplane-to-ground noise level. Reduced thrust take-off must not be used in the following cases: Icy or very slippery runways Contaminated runways Anti-skid inop Reverse thrust inop Increased V2 procedure (improved climb) Engine Power Management Computer inop Not recommended in Windshear conditions

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: What is the advantage of using the "reduced take off-thrust” technique?

options.A: Less runway is used, compared to a normal take-off.
options.B: It can be used for contaminated runways.
options.D: It increases the obstacles clearance margin.

key_points: When an aircraft is neither climb, nor field length limited, nor obstacle limited on take-off, there is essentially performance to spare
There is no point in taking off with the maximum take-off thrust set, when clearly this is unnecessary
Any thrust setting, less than the maximum, will provide substantial benefits in terms of engine life, maintenance and operating costs
learning.explanation: When an aircraft is neither climb, nor field length limited, nor obstacle limited on take-off, there is essentially performance to spare. There is no point in taking off with the maximum take-off thrust set, when clearly this is unnecessary. Any thrust setting, less than the maximum, will provide substantial benefits in terms of engine life, maintenance and operating costs. In such cases, it is normal for the operators to use approved procedures to reduce the thrust, so that the aircraft is at or close to its performance limits at the reduced thrust setting. Doing a take-off with less than full thrust does not save fuel. It actually increases the total fuel burn, because of the increased time to height. Nor does it necessarily reduces the aircraft noise. It is quite likely to leave a bigger noise footprint, because the aircraft is lower and closer to any noise monitoring site, than it would be under full thrust. The purpose of the Reduced Thrust take-offs is to extend engine life and thus save money.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: When compared to a clean configuration, how does flap setting usually affect the Runway Length Limited Take-Off Mass and the Climb Limited Take-Off Mass? The Runway Length Limited Take-Off Mass…

options.A: increases, and the Climb Limited Take Off Mass increases.
options.B: increases, and the Climb Limited Take Off Mass decreases.
options.C: decreases, and the Climb Limited Take Off Mass increases.
options.D: decreases, and the Climb Limited Take Off Mass decreases.

key_points: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient
For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed
As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient)
learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce. Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean. => Based on the above, we can conclude that the Runway Length Limited Take-Off Mass increases (due to the reduced take-off run required with the use of flaps) and the Climb Limited Take Off Mass decreases (due to the degraded climb performance).

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: When planning a take-off from Porto (LPPR) at a take-off mass of 89 tonnes, the EFB performance software gives a Flex temperature of 36° and a range of possible decision speeds with V1 MAX at 155 kts and V1 MIN at 142 kts. Complete the following sentence: Using a V1 of 155 kts, the climb performance (1) _____ ; and using a V1 of 142 kts, the stopping performance is (2) _____.

key_points: The Take-off Decision Speed (V1) is the maximum speed at which a rejected take-off can be initiated and a stop within the ASDA can be accomplished with the critical engine inoperative
V1 is also the minimum speed at which a pilot can continue takeoff following an engine failure
Following an engine failure, the overall thrust is decreased and the drag is increased
learning.explanation: The Take-off Decision Speed (V1) is the maximum speed at which a rejected take-off can be initiated and a stop within the ASDA can be accomplished with the critical engine inoperative. V1 is also the minimum speed at which a pilot can continue takeoff following an engine failure. Following an engine failure, the overall thrust is decreased and the drag is increased. Consequently, the aircraft will accelerate more slowly. With a higher V1, the acceleration to VLOF to be achieved on one engine is smaller than with a lower V1. Therefore, the aircraft will take-off sooner (closer to the line-up position). It will then climb at the same shallow angle as with a lower V1. With a higher V1, the overall climb performance (regarding obstacle clearance), is improved. Choosing a lower V1 will imply that an engine failure can be accepted at a lower speed. Meaning that the aircraft will also initiate its deceleration at a lower speed improving the stopping performance.

content.question: Which of the following would cause a reduction in the landing distance?

key_points: Lets go through each option; remember, we are looking for something that reduces landing distance, so effectively increases our landing performance (in other words, something good): "A contaminated runway
" A contaminated runway means more than 3 mm of water (or equivalent), and would reduce wheel traction, and would increase landing distance
"Using thrust reversers
learning.explanation: Lets go through each option; remember, we are looking for something that reduces landing distance, so effectively increases our landing performance (in other words, something good): "A contaminated runway." A contaminated runway means more than 3 mm of water (or equivalent), and would reduce wheel traction, and would increase landing distance. "Using thrust reversers." Thrust revers increase an aircraft's deceleration, so decrease landing distance. "A tailwind component." This would increase our groundspeed over the threshold, increasing landing distance. "Increased outside air temperature." This would increase our TAS and therefore groundspeed over the threshold for the same IAS, due to lower air density, therefore increasing landing distance.

content.question: If ATC asks you to descend using the steep approach technique, what happens to the speed buffet?

options.A: High speed increases due to altitude reduction.
options.B: Low speed decreases due to Mach number reduction.
options.C: High speed decreases due to Mach number reduction.
options.D: Low speed increases due to altitude reduction.

key_points: The buffet onset boundary (BOB) defines the low-speed buffet associated with an approach to the stall and the high-speed buffet associated with shock wave development
Both speeds cause the airflow over the wing to separate from the wing, creating turbulent airflow aft of the separation point on the wing, which causes buffeting of the aeroplane
Taking into consideration the Mach numbers for both low-speed and high-speed buffet, it means that there are two Mach numbers, below and above, which the aeroplane is unable to fly
learning.explanation: The buffet onset boundary (BOB) defines the low-speed buffet associated with an approach to the stall and the high-speed buffet associated with shock wave development. Both speeds cause the airflow over the wing to separate from the wing, creating turbulent airflow aft of the separation point on the wing, which causes buffeting of the aeroplane. Taking into consideration the Mach numbers for both low-speed and high-speed buffet, it means that there are two Mach numbers, below and above, which the aeroplane is unable to fly. This speed range between the Mach numbers for the low-speed stall and high-speed stall is called the buffet margin. The important point to understand is that the margin between the low-speed and high-speed buffets decreases with increasing altitude. It seems that in this question they are asking about the speed and not the margin and the effect of altitude. If we look at the graph, with decreasing altitude the high speed buffet increases and the low speed buffet decreases (increasing the margin).

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Is it a requirement to adjust the TODA for distance used lining up on the runway?

options.B: Only if a backtrack is required to lineup.
options.D: Only if a 90 degree lineup is required.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.01.01.08: Explain how loss of TORA due to alignment is accounted for. EASA AMC1 CAT. POL. A.205 - Take-off LOSS OF RUNWAY LENGTH DUE TO ALIGNMENT (a) The length of the runway that is declared for the calculation of take-off distance available (TODA), accelerate-stop distance available (ASDA) and take-off run available (TORA) does not account for line-up of the aeroplane in the direction of take-off on the runway in use. This alignment distance depends on the aeroplane geometry and access possibility to the runway in use. Accountability is usually required for a 90°-taxiway entry to the runway and 180°-turnaround on the runway. There are two distances to be considered: (1) the minimum distance of the main wheels from the start of the runway for determining TODA and TORA,’L’; and (2) the minimum distance of the most forward wheel(s) from the start of the runway for determining ASDA,’N’. Where the aeroplane manufacturer does not provide the appropriate data, the calculation method given in (b) should be used to determine the alignment distance. The above AMC means that the distance used during lineup with the runway should always be removed from the TORA, TODA and ASDA. This is not the case when the aircraft can lineup on the beginning of the threshold without turning of course, but that is not a very common scenario. In terms of this question, though, any distance used lining up on the runway must be accounted for.

content.question: Choose the speed profile which corresponds to the highest CI (Cost Index):

key_points: The two major variable costs are the cost of fuel and the cost of flight time, excluding fuel
The longer the time airborne, the higher will be the scheduled maintenance, salary and leasing charges
Flying faster will save on flight time costs, but increases the fuel burn and therefore fuel cost
learning.explanation: The two major variable costs are the cost of fuel and the cost of flight time, excluding fuel. The longer the time airborne, the higher will be the scheduled maintenance, salary and leasing charges. Flying faster will save on flight time costs, but increases the fuel burn and therefore fuel cost. The factor derived from the ratio of these two costs, the aircraft operating cost divided by the fuel cost, is called Cost Index (CI) and is given by the formula: CI = Costs incurred over time / Fuel cost. "Costs incurred over time" or "time related costs" contain the sum of several components, such as hourly maintenance cost, flight crew and cabin crew cost per flight hour, the cost of ownership or aircraft rental, overtime, passenger dissatisfaction, hubbing or missed connections, etc. The CI is a number from 0 to a maximum which could, depending on type, be 100, 200, 500, 999 or even 9999. An index of 0 represents maximum range and the maximum value, whatever it is, represents minimum time. It is normal for a company route to have an attached CI. Alternatively, the CI can be manually input by the flight crew. Airlines determine this ratio using a somewhat complex formula that is presented as a number on the flight plan which the crew then sets in the FMS to control the speed. The higher the cost index the faster the speed, the greater the fuel burn and obviously the shorter the flight time. At a cost index of 000 the aircraft will be at maximum range speed (VMR). The effect of a higher cost index is to increase the speeds, thus saving flight time, but increasing the fuel consumption. The effect of a lower Cost Index is the opposite, to decrease the speeds, thus saving fuel but increasing flight time. The only speed profile that corresponds to the highest CI is: 350 kt, Mach 0.8, 350 kt, where all speeds are the highest.

content.question: Which statement with respect to the stepped climb is correct?

options.A: In principle a stepped climb is performed immediately after the aircraft has exceeded the optimum altitude.
options.B: Performing a stepped climb can be up to the 1.3g buffet onset limit.
options.C: A stepped climb provides better economy than a optimum cruise.
options.D: A stepped climb can only be performed when the altitude exceeds the one engine out service ceiling.

key_points: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed
As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range
The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed. As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range. The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change. Optimum altitude increases with reducing aircraft weight: the drag curve will move down and to the left as the weight decreases through fuel burn. The aeroplane maximizes its specific range by remaining at the optimum altitude as it slowly increases (it must climb along the green line shown in the attached figure). As the optimum altitude increases, the specific range increases. However, for a number of reasons, ATC will probably not allow a cruise climb. The compromise between a level cruise and a cruise climb is a step climb. STEP CLIMB means that the airplane climbs to about 2000 ft above the optimum altitude and levels off. As fuel is used and weight falls, the optimum altitude will increase to a point where it is again 2000 ft above the airplane’s current level. And thereafter the climb process can be repeated. This is the most common way of operating jets in real life. The pilot should always aim to use the step climb technique to remain as close as possible to the optimum altitude. Although a climb above the 1.3 g cruise buffet boundary altitude may be possible, it is prudent to maintain the safety that this limiting altitude gives. At times, a further climb may narrow the gap between high speed buffet and low speed buffet, this should be avoided.

content.question: Compared with proper use of fully manual braking, the use of autobrake (1) _____ landing distance, as the aircraft will decelerate at a (2) _____ rate.

key_points: Note: We believe that the question is badly worded, and is open to interpretation
From recent feedback we know that this is a real exam question

Additionally, based on the feedback we received about the answer to this question, we assumed that the “proper use of fully manual braking” mentioned in the question means "MAXIMUM manual braking with antiskid operative"
learning.explanation: Note: We believe that the question is badly worded, and is open to interpretation. From recent feedback we know that this is a real exam question. Additionally, based on the feedback we received about the answer to this question, we assumed that the “proper use of fully manual braking” mentioned in the question means "MAXIMUM manual braking with antiskid operative". Please let us know if you see this question in the exam via the comments, or email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Autobrake is a system where the pilots do not press the aircraft brakes at all, the aircraft instead modulates its own brake pressure to maintain a selected rate of deceleration. There are multiple levels of braking available, for progressively shorter runways, requiring a progressively higher rate of deceleration. Anti-skid must be operative for autobrake to work. The autobrake cannot control the aircraft laterally, so it would be really bad if the wheels locked up (on a wet runway without anti-skid), and therefore it cannot be used at all if anti-skid is not available. EASA tend to refer to a "generic" autobrake system, and this always resembles the Boeing 737 autobrake system, where the autobrake modes are OFF, 1, 2, 3, MAX and RTO. Technically, the maximum rate of deceleration comes from maximum manual braking, or from autobrakes in the RTO mode, and the RTO mode is better in the event of a rejected take-off as it applies the brakes faster and more efficiently than the pilot could usually apply maximum manual braking. Autobrakes 1, 2 and 3 are simple, they produce set rates of deceleration, as does autobrake MAX. Contrary to its name though, autobrake MAX applies a high level of braking, but not quite the maximum brake pressure like max manual or RTO mode. However, autobrake MAX does apply the brakes quickly and efficiently after main gear touchdown, so provides initially a better deceleration than maximum manual braking, however overall, it would then be better to override with max manual to provide the small amount of extra brake pressure, if minimum stopping distance is what you want. Therefore, any landing autobrake setting (even MAX) gives a longer landing distance than using maximum manual braking. We have checked this using Boeing 737 performance figures and they agree with this statement, so we hope that this is what EASA means in this question.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the speed of aquaplaning for a rotating wheel, versus that of a non-rotating wheel?

options.A: A rotating wheel has a lower aquaplaning speed and is more sensitive to aquaplaning during landing.
options.B: A non-rotation wheel has a lower aquaplaning speed and is more sensitive to aquaplaning during landing.
options.C: The two aquaplaning speeds are the same.
options.D: The comparison is only possible when the type of contaminant is known.

key_points: AQUAPLANING/HYDROPLANING On wet surfaces, aeroplane tyres can lose traction and grip due to hydroplaning
This is where the water on the surface can create a slippery layer between the runway and the tyres
This has very low friction, so the tyre will have no traction available to applying braking force, the wheel will "lock up" and the tyre will just skid on a "wedge of water"
learning.explanation: AQUAPLANING/HYDROPLANING On wet surfaces, aeroplane tyres can lose traction and grip due to hydroplaning. This is where the water on the surface can create a slippery layer between the runway and the tyres. This has very low friction, so the tyre will have no traction available to applying braking force, the wheel will "lock up" and the tyre will just skid on a "wedge of water". Hydroplaning occurs differently whether the tyres are spinning or not, and the speed it occurs at is governed by the following two formulas. Tyres are not spinning when the aircraft touches down, hence the increased risk of hydroplaning during landing, rather than during a rejected take-off, which is the other time it could cause problems. (non-rotating wheel) Hydroplaning speed = 7.7 x √(tyre pressure (psi)) (rotating wheel) Hydroplaning speed = 9 x √(tyre pressure (psi)) Therefore the hydroplaning speed is lower for non-rotating wheels, meaning that they are more sensitive to hydroplaning. Note: Hydroplaning and aquaplaning are exactly the same thing, more commonly referred to as hydroplaning.

content.question: What is the effect on the optimum altitude, specific fuel consumption and specific range, when the weight of a jet aircraft is greater than scheduled?

options.A: The optimum altitude increases, the specific fuel consumption decreases and the specific range increases.
options.B: The optimum altitude increases, the specific fuel consumption increases and the specific range decreases.
options.C: The optimum altitude decreases, the specific fuel consumption decreases and the specific range increases.
options.D: The optimum altitude decreases, the specific fuel consumption increases and the specific range decreases.

key_points: Higher altitudes lead to better Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) and as the thrust reduces with altitude, SFC is further improved, when the best range speed at 1
32 VMD corresponds to 90% thrust
Flying at height, means that 1
learning.explanation: Higher altitudes lead to better Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC) and as the thrust reduces with altitude, SFC is further improved, when the best range speed at 1.32 VMD corresponds to 90% thrust. Flying at height, means that 1.32 VMD occurs at a much greater TAS, giving more air miles. The altitude at which all these variables come together is called as "optimum altitude". The optimum flight profile for a jet aircraft requires a climb after take-off to the optimum altitude. An aircraft weight greater than scheduled, will increase the thrust required and fuel flow, will decrease the thrust available and finally the 90% thrust at 1.32 VMD will be achieved at a lower optimum altitude. The SFC is: Fuel flow / Thrust. With an increased fuel flow and decreased thrust available, because of the greater weight, the SFC will increase. The specific range is: SR = TAS / Fuel flow, and expresses the air miles travelled for every amount of fuel. Thus, for an increased fuel flow, because of the greater weight and for a lower TAS, due to the decreased optimum altitude, the specific range will decrease.

content.question:
What advantages can an aerodrome or an operator gain from implementing a Continuous Descent Final Approach (CDFA)?
1. Glide path can be increased from 3 degrees to 5 degrees
2. Reduced engine emissions
3. Reduced airframe noise
4. Reduce noise footprint
5. Mandated speed increase
6. Reduced fuel consumption

key_points: Important Note: We require further feedback on this, as the current options do not have a solid correct answer
Statements 2, 4 and 6 are correct, with 1, 3 and 5 being at least partially incorrect, but the feedback indicates that the correct answer is "1, 2, 4 and 6"

Please remember this for the exam, and make sure to read each statement and option carefully, and evaluate the question based on knowledge and not just this answer, which could have been misremembered
learning.explanation: Important Note: We require further feedback on this, as the current options do not have a solid correct answer. Statements 2, 4 and 6 are correct, with 1, 3 and 5 being at least partially incorrect, but the feedback indicates that the correct answer is "1, 2, 4 and 6". Please remember this for the exam, and make sure to read each statement and option carefully, and evaluate the question based on knowledge and not just this answer, which could have been misremembered. A Continuous Descent Final Approach (CDFA) is a method of non-precision approach where the aircraft descends at a constant angle from a platform altitude to 50 ft above the runway threshold, rather than the old style "dive and drive" method of descending to a MDA/H and flying level until the runway was sighted or the MAP. It has many benefits, the following extract taken from EASA Air Ops. GM1 CAT. OP. MPA 115(b) (4) The advantages of CDFA are as follows: (i) the technique enhances safe approach operations by the utilisation of standard operating practices; (ii) the technique is similar to that used when flying an ILS approach, including when executing the missed approach and the associated missed approach procedure manoeuvre; (iii) the aeroplane attitude may enable better acquisition of visual cues; (iv) the technique may reduce pilot workload; (v) the approach profile is fuel-efficient; (vi) the approach profile affords reduced noise levels; (vii) the technique affords procedural integration with 3D approach operations; and (viii) when used and the approach is flown in a stabilised manner, CDFA is the safest approach technique for all instrument approach operations using NPA procedures. Statements 2, 4 and 6 are correct due to the reduced engine noise, fuel consumption, and therefore emissions. Statement 1 is odd, the feedback shows it to be "correct", but the regulations only allow CDFAs up to a glide path angle of 4.5 degrees, other than for steep approach operations, which is a separate approval. Statement 3 is incorrect, as the airframe noise will be the same whether the aircraft does a CDFA or not, it is really dependent on speed and configuration, and the question does not give enough information to gleam any data about these points. Statement 5 is incorrect, the speeds of approach are not always higher for a CDFA.

content.question: Which of the folowing statements is correct regarding VMBE?

options.A: It must never be lower than 1.1 x VLOF to ensure safe climb.
options.B: It is limited by the stall speed in take-off configuration.
options.C: It must never be higher than V1, in order to be able to stop within the required limits.
options.D: It can be the upper limit of the V1, if a higher value of V1 would go outside the safety margin.

key_points: VMBE is the maximum brake energy speed
It is the speed which an aircraft can safely stop from, without overloading the brakes with energy

The brakes take the vast majority of an aircraft's kinetic energy in as heat, so will have a limit on the temperature they can withstand, which equates to a maximum energy they can stop, before overheating and causing effects like brake fade, brake fires and tyre blowouts
learning.explanation: VMBE is the maximum brake energy speed. It is the speed which an aircraft can safely stop from, without overloading the brakes with energy. The brakes take the vast majority of an aircraft's kinetic energy in as heat, so will have a limit on the temperature they can withstand, which equates to a maximum energy they can stop, before overheating and causing effects like brake fade, brake fires and tyre blowouts. VMBE obviously varies a lot on weight, and the heavier an aircraft is, the more kinetic energy it has at the same speed, so the lower the VMBE. VMBE also depends on temperature and density altitude, as the hotter and higher the airfield is, the higher the groundspeed for any value of IAS. It is an upper limit of V1. If the calculated V1 is higher than the VMBE, then the VMBE should be used as the V1 speed, and this will cause a reduction in the FLLTOM (Field Length Limited Take-Off Mass). If the aircraft were to use a higher V1 than the VMBE speed, braking could be compromised due to overheating, which would cause melting of the fusible plugs in the tyres, brake fires, and brake fade. The annex attached above is the graph and guidance for calculating if the VMBE will be limiting. You do not need to use the graph at all for this question, but it is good to get an association.

key_points: EASA CS Definitions 'V1' means the maximum speed in the take-off at which the pilot must take the first action (e
g
apply brakes, reduce thrust, deploy speed brakes) to stop the aeroplane within the accelerate-stop distance
learning.explanation: EASA CS Definitions 'V1' means the maximum speed in the take-off at which the pilot must take the first action (e.g. apply brakes, reduce thrust, deploy speed brakes) to stop the aeroplane within the accelerate-stop distance. V1 also means the minimum speed in the take-off, following a failure of the critical engine at VEF, at which the pilot can continue the take-off and achieve the required height above the take-off surface within the take-off distance.

content.question: If the anti-skid system is inoperative, which of the following statements is true?

options.C: Take-off with the anti-skid inoperative is never permitted.
options.D: It has no effect on the accelerate-stop distance.

key_points: All modern aircraft are fitted with anti-skid systems
Anti-skid systems are fitted to prevent the brakes "locking up" the wheels by releasing brake pressure before the wheel stops turning, thereby achieving optimum braking performance
It is normal for the anti-skid system to be selected "ON" for every landing and take-off
learning.explanation: All modern aircraft are fitted with anti-skid systems. Anti-skid systems are fitted to prevent the brakes "locking up" the wheels by releasing brake pressure before the wheel stops turning, thereby achieving optimum braking performance. It is normal for the anti-skid system to be selected "ON" for every landing and take-off. With anti-skid system inoperative, if maximum braking is applied, then the wheel locks and a skid develops with reduced friction between the wheels and surface, thus reducing the braking efficiency. Therefore, failure of the anti-skid system will increase the Accelerate-Stop Distance and the Landing Distance required.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the obstacle limited take-off mass for a Performance Class A aeroplane?

options.A: It should be calculated in such a way that it ensures a obstacle clearance margin of 50 ft with respect to the net take-off flight path.
options.B: It cannot be lower than the corresponding climb limited take-off mass.
options.C: It should be determined on the basis of a 35 ft obstacle clearance with respect to the net take-off flight path.
options.D: It allows for turns of up to 30° angle of bank in the take-off path.

key_points: Obstacle Clearance In EU-OPS it states that an operator must ensure that the net take-off flight path must clear all obstacles by a vertical margin of 35 ft for Class A airplanes to 50 ft for Class B airplanes
If the airplane is unable to do so it must turn away from the obstacle and clear it by a horizontal distance of at least a horizontal distance of at least 90 m + 0
125D where D is the distance from the end of the TODA, or the end of the TOD if a turn is scheduled before the end of the TODA
learning.explanation: Obstacle Clearance In EU-OPS it states that an operator must ensure that the net take-off flight path must clear all obstacles by a vertical margin of 35 ft for Class A airplanes to 50 ft for Class B airplanes. If the airplane is unable to do so it must turn away from the obstacle and clear it by a horizontal distance of at least a horizontal distance of at least 90 m + 0.125D where D is the distance from the end of the TODA, or the end of the TOD if a turn is scheduled before the end of the TODA. For airplanes with a wingspan of less than 60 m the horizontal distance may be taken as 60 m + half the wingspan + 0.125D.

content.question: During the flight preparation the climb limited take-off mass (TOM) is found to be much greater than the field length limited TOM using 5° flap. In what way can the performance limited TOM be increased? There are no limiting obstacles.

options.B: By selecting a higher flap setting
options.C: By selecting a lower flap setting

key_points: T/O Flap setting Increasing flap angle increases CLMAX, which reduces stalling speed and take-off speed
, this reduces the take-off distance
Increasing flap angle increases drag, reducing acceleration, and increasing the take-off distance
learning.explanation: T/O Flap setting Increasing flap angle increases CLMAX, which reduces stalling speed and take-off speed., this reduces the take-off distance. Increasing flap angle increases drag, reducing acceleration, and increasing the take-off distance. The effect is that take-off distance will decrease with increase of flap angle but above a certain flap angle the take-off distance will increase again. The flap setting will affect the climb gradient, and this will affect the Maximum TOM which is determined by a climb gradient requirement, and the clearance of obstacles in the take-off flight path. Increasing the flap angle increases the drag, and so reduces the climb gradient for a given aircraft mass. A greater take-off mass may be obtained by using a higher flap setting (for instance, flaps 5º instead of flaps 1º), when not limited by TODA.

options.B: a specific range which is approximately 99% of maximum specific range and a higher cruise speed.
options.C: a 1% higher TAS for maximum specific range.

This speed is used because getting to destination more quickly, more revenue earning flights can be carried out for a given period

Operationally a faster “long range cruise” is used. This speed is used because getting to destination more quickly, more revenue earning flights can be carried out for a given period. For a given time period, 4% more flights can be carried out with only a fuel consumption increase of 1%.

content.question:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the take-off climb-gradient requirements for a Performance Class A aeroplane?
The climb-gradient requirement in...
1. each take-off climb segment is a flight path climb gradient,
2. the second segment of a four-engined aeroplane is higher than that of a two-engined aeroplane,
3. the first segment is based on all engines operating,
4. the first segment is lower than that of the second segment,
5. the second segment assumes flaps and slats retracted,
6. the final segment is achieved with maximum continuous thrust.

key_points: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, one engine inoperative, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative
On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15 ft
Operating engines are at take-off thrust, the flaps/slats are in take-off configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb
learning.explanation: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, one engine inoperative, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative. On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15 ft. Operating engines are at take-off thrust, the flaps/slats are in take-off configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb. The first segment ends when the landing gear is fully retracted. Begins when the landing gear is fully retracted. Engines are at take-off thrust and the flaps/slats are in the take-off configuration. This segment ends at the higher of 400 ft. Begins at 400 ft or higher specified acceleration altitude. Engines are at take-off thrust and the aircraft is accelerated in level flight. Slats/flaps are retracted on speed. The segment ends when aircraft is in clean configuration and the final take-off speed has been achieved. Once this has happened, thrust can be reduced from maximum take-off thrust, TOGA, to maximum continuous thrust, MCT. Starts when the flaps are retracted, the final segment speed is achieved, and the thrust is set to maximum continuous thrust. From this point the airplane is climbed to above 1500 ft where the take-off flight path ends. The climb gradient for this last stage must not be less than 1.2%. 1st Segment 2nd Segment 3rd Segment 4th Segment Starts 35 ft Gear Up > 400 ft AGL Flaps Up VFTO MCT Action Select Gear Up Climb to > 400 ft AGL Retract Flaps Accelerate to VFTO Set MCT Climb to 1500 ft AGL Gradient for 2 Engines > 0% > 2.4% N/A > 1.2% Gradient for 3 Engines > 0.3% > 2.7% N/A > 1.5% Gradient for 4 Engines > 0.5% > 3.0% N/A > 1.7%

content.question:
An operator is planning a flight to an aerodrome where its pavements show signs of failure. He/she should depart also from this aerodrome later. Given the following information, are there any associated hazards to this operation? (For simplicity purposes, the subgrade categories, tyre pressure limits, and codes for the evaluation methods have been omitted).
Apron PCN: 43
Taxiway PCN: 37
Runway PCN: 46
ACN for the planned landing mass: 36
ACN for the planned take-off mass: 42

options.A: The above operation has NO associated hazards as the planned landing mass ACN is lower than all three published PCNs.
options.B: The above operation has NO associated hazards as the ACNs for the planned landing and take-off masses are lower than the runway PCN.
options.C: There is a potential hazard due to operating at an ACN higher than the taxiway PCN during departure.
options.D: There is a potential hazard due to operating at an ACN lower than the runway PCN during arrival and departure.

key_points: Aircraft Classification Number (ACN) This is a value assigned to an airplane to show its load force
The aircraft classification number must be compared to the pavement classification number (PCN) of an aerodrome

The ACN should be lower than the PCN, however, "overload operations" can be undertaken as long as they are only occasional, with the ACN exceeding the PCN by up to 5% or 10% dependent on the surface type
learning.explanation: Aircraft Classification Number (ACN) This is a value assigned to an airplane to show its load force. The aircraft classification number must be compared to the pavement classification number (PCN) of an aerodrome. The ACN should be lower than the PCN, however, "overload operations" can be undertaken as long as they are only occasional, with the ACN exceeding the PCN by up to 5% or 10% dependent on the surface type. Overload operations are NOT allowed on surfaces exhibiting signs of distress or failure. This means that we must be strict with the numbers in this question, and ACN must be lower than PCN in all cases. The ACN is lower than the PCN in most cases, but the ACN for the planned take-off mass exceeds the taxiway PCN. This causes a hazard to the planned operation during the following departure.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
The departure airport reports an air temperature of -5ºC. Using the data below, which statement is correct? (SEL OAT is equivalent to the assumed temperature of FLEX)
V1: 132 kt
Flaps: 5 degrees
VR: 132 kt
SEL OAT: +59ºC
V2: 139 kt

options.A: The SEL value will only be considered when it is lower than the air temprature at the airport. it is the lowest of either the SEL OAT or the airport air temprature that determines the take-off thrust for the engines.
options.B: SEL OAT wil force the engine control computer to think the air temprature is +59ºC and therefore that the air density is low and the engine requires less fuel to maintain the correct fuel/air ratio. This leads to less thrust being produced.
options.C: By entering the SEL OAT value the engine will produce a greater amount of thrust since a higher SEL OAT value will tell the engine that the air is warmer. This means that more fuel is required to maintain the thrust when the air is less dense.
options.D: SEL OAT is a parameter that is used to modify the take-off performance calculation in order find the appropriate thrust setting and is NOT entered in any aeroplane systems. The aeroplane can only work with the actual air temperature.

key_points: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude
The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs
Secondary advantages include fuel savings
learning.explanation: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude. The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs. Secondary advantages include fuel savings. There are two methods of achieving an acurately controlled reduction in engine thrust: Derate; and Assumed temperature (sometimes referred to as Flexible temperature or FLEX). An assumed temperature take-off is where the engine thrust is reduced to match the performance on a higher-temperature day, up to either the maximum thrust reduction allowed or the maximum assumed temperature that meets take-off distance requirements. In simple words, a higher temperature means lower air density; in turn, less fuel has to be added to obtain the correct fuel/air ratio => This decreases fuel flow and thrust produced.

content.question: What factors need to be taken into account when calculating the take-off performance for an MRJT ferry flight in very cold temperatures?

options.A: The use of anti-icing and de-icing equipment is not necessary for take-off performance calculation.
options.B: The weight of the aircraft has no effect on the take-off performance in cold temperatures.
options.D: V1 cannot be limited in any way due to regulatory requirements.

key_points: For reference, refer to CAP698, Section 4
There you can find the 'Density Sub Graph' and below on 'Figure 4
8 Take-Off Speeds' the effect of temperature and density on VMCG and V1
learning.explanation: For reference, refer to CAP698, Section 4. There you can find the 'Density Sub Graph' and below on 'Figure 4.8 Take-Off Speeds' the effect of temperature and density on VMCG and V1. At low temperatures and low-pressure altitudes where the air density is high, the value of VMCG is also high. Therefore, we can say that as density increases, VMCG increases. V1 is also affected by density due to the temperature effect on density: as density increases, V1 decreases. V1 cannot be allowed to be less than VMCG because engine failure below VMCG means the airplane is uncontrollable, and the definition of V1 is that the takeoff can be continued following engine failure. Given the above, with low temperatures and, therefore, higher density, VMCG increases and V1 decreases. But as V1 cannot be lower than VMGC, at lower temperatures, V1 may be limited by the value of VMCG.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
An aeroplane is maintaining FL350 at 250 kt CAS when an engine failure forces the pilot to commence a driftdown procedure. The pilot reports to ATC that the driftdown procedure has commenced. Which one should the pilot use of the three driftdown speeds below?
1. Obstacle clearance speed (210 CAS)
2. Normal speed (240 CAS)
3. Faster speed (360 CAS)

options.A: Use faster CAS, first, you need to gain speed before descending.
options.B: Use normal descent as this will get you down the fastest.
options.C: Use normal descent as this will take you the furthest.
options.D: Use obstacle descent as this will give the best obstacle clearance.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.04.01.03: Describe the optimum speed that the pilot should select during drift-down. If an engine fails in the cruise, then the remaining engine(s) are set to Maximum Continuous Thrust (MCT), in an attempt to maintain height. At cruise altitudes, the attempt to maintain height usually fails, because of inadequate thrust on the remaining engine(s) and the aircraft will descend down to a height at which it is able to stabilise. This is called "driftdown" and it is a "power on" descent. The driftdown is flown at the best angle of descent speed, which is VMD. Also, the greatest excess thrust is found at VMD and it minimizes the descent angle. A deceleration to VMD at FL350, will create a nose-up attitude and will delay for some seconds the commencement of the descent, improving that way the obstacle clearance. Thus, the Obstacle clearance speed, where the cruise speed of 250 kt CAS is reduced to the Minimum drag speed VMD before commencing the descent, improves the obstacle clearance. Using the obstacle clearance speed maximizes cruise altitude and minimizes the rate of descent for the best off-engine altitude in the given conditions.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which figure represents the effect on take-off distance when considering the engine failure case?

key_points: The graphs depict the Take-Off Distance (TOD) with differing flap settings (the dotted lines are the all-engines case, AEO - All Engines Operative) and how that changes in the event of an engine failure (OEI - One Engine Inoperative)
The effect of flaps on TOD is as follows: Initially, increasing flap setting (from no flaps) reduces the take-off distance as the aircraft can lift-off at a lower speed, reducing the Take-Off Run
At a certain point though, the extra drag of high flap settings becomes a problem, as the aircraft will require more distance to accelerate and much more distance to reach the screen height
learning.explanation: The graphs depict the Take-Off Distance (TOD) with differing flap settings (the dotted lines are the all-engines case, AEO - All Engines Operative) and how that changes in the event of an engine failure (OEI - One Engine Inoperative). The effect of flaps on TOD is as follows: Initially, increasing flap setting (from no flaps) reduces the take-off distance as the aircraft can lift-off at a lower speed, reducing the Take-Off Run. At a certain point though, the extra drag of high flap settings becomes a problem, as the aircraft will require more distance to accelerate and much more distance to reach the screen height. This extra distance eventually outweighs the small reduction in lift-off speeds when using high flap settings. This creates the curved pattern The final part of this question is to work out whether TOD increases or decreases if an engine fails. If an engine fails at VEF (the most limiting point of the take-off run), then the aircraft will have to perform the rest of the take-off and climb to screen height with half the thrust, so much less performance. Therefore, the TOD in the OEI case is longer than in the AEO scenario, and therefore the graph moves upwards in the event of an engine failure, so the correct answer is figure 4.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
Which of the following statements are correct, concerning the determination of VMCG, the minimum control speed on the ground?
1. VMCG must be determined using rudder control alone.
2. During the VMCG determination, the CG should be on the forward limit.
3. Reduced thrust may be used during the VMCG determination.
4. The aircraft may NOT deviate more than 9.1 m (30 ft) laterally from the centre line

key_points: VMCG, the minimum control speed on the ground, is the calibrated airspeed during the take-off run, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the airplane using the rudder control alone (without the use of nose wheel steering) to enable the take-off to be safely continued using normal piloting skill

In simple words, if an engine fails below VMCG during the take-off run, then the aircraft will not be able to stay on the runway (determined as within 30 ft of the centreline) using rudder deflection force alone
We are not allowed to use nose-wheel steering when testing VMCG as it would not work as well if the runway is wet
learning.explanation: VMCG, the minimum control speed on the ground, is the calibrated airspeed during the take-off run, at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the airplane using the rudder control alone (without the use of nose wheel steering) to enable the take-off to be safely continued using normal piloting skill. In simple words, if an engine fails below VMCG during the take-off run, then the aircraft will not be able to stay on the runway (determined as within 30 ft of the centreline) using rudder deflection force alone. We are not allowed to use nose-wheel steering when testing VMCG as it would not work as well if the runway is wet. When determining VMCG, the aircraft must be at: maximum available take-off power or thrust on the engines. the airplane trimmed for take-off. the most unfavourable CG position. maximum sea level take-off weight. Because the aircraft rotates laterally around the CG, the position of the CG directly affects the length of the moment arm of the rudder and, thus, the power of the rudder and fin to maintain directional stability and control. The ‘worst case’ is with the CG at the aft limit, so this is where the CG is when the VMCG is determined. If the requirements can be met in this configuration, the ability to maintain directional control will be enhanced at any other CG location. A more forward CG decreases VMCG.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: On a transatlantic flight, the captain asks the First Officer why a final step climb from FL340 to FL380 ten minutes before top of descent might not be an efficient use of the fuel. Select a possible explanation:

options.A: A climb to FL380 might consume more fuel than would be saved by being at the higher altitude for a short period.
options.B: The headwind present at FL 340 might be more favourable than the still air conditions at FL380.
options.C: Even in still air, cruising at the higher optimum level would decrease the specific range.
options.D: There might be stronger tailwinds at FL380.

key_points: OPTIMUM ALTITUDES ON SHORT STAGES Airbus philosophy assumes a minimum 5 minute cruise sector, because a climb followed immediately by the descent is not appreciated by pilots, passengers or ATC
If the stage length is of sufficient length that the optimum flight level can be reached, but the cruise is of short duration, then the benefits at this flight level will be marginal
It may even be worthwhile to cruise at one flight level lower, as the increased climb consumption offsets any reduced cruise consumption
learning.explanation: OPTIMUM ALTITUDES ON SHORT STAGES Airbus philosophy assumes a minimum 5 minute cruise sector, because a climb followed immediately by the descent is not appreciated by pilots, passengers or ATC. If the stage length is of sufficient length that the optimum flight level can be reached, but the cruise is of short duration, then the benefits at this flight level will be marginal. It may even be worthwhile to cruise at one flight level lower, as the increased climb consumption offsets any reduced cruise consumption.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: In the cruise, a pilot begins preparing for landing by performing an in-flight landing performance calculation, incorporating the use of autobrakes and spoilers onto a dry runway. The result does NOT satisfy the pilot, who decides to perform the same calculation again, incorporating reverse thrust as well as autobrakes and spoilers. Compared with the first calculation, the newly calculated landing distance will be...

options.A: nearly the same, because the deceleration due to application of reverse thrust will result in an equivalent reduction in the rate of deceleration provided by the autobrake system.
options.B: invalid, because the use of reverse thrust is NOT allowed on dry runways.
options.C: considerably reduced, because the deceleration due to application of reverse thrust in combination with the use of autobrakes will result in an increase in the total deceleration rate.
options.D: increased, because the use of reverse thrust will cancel the operation of the autobrake system.

key_points: Whilst this question is quite complex if you begin to dig into it, we can make it simpler by working out what the examiner is really asking about

Since there is often so much stress put into the fact that autobrakes brake at a constant rate of deceleration, and that is mentioned in a few of the options, we can assume that we are really being asked about that
The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO)
learning.explanation: Whilst this question is quite complex if you begin to dig into it, we can make it simpler by working out what the examiner is really asking about. Since there is often so much stress put into the fact that autobrakes brake at a constant rate of deceleration, and that is mentioned in a few of the options, we can assume that we are really being asked about that. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation; with inoperative anti-skid, the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. The selected deceleration mode will give a standard deceleration rate independent of the weight of the aircraft for a dry runway. This standard deceleration rate means that the use of other deceleration methods will simply take some of the energy away from the brakes, making their job easier. The autobrake system does not care how easy the braking is though, it is very set on gaining a constant rate of deceleration, so applying even maximum reverse thrust would not change the rate of deceleration, it would just make the brakes cooler at the end of the landing. As per the correct option, the deceleration rate caused by the brakes just reduces due to the deceleration rate of the reverse thrust, making the total deceleration rate the same as if it were just the autobrakes working alone. Note that the question does gloss over a few complexities, though. The runway being considered "dry" is the examiner's way of saying "we have as much traction as we want", so we can assume that the aircraft is not going to be "out-braking" itself and requiring the use of the antiskid system. This is when the reverse thrust system becomes really useful, when braking is reduced by low traction and the reverse thrust provides the majority of the deceleration force. Answer B is incorrect because reverse thrust is used on almost all landings, dry or wet runways. It is trying to confuse you with the requirements for calculating ASDA to only include reverse thrust when wet.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
CS 25.119 states the landing climb requirement for a large aeroplane. To assess this requirement, what are the power or thrust control positions used?
The power or thrust controls are:

options.B: Moved to the go-around position from the approach position.
options.D: Moved from the minimum flight idle to go-around position.

key_points: CS 25

119 Landing climb: all-engines-operating In the landing configuration, the steady gradient of climb may not be less than 3·2%, with the engines at the power or thrust that is available 8 seconds after initiation of movement of the power or thrust controls from the minimum flight idle to the go-around power or thrust setting (see AMC 25
119); and (a) In non-icing conditions, with a climb speed of VREF determined in accordance with CS 25

content.question:
Refer to figure.
A pilot is considering the possibility of having to carry out a rejected take-off on a flooded runway and is evaluating the aircraft configuration and the selection of the take-off speeds. Given the following information, choose the lowest possible flap setting that would avoid dynamic hydroplaning in case of a rejected take-off.
Take-off Mass: 70000 kg
Tyre pressure: 200 psi

key_points: Hydroplaning is caused by a thin layer of standing water that separates the tires from the runway
It causes substantial reduction in friction between the airplane tires and the runway surface and results in poor or nil braking action at high speeds
High aircraft speed, standing water, slush, and a smooth runway texture are factors conductive to hydroplaning
learning.explanation: Hydroplaning is caused by a thin layer of standing water that separates the tires from the runway. It causes substantial reduction in friction between the airplane tires and the runway surface and results in poor or nil braking action at high speeds. High aircraft speed, standing water, slush, and a smooth runway texture are factors conductive to hydroplaning. Dynamic hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water or slush on the runway deeper than the tread depth of the tyres. A wedge of water builds up, lifting the tires away from the runway surface. The speed of the airplane, the depth of the water, and the air pressure in the tires are some of the factors that affect dynamic hydroplaning. HYDROPLANING SPEED CALCULATIONS: Rotating Tyres formula (applies to rejected take-offs): V = 9 √ P NON-Rotating Tyres formula (applies to touchdown): V = 7.7 √ P Where V stands for velocity (kt) and P is tyre pressure (PSI) In this case, the aircraft is taking off: V = 9 √ 200 = approx. 127 kt => Take-off must be aborted up to V1, consequently, we must make sure that V1 is lower than the speed for Dynamic Hydroplaning 127 kt. Referring to the provided table, the lowest flap setting which can be used is FLAPS 10.
