content.question:
After calculating the following take-off figures, what would be the consequence of the pilots accidentally entering a V1 value of 124 kt.
V1: 142 kt
VR: 142 kt
V2: 145 kt

options.A: TOD is not affected though the aircraft may not become airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.
options.B: TOD is not affected and the aircraft will not encounter any additional challenges in becoming airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.
options.C: TOD would decrease significantly and the aircraft might not be able to get airborne before the end of the runway in case of engine failure.
options.D: TOD would increase significantly and the aircraft may not become airborne before the end of the runway in case of an engine failure.

key_points: V1 is the take-off decision speed
It is the point on the take-off run where the pilots will go from stopping if there is an emergency to continuing

It is created from the maximum speed at which the aircraft can get to and stop again within the ASDA (Accelerate-Stop Distance Available), and the minimum speed where the aircraft can accelerate the rest of the way to V2 speed and screen height by the end of the TODA (Take-Off Distance Available)
learning.explanation: V1 is the take-off decision speed. It is the point on the take-off run where the pilots will go from stopping if there is an emergency to continuing. It is created from the maximum speed at which the aircraft can get to and stop again within the ASDA (Accelerate-Stop Distance Available), and the minimum speed where the aircraft can accelerate the rest of the way to V2 speed and screen height by the end of the TODA (Take-Off Distance Available). Sometimes there is a range of V1 speeds that can be chosen from, if the aircraft is under its FLLTOM (Field Length Limiting Take-Off Mass), but we usually choose the "balanced V1", which gives the same ASD as TOD in the event of an engine failure at VEF (just before V1). Choosing a V1 that is much too low, such as in this question, means that the changeover point from STOP to GO (if an event happens) will happen much earlier in the take-off roll, which will cause a greatly reduced ASD (Accelerate-Stop Distance) in the event of a rejected take-off, as the aircraft would spend less runway getting up to speed, then have to stop from a lower speed. The big problem is that, in the event of an engine failure at 124 kt, the aircraft would then have to accelerate all the way from 124 kt to 145 kt and reach the screen height (usually 35 ft) by the end of the TODA, when there is half the thrust of normal operation. As you can see from the calculated figures, the aircrat is only supposed to accelerate from 142 kt to 145 kt on one engine (and climb to 35 ft), so asking it for just over 20 kts single engine acceleration will cause the TOD to increase greatly, with the aircraft rotating very late, making it unlikely to reach the screen height in sufficient distance, also reducing obstacle clearance in the climb out. Note: This question does not make it absolutely clear that we are considering the one engine inoperative scenario for the TOD, but our best feedback has given the correct answer we currently have, so this is the assumption we have had to make. Please send any further feedback to us in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions so we can verify this, thank you.

content.question: Which of the following statements describes typical characteristics of Continuous Descent Arrivals (CDAs). By performing a CDA the aircraft...

options.A: remains higher for longer and operates at lower engine thrust.
options.B: descends earlier, flies faster and saves flight time.
options.C: descends earlier and operates at lower engine thrust.
options.D: descends step-wise with portions of level flight as required, until starting the approach.

key_points: Continuous Descent Arrival (CDA) is an aircraft operating technique in which an arriving aircraft descends from an optimal position with minimum thrust and avoids level flight to the extent permitted by the safe operation of the aircraft and compliance with published procedures and ATC instructions
The meaning of a CDA is to avoid having to level off in stages, during the descent phase and to plan an approach/descent at idle thrust as far as is possible
The purpose of this is to reduce noise and save fuel, not time, by keeping the aircraft as high as possible for as long as possible
learning.explanation: Continuous Descent Arrival (CDA) is an aircraft operating technique in which an arriving aircraft descends from an optimal position with minimum thrust and avoids level flight to the extent permitted by the safe operation of the aircraft and compliance with published procedures and ATC instructions. The meaning of a CDA is to avoid having to level off in stages, during the descent phase and to plan an approach/descent at idle thrust as far as is possible. The purpose of this is to reduce noise and save fuel, not time, by keeping the aircraft as high as possible for as long as possible. This implies that you start your descent at the correct point. If you start your descent too early, you have to either apply thrust in the descent to arrive at the bottom of descent at the right place, or level off and then apply thrust. If you start your descent too late, you have to apply the speedbrakes so as to increase the drag and arrive at the bottom of the descent point. Despite the fact that the question does not take into consideration the "bad" option of starting the descent too late, which requires speedbrakes, the wrong answers only consider a wasteful early descent. Therefore, the statement "remains higher for longer and operates at lower engine thrust", matches better.

content.question: An aeroplane receives a late descent clearance from ATC due to opposite traffic with all factors being equal and constant. Choose the correct statement. The pilot may:

options.A: Increase drag by increasing the airspeed and therefore increasing the descent angle, reducing the energy state of the aeroplane due to extra drag.
options.B: Use speed brakes and maintain planned descent speed, however, the aeroplane will have a higher energy state when back on the planned profile.
options.C: Increase the airspeed to regain the vertical profile, however, the aeroplane will have a higher energy state when back on the planned profile.
options.D: Slow down and use speed brakes to increase the drag and increase the descent angle since the speed brakes are more effective at lower airspeed.

key_points: Note: We believe that there are two answers that could be considered correct here, and we have had to change the answer and option wording based on some recent feedback

We do believe that the current correct answer is the most correct, and we also believe that we may be missing some information that makes the other option more incorrect, or changes the interpretation slightly
We are therefore asking for any further feedback you can remember from the exams, even if it is just a small change in wording that you noticed
learning.explanation: Note: We believe that there are two answers that could be considered correct here, and we have had to change the answer and option wording based on some recent feedback. We do believe that the current correct answer is the most correct, and we also believe that we may be missing some information that makes the other option more incorrect, or changes the interpretation slightly. We are therefore asking for any further feedback you can remember from the exams, even if it is just a small change in wording that you noticed. It is all useful for trying to verify the exact question, options and correct answer, thank you! When an aircraft is required to descend later than planned, it is put into a high energy state, meaning that has either too much speed (kinetic energy) or height (potential energy) to perform a standard descent. Ways to reduce this total energy include reducing thrust and increasing drag. In this question thrust is not mentioned (large jet aircraft usually descend at idle thrust), so we must increase our drag somehow. Ways to increase drag include: Increasing aircraft speed (although this does mean the aircraft will have to be slowed down eventually). Extending speedbrakes (more effective at high airspeeds) Using flaps (only works at slower speeds and gives a much lower maximum airspeed to stay below). Extending landing gear early (usually only recommended near to the approach). To go through the options: "Increase drag by increasing the airspeed and therefore increasing the descent angle, reducing the energy state of the aeroplane due to extra drag." Whilst this could be considered correct, there is a more correct option present which explains this option better, and we are still unsure of the exact wording of this answer (we think we are missing a key part that will make it incorrect). "Use speed brakes and maintain planned descent speed, however, the aeroplane will have a higher energy state when back on the planned profile." Whilst this is an acceptable way to reduce excess energy, the aircraft would not have a higher energy state when it gets back on profile, as it would be at the correct speed, and the correct altitude for that position, so it would have the right energy state. Therefore, this is incorrect. "Increase the airspeed to regain the vertical profile, however, the aeroplane will have a higher energy state when back on the planned profile." Correct. Increasing the speed in the descent allows the aircraft to trade altitude for speed, and will be able to get back on the profile, but now at a higher speed. This is a good method of energy management, as now the aircraft is back on the correct profile and at a higher speed, which will naturally want to reduce due to extra drag (and speedbrakes will be more effective at this higher speed also). "Slow down and use speed brakes to increase the drag and increase the descent angle since the speed brakes are more effective at lower airspeed." Incorrect. Speed brakes are more effective at higher airspeeds.

options.B: All engines operating and it will be lower at high temperatures.
options.C: All engines operating and it will be lower at low temperatures.
options.D: The critical engine inoperative, and it will be higher at higher temperatures.

key_points: VMC (or VMCA) is the minimum control speed in the air, following a failure of the critical engine

Once airborne with a critical engine failure, the minimum control speed, VMC, is the minimum CAS at which the pilot can maintain heading within 20o, using no more than 5 degrees of bank angle and with the live engine(s) at the maximum available take-off power
Below VMC it will not be possible to maintain control of the aircraft using the primary flying controls alone
learning.explanation: VMC (or VMCA) is the minimum control speed in the air, following a failure of the critical engine. Once airborne with a critical engine failure, the minimum control speed, VMC, is the minimum CAS at which the pilot can maintain heading within 20o, using no more than 5 degrees of bank angle and with the live engine(s) at the maximum available take-off power. Below VMC it will not be possible to maintain control of the aircraft using the primary flying controls alone. For each aircraft, VMC is a single speed defined during certification. It is effectively tested in worse case conditions and therefore you may find, on the day, that the aircraft is easier to control than you expect. This provides a desirable safety margin. The factors which could cause the "happy" situation where the actual minimum control speed is lower than the published VMC is temperature, pressure altitude and humidity. With increased temperature, pressure altitude and humidity, the asymetric thrust or power reduces, which will result in a decreased minimum control speed.

V1 is also the minimum speed at which a pilot can continue takeoff following an engine failure
Following an engine failure, the overall thrust is decreased and the drag is increased
learning.explanation: The Take-off Decision Speed (V1) is the maximum speed at which a rejected take-off can be initiated and a stop within the ASDA can be accomplished with the critical engine inoperative. V1 is also the minimum speed at which a pilot can continue takeoff following an engine failure. Following an engine failure, the overall thrust is decreased and the drag is increased. Consequently, the aircraft will accelerate more slowly. With a higher V1, the acceleration to VLOF to be achieved on one engine is smaller than with a lower V1. Therefore, the aircraft will take-off sooner (closer to the line-up position). It will then climb at the same shallow angle as with a lower V1. Therefore climb perfomance remains unchanged. Regarding obstacle clearance, with a higher V1, the overall climb performance is improved. Furthermore, a higher V1 decreases the take-off distance required because for an engine failure go condition, the aircraft will have to accelerate a lesser margin on single engine between V1 and VR. IMPORTANT NOTE: This question contradicts question (329085) in the sense that climb performance remains unchanged. It seems that question 329085 refers to the climb performance regarding obstacle clearance. We would kindly ask anyone who comes across this question to contact us at their earliest convenience. Furthermore, 329085 refers to the stopping performance rather than the take-off distance required. Please note that choosing a lower V1 will improve the stopping distance alone because it will imply that an engine failure can be accepted at a lower speed, meaning that the aircraft will also initiate its deceleration at a lower speed.

content.question: What is the effect of a wet runway on V1?

options.C: V1 is independent of runway condition

key_points: On a wet or contaminated runway, the takeoff distance required will increase because of the additional wheel drag and impingement drag
Therefore, the takeoff performance must be changed

The accelerate-stop distance will increase because of the increased distance to accelerate and the increased distance to stop the aircraft, resulting from the reduced runway coefficient of braking friction
learning.explanation: On a wet or contaminated runway, the takeoff distance required will increase because of the additional wheel drag and impingement drag. Therefore, the takeoff performance must be changed. The accelerate-stop distance will increase because of the increased distance to accelerate and the increased distance to stop the aircraft, resulting from the reduced runway coefficient of braking friction. For the given distances available, the maximum takeoff mass and V1 will therefore be reduced compared to the dry runway. The greater the depth of contamination, the greater the mass reduction and the less the V1 reduction. Additionally, VMCG will have to be checked against V1.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Which of the following is the correct method for applying steel brakes?

options.B: To refrain from applying the brakes until below a particular speed, listed in the flight manual.
options.C: Autobraking must always be used in conjunction with steel brakes.

key_points: Whilst this is more of a question that belongs in AGK, we have strong evidence to say that it is also a question in the Performance exam
The two usual materials for aircraft brakes are steel and carbon
They vary somewhat in characteristics, and in cost
learning.explanation: Whilst this is more of a question that belongs in AGK, we have strong evidence to say that it is also a question in the Performance exam. The two usual materials for aircraft brakes are steel and carbon. They vary somewhat in characteristics, and in cost. Steel brakes are usually much cheaper than carbon brakes. Steel brakes perform better at lower temperatures, and when they get hot, suffer from brake fade, where the rotors do not apply as much traction onto the stators due to the intense heat. Carbon brakes, however, have a much hotter operating window. In fact, carbon brakes are not very effective at low temperatures, so need to have some heat in them already, to be able to produce the peak braking force. This is why the two types should be treated differently. Steel brakes should be kept cool, by using them softly with gaps to allow them to cool. Carbon brakes, on the other hand, should be applied firmly all at once when possible, to allow them to work in their operating window as much as possible.

content.question: For jet aeroplanes which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: An anti-skid system malfunction has no effect on the required landing field length.
options.B: The required landing field length is the distance from 35 ft to the full stop point.
options.C: When determining the maximum allowable landing mass at destination, 60% of the available distance is taken into account, if the runway is expected to be dry.
options.D: In any case runway slope is one of the factors taken into account when determining the required landing field length.

key_points: For dispatching the aircraft, the maximum allowable landing mass at destination must be determined on the most limiting runway, in still air conditions, and on the runway most likely to be assigned to the aircraft on arrival
When making these calculations, Class A jet aircraft must be assumed to land and stop within 60% of the Landing Distance Available (LDA)
This is in addition to any factors for wet runways
learning.explanation: For dispatching the aircraft, the maximum allowable landing mass at destination must be determined on the most limiting runway, in still air conditions, and on the runway most likely to be assigned to the aircraft on arrival. When making these calculations, Class A jet aircraft must be assumed to land and stop within 60% of the Landing Distance Available (LDA). This is in addition to any factors for wet runways. This percentage factor can also be expressed as multiplication and division factor: Actual Landing Distance <= 60% of LDA or, Actual Landing Distance x 1.67 <= LDA or, Actual Landing Distance <= LDA / 1.67 NOTE: The corresponding regulatory factor for a turboprop is 70%.

content.question: On short final to land on a visibly damp runway, you notice significant rubber deposits on the touchdown zone. The runway is long so little to no braking is required to stop before the end of the runway. Which of the following is most correct with regards to hydroplaning?

options.A: Dynamic hydroplaning would occur, but will not have an effect due to the light braking.
options.B: Dynamic hydroplaning will not occur due to the lack of braking.
options.C: Viscous hydroplaning may occur in the touchdown zone due to the rubber and water.
options.D: Dynamic hydroplaning is less likely to occur due to the extra deceleration of the rubber deposits on the runway.

key_points: Note: This is quite similar to question 322315, which we believe is seen more often, but we are treating this as a slightly different question that some students are reporting from different authorities
Hydroplaning is caused by a thin layer of fluid that separates the tires from the runway
It causes substantial reduction in friction between the airplane tires and the runway surface and results in poor/no braking action and directional controllability
learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to question 322315, which we believe is seen more often, but we are treating this as a slightly different question that some students are reporting from different authorities. Hydroplaning is caused by a thin layer of fluid that separates the tires from the runway. It causes substantial reduction in friction between the airplane tires and the runway surface and results in poor/no braking action and directional controllability. High aircraft speed, standing water, slush, and a smooth runway texture are factors conductive to hydroplaning. Dynamic hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water or slush on the runway deeper than the tread depth of the tyres. A wedge of water builds up, lifting the tires away from the runway surface. The speed of the airplane, the depth of the water, and the air pressure in the tires are some of the factors that affect dynamic hydroplaning. Viscous hydroplaning can occur when oil or accumulated rubber combines with water on a runway, it forms a very thin, impenetrable layer of slippery liquid your tires can’t break through. This is especially problematic on smooth runways, and it can occur on just a thin film of water. Viscous hydroplaning typically occurs in the touchdown zone of the runway, where you get a build-up of black rubber deposit. Reverted rubber hydroplaning is the result of a prolonged locked-wheel skid, in which reverted rubber acts as a seal between the tire and the runway. Entrapped water is heated to form steam, which supports the tire off the pavement. Particularly important in this question is the mention of the rubber deposits in the touchdown zone and the runway being damp (indicating viscous hydroplaning). As an extra help, the examiner says that the runway is long so heavy braking is not required, and is damp (not wet), which reduces the chance of dynamic hydroplaning, particularly as there is not enough water on a "damp runway" for dynamic hydroplaning.

content.question: A pilot is calculating the take-off speeds for a contaminated runway and chooses a “Wet V1”. Should he/she expect this “Wet V1” to be higher or lower compared to V1 for dry runway conditions?

options.A: Runway surface conditions have NO effect on the V1 calculation.
options.B: “Wet V1” would be higher for wet runway conditions.
options.C: “Wet V1” would be lower for wet runway conditions.
options.D: “Wet V1” would be equal to V2.

key_points: A dry (maximum) V1 is the normal decision speed that following an engine failure allows the take-off to be continued safely within the TODA or to be stopped safely within the ASDA
A wet (minimum) V1 is the maximum speed for abandoning a take-off on a contaminated runway

A wet V1 improves the stopping capabilities (final stop point) back to the dry conditions level but degrades the takeoff chances with a reduced screen height in the event of a take-off being continued
learning.explanation: A dry (maximum) V1 is the normal decision speed that following an engine failure allows the take-off to be continued safely within the TODA or to be stopped safely within the ASDA. A wet (minimum) V1 is the maximum speed for abandoning a take-off on a contaminated runway. A wet V1 improves the stopping capabilities (final stop point) back to the dry conditions level but degrades the takeoff chances with a reduced screen height in the event of a take-off being continued. A recommended wet V1 for contaminated conditions is the dry V1 - 10 knots. Thus wet V1 is a lower speed than dry V1. Note: Due to lower friction and consequently reduced braking action on a wet runway, longer braking distances are experienced, V1 must be decreased.

content.question: What is correct for a take-off from a contaminated runway with slush?

options.A: The take-off distance increases and the accelerate-stop distance decreases.
options.B: The take-off distance decreases and the accelerate-stop distance increases.
options.C: Both the take-off distance and the accelerate-stop distance increase.
options.D: Both the take-off distance and the accelerate-stop decrease.

key_points: Even on a smooth runway there will be rolling resistance due to the bearing friction
If the runway is contaminated by snow, slush or standing water, there will be additional drag due to fluid resistance
This drag will increase with speed, until a critical speed is reached, the hydroplaning speed, above which the drag will start to decrease
learning.explanation: Even on a smooth runway there will be rolling resistance due to the bearing friction. If the runway is contaminated by snow, slush or standing water, there will be additional drag due to fluid resistance. This drag will increase with speed, until a critical speed is reached, the hydroplaning speed, above which the drag will start to decrease. Any contamination will increase the drag and hence increase the take-off distance. If the take-off is rejected and braking is required, the coefficient of braking friction is severely reduced on a runway which is wet, icy or contaminated by snow or slush. This means that the brake pressure must be severely reduced to prevent skidding. Thus, the stopping distance is greatly increased.

content.question: When is a runway considered to be contaminated? When:

options.A: Less than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) is covered with water more than 3 mm deep.
options.B: More than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) is covered with slush equivalent to 2 mm of water.
options.C: More than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) is covered with wet ice 1.5 mm thick.
options.D: Only if the contaminant covers a connected 25% of the runway surface area (patches of contaminants can add up to more than 25% of the surface area without effects).

key_points: EASA AIR OPS Annex I to VIII "Contaminated runway"

A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0,125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0,125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice
You can simply ignore the "1
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS Annex I to VIII "Contaminated runway". A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0,125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0,125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice. You can simply ignore the "1.5 mm" because any wet ice makes the runway contaminated.

content.question: Which of the following statements with regard to the optimum cruise altitude (best fuel mileage) is correct?

options.A: An aeroplane usually flies above the optimum cruise altitude, as this provides the largest specific range.
options.B: An aeroplane always flies on the optimum cruise altitude, because this is most attractive from an economy point of view.
options.C: An aeroplane always flies below the optimum cruise altitude, as otherwise Mach buffet can occur.
options.D: An aeroplane sometimes flies above the optimum cruise altitude, because ATC normally does not allow to fly continuously at the optimum cruise altitude.

key_points: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed
As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range
The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed. As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range. The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change. Optimum altitude increases with reducing aircraft weight: the drag curve will move down and to the left as the weight decreases through fuel burn. The aeroplane maximizes its specific range by remaining at the optimum altitude as it slowly increases (it must climb along the green line shown in the attached figure). As the optimum altitude increases, the specific range increases. However, for a number of reasons, ATC will probably not allow a cruise climb. The compromise between a level cruise and a cruise climb is a step climb. STEP CLIMB means that the airplane climbs to about 2000 ft above the optimum altitude and levels off. As fuel is used and weight falls, the optimum altitude will increase to a point where it is again 2000 ft above the airplane’s current level. And thereafter the climb process can be repeated. This is the most common way of operating jets in real life. The pilot should always aim to use the step climb technique to remain as close as possible to the optimum altitude. However, it can be beneficial to fly at an altitude other than the optimum altitude in case of, for example, significant tailwind at a different level - even if it means flying significantly below the Optimum Altitude. Or when experiencing severe turbulence at the Optimum Altitude.

On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15 ft

On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15 ft. Operating engines are at take-off thrust, the flaps/slats are in take-off configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb. The first segment ends when the landing gear is fully retracted. Begins when the landing gear is fully retracted. Engines are at take-off thrust and the flaps/slats are in the take-off configuration. metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Consider a large jet transport aeroplane under Performance Class A. For any given take-off, the Performance-Limited Take-Off Mass (PLTOM) is limited by brake-energy or tyre-speed limits...

options.A: to ensure that V2 is greater than VMBE.
options.B: to ensure that V1 is less than or equal to VMBE.
options.C: when VR is less than VMAX TYRE.
options.D: when VLOF is less than VMAX TYRE.

key_points: There are many limitations for an aircraft on take-off
Not only items such as obstacle clearance or field length limitations, but also more obscure limitations such as VMCG, VMBE and maximum tyre speed limits
You must know the reason behind these limitations
learning.explanation: There are many limitations for an aircraft on take-off. Not only items such as obstacle clearance or field length limitations, but also more obscure limitations such as VMCG, VMBE and maximum tyre speed limits. You must know the reason behind these limitations. This question is about VMBE and maximum tyre speeds. VMBE is the maximum brake energy speed. It is the speed which an aircraft can safely stop from, without overloading the brakes with energy. The brakes take the vast majority of an aircraft's kinetic energy in as heat, so will have a limit on the temperature they can withstand, which equates to a maximum energy they can stop, before overheating and causing effects like brake fade, brake fires and tyre blowouts. VMBE obviously varies a lot on weight, and the heavier an aircraft is, the more kinetic energy it has at the same speed, so the lower the VMBE. VMAX TYRE is the maximum tyre speed. A tyre is only built to spin so fast. When a tyre spins faster than its rated speed, the intense forces can cause it to break apart, and can cause tyre blowouts. Of course, this would be very bad during take-off or landing, so the aircraft cannot go faster than the tyre limiting speed, VMAX TYRE. For this question, we have to evaluate each option, to see if that scenario would limit the Performance-Limited Take-Off Mass (which is the lowest of the performance limited masses, then compared with the structural MTOM to find the RTOM). There are two styles of options, one which mentions a case where the PLTOM might be max tyre speed limited, and the other type which effectively asks why a case might limit the PLTOM. "to ensure that V2 is greater than VMBE." V2 is the take-off climb safety speed, and will only be reached after rotation and lift-off, so we would not have to stop from that speed, so it is incorrect. "to ensure that V1 is less than or equal to VMBE." V1 is the decision speed, so is the highest speed at which the decision to stop can be taken. We must make sure that this is below the VMBE, or the brakes might not be able to handle a maximum speed rejected take-off. Therefore, this is correct.* "when VR is less than VMAX TYRE." The answers have changed in style here. Yes, we must make sure that the aircraft speed does not exceed VMAX TYRE on the ground, but VR is only the speed we begin rotation at, and the not the maximum speed the tyres will go. Also, if VR is less than VMAX TYRE, there is no problem there, so this would not cause the PLTOM to be limited. "when VLOF is less than VMAX TYRE." VLOF is the expected speed where the aircraft main gear will lift-off from the runway, so is the fastest speed expected that the tyres would have to endure. It is faster than VR. Again, as above, we would not have a problem if the VLOF is less than the VMAX TYRE, as this means the tyres will not reach their maximum speed, and should be safe, so there is no need to reduce the PLTOM for this. * Note that this is not quite exact. The stopping segment of a rejected take-off is assumed to begin when the first action is made to close the thrust levers. Now, this is at any speed between V1 and V1 + 2 seconds, and in those 2 seconds, some acceleration may take place. We still measure V1 against VMBE, so the answer is absolutely correct, but the aircraft might end up stopping from just above that speed in reality.

content.question: Which of the following options is true as regards to 'reduced thrust ' and 'de-rated' take-off thrust?

options.A: The 'de-rated ' take-off thrust must be at least 75% of the (normal take-off) thrust.
options.B: In a 'reduced thrust' take-off, the pilot can select the (normal configuration) any time, if needed.
options.C: Operations from contaminated runways are not permissible using 'de-rated' take-off thrust.
options.D: For a 'reduced thrust' take-off there are certain 'limitation' that can be inreased.

key_points: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude
This reduces engine wear
A take-off thrust which is less than the maximum take-off (or derated take-off) thrust is used
learning.explanation: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude. This reduces engine wear. A take-off thrust which is less than the maximum take-off (or derated take-off) thrust is used. In this method, the thrust for take-off is not considered as a take-off operating limit. Which means that maximum take-off thrust may be applied at any stage of the take-off. "Operations from contaminated runways are not permissible using 'de-rated' take-off thrust." INCORRECT From the Boeing 777 FCTM: Reduced takeoff thrust (ATM) may be used for takeoff on a wet runway if approved takeoff performance data for a wet runway is used. However, reduced takeoff thrust (ATM) is not permitted for takeoff on a runway contaminated with standing water, slush, snow, or ice. Derated takeoff thrust (fixed derate) may be used for take-off on a wet runway and on a runway contaminated with standing water, slush, snow, or ice. "For a 'reduced thrust' take-off there are certain 'limitations' that can be increased." INCORRECT Limitations should not be ignored and no exemptions shall be made in order to decrease engine wear. "The 'de-rated ' take-off thrust must be at least 75% of the (normal take-off) thrust." INCORRECT The reduced take-off thrust setting is at least 75 percent of the take-off thrust.

content.question: What is correct about a balanced field take-off? It is:

options.A: Where the OEI TODR = the AEO ASDR.
options.B: Where the OEI TODR = the OEI ASDR.

key_points: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length
Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length

BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the OEI Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the OEI Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition
learning.explanation: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length. Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length. BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the OEI Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the OEI Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition. The balanced field length is the shortest field length at which a balanced field take-off can be performed. A Balanced field length is used to simplify the field-length take-off mass. When applying this concept, TOD = ASD and V1 = V1 Balanced. And this means that we are using the minimum requirements in case of engine failure, thus increasing safety margins. When using stopway or clearway, extra distance will be available and V1 will vary.

content.question: When considering a take-off which is rejected at high speed, what effect will inoperative ground spoilers have on the accelerate-stop distance. It will be...

options.C: increased or decreased, depending on the runway condition.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.01.03.06: Explain how the accelerate-stop distance is affected by the use of brakes, anti-skid, reverse thrust, ground spoilers (lift dumpers) and by brake energy absorption limits, delayed temperature rise and brake temperature indication. During the landing ground roll or during a rejected take-off, all spoiler panels are extended to their maximum angle. Some of these panels may be flight spoilers used for roll and drag in flight, and some may be ground spoilers, which are simply deployed on the ground to increase aircraft braking. The primary purpose of the ground spoilers is to maximise wheel brake efficiency by "spoiling" or dumping the lift generated by the wing and thus forcing the full weight of the aircraft onto the landing gear. Therefore, if the ground spoilers are inoperative, the aircraft will accelerate as normal, but will have less effective braking capability, so will have a longer stopping distance. The accelerate-stop distance will therefore increase.

content.question: From the following statements, what is correct about using step climbs?

options.A: Performing a step climb based on economy can be limited by the 1.3 g buffet onset.
options.B: Step climbs decrease fuel efficiency but increase performance.
options.C: Step climbs provide better fuel efficiency than cruise climbs.
options.D: Step climbs increase efficiency for turboprops but NOT for turbofan aeroplanes.

key_points: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed
As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range
The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed. As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range. The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change. Optimum altitude increases with reducing aircraft weight: the drag curve will move down and to the left as the weight decreases through fuel burn. The aeroplane maximizes its specific range by remaining at the optimum altitude as it slowly increases (it must climb along the green line shown in the attached figure). As the optimum altitude increases, the specific range increases. However, for a number of reasons, ATC will probably not allow a cruise climb. The compromise between a level cruise and a cruise climb is a step climb. STEP CLIMB means that the airplane climbs to about 2000 ft above the optimum altitude and levels off. As fuel is used and weight falls, the optimum altitude will increase to a point where it is again 2000 ft above the airplane’s current level. And thereafter the climb process can be repeated. This is the most common way of operating jets in real life. The pilot should always aim to use the step climb technique to remain as close as possible to the optimum altitude. Although a climb above the 1.3 g cruise buffet boundary altitude may be possible, it is prudent to maintain the safety that this limiting altitude gives. At times, a further climb may narrow the gap between high speed buffet and low speed buffet, this should be avoided. When performing a step climb, buffet limits should be considered. 1.3g buffet onset may limit step climb.

content.question: Compared with fully manual braking, the use of anti-skid (1) _____ landing distance, as the aircraft will decelerate at a (2) _____ rate.

key_points: This question is a little sneaky
It wants you to know the difference between anti-skid and autobrake

Anti-skid is the system that stops our wheels "locking up" - primarily in wet or slippery runway conditions, as that would only damage our tyres, remove our controllability and provide a reduced braking performance
learning.explanation: This question is a little sneaky. It wants you to know the difference between anti-skid and autobrake. Anti-skid is the system that stops our wheels "locking up" - primarily in wet or slippery runway conditions, as that would only damage our tyres, remove our controllability and provide a reduced braking performance. Instead, we want our tyres to be going just slightly slower than our groundspeed, to provide the greatest braking efficiency, especially in low traction conditions, and this is what anti-skid does. Anti-skid is used all the time (except when inoperative, of course) in commercial aviation, due to its many benefits and very few (if any) issues. It can be used when manual braking and when the aircraft is using autobrake. Autobrake is a more modern system, that takes over the pilot's job of pressing the brake pedals. It is set by a dial or series of buttons in the cockpit and attempts to provide a constant, pre-selected rate of deceleration throughout braking. There are multiple levels of braking available, for progressively shorter runways, requiring a progressively higher rate of deceleration. Anti-skid must be operative for autobrake to work. The autobrake cannot control the aircraft laterally, so it would be really bad if the wheels locked up (on a wet runway without anti-skid), and therefore it cannot be used at all if anti-skid is not available. This question is asking about anti-skid (even though it is phrased as if it was about autobrake - sneaky EASA), and therefore, the answer is that anti-skid reduces the landing distance due to the availability to apply maximum deceleration, as opposed to the pilots stamping on the brakes (without anti-skid protection) as hard as possible, which could cause the wheels to lock. You could argue that the pilot may be able to brake just as well as the anti-skid system can, but this is not a racing car, and we are mostly not racing drivers, so the vast majority of the time, this is certainly not the case.

The only solution is to descend to a lower flight altitude, where the remaining engine can provide enough thrust to balance the drag and allow level flight

learning.explanation: Engine Failure and Drift Down In the case of an engine failure, the remaining thrust is not sufficient to balance the drag force and the cruise speed cannot be maintained. The only solution is to descend to a lower flight altitude, where the remaining engine can provide enough thrust to balance the drag and allow level flight. As the airplane descends into the lower atmosphere where density is greater, the remaining engine can develop more thrust which will equal the drag force, this is the GROSS level-off altitude, but would give no performance margin. So the DRIFT DOWN PROCEDURE is continued to a lower altitude, the NET level-off altitude. The main purpose of the drift down procedure is to bring the aircraft to an altitude where the aircraft can generate enough trust with the remaining to balance the drag. The level-off altitude is determined by the actual air density. However, the conditions in which the aircraft is currently in must be evaluated. Situations such as terrain condition, air traffic situation and ATC coordination are effective in determining the nature of this descent. Depending on the obstacle conditions, the descend process may be delayed or gradually planned. Or, if there is no constraint, optimum descent can be made smoothly.

If the antiskid is inoperative, braking effectiveness is reduced considerably
learning.explanation: ANTISKID INOPERATIVE The problem to consider is a system failure that is permissible, but reduces the aeroplane’s ability to stop. This would typically include antiskid or reverse thrust inoperative. If the antiskid is inoperative, braking effectiveness is reduced considerably. This has performance implications for both the rejected take-off and landing. Reduced thrust take-offs or operations from contaminated runways are not permitted when antiskid is inoperative. However, an aeroplane’s Minimum Equipment List (MEL) allows an aeroplane to be dispatched with antiskid inoperative in normal situations, but it is restricted to a much lighter take-off and landing mass for a given distance available. If the stopping ability of the aeroplane if reduced, the fastest speed from which it can stop, VSTOP, is slower. However, to be able to continue the take-off with the critical engine failing at this slower speed results in the necessity to reduce the take-off mass. As the stopping ability of aeroplane reduces, it needs to increase for the accelerated stop distance available. For using the whole runway lenght properly V1 decreases for safety reason.

learning.explanation: TIRE SPEED LIMITED TAKE-OFF When dispatching an airplane in compliance with the certified Airplane Flight Manual, the airplane take-off speeds are designed to ensure that the lift-off speed does not exceed the tire speed rating. content.question: During a descent at a constant Mach number, which of these limiting speeds is the first to be reached without any pilot intervention?

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.05.01.05: Describe the following limiting speeds for descent: maximum operating speed (VMO); maximum Mach number (MMO). Aircraft certified under CS-25 (and some aircraft under CS-23) are given maximum flight speeds as a VMO and MMO (maximum operating airspeed/Mach No.). Depending on the altitude and air temperature, one of these will correspond to a lower airspeed than the other. That one will be the most limiting. The MMO is most limiting at high altitudes, which is when it is most useful for us to refer to our speed in Mach No., whereas at lower altitudes, the VMO is most limiting, and we should use IAS/CAS instead. The point where this crossover happens is called the crossover altitude. A common altitude for this is around 28000 ft, but it depends on the aircraft and conditions. If descending at a constant mach number, the Mach number will not exceed the MMO (as it is constant), but using the ECTM graph above, we can see that the IAS will be increasing, and therefore the IAS may well reach and exceed VMO if the crossover is delayed to a lower altitude. The other two options "shock stall speed" and "never exceed speed" can be discounted here, as aircraft with VMO/MMO do not have a VNE and the shock stall speed occurs based on the Mach No. and MMO, both of which we know remain constant (and it is not a limiting speed as such).

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The crew of a large jet transport aircraft is planning their departure from Gran Canaria on either runway 21L or 21R, shown in the figure above. After running their performance software, their Maximum Allowed Take-Off Masses are summarised as below.
RWY 21L: 91.4 Tonnes
RWY 21R: 90.9 Tonnes
Assuming that the runways have the same slope, what might be the reason for the two different Maximum Allowed Take-Off Masses?

options.A: The runways are field-length-limited as each runway will have its own individual Field-Length-Limiting Take-Off Mass.
options.B: Runway 21L has more limiting close-in obstacles than runway 21R and requires a greater climb gradient in the second segment.
options.C: More limiting obstacles are within the obstacle domain for runway 21R compared to runway 21L, requiring a greater climb gradient.
options.D: The runways are climb-limited with the obstacle domains being the same since the runways are close together with parallel thresholds.

key_points: This question is asking us to know the relationship between weight limitation and take-off/climb limitations
Of course, weight reduces our take-off performance in every way
Not only does it increase our required take-off distance, but it also reduces our climb gradient
learning.explanation: This question is asking us to know the relationship between weight limitation and take-off/climb limitations. Of course, weight reduces our take-off performance in every way. Not only does it increase our required take-off distance, but it also reduces our climb gradient. We often want to take-off with as much weight as possible, as this either means adding more passengers or cargo, or adding more fuel, both of which are good. Our Maximum Allowed Take-Off Mass (MATOM) is the most limiting of our climb limited take-off mass (CLTOM), obstacle limited take-off mass (OLTOM), field length limiting take-off mass (FLLTOM) and maximum structural take-off mass (MSTOM). Depending on the airport, conditions, and surrounding obstacles, these are all calculated by the performance software. Higher weight means lower performance, meaning that, in this question, the lower MATOM is on runway 21R, meaning that something about that departure is more restrictive, hence we cannot take-off with as much weight as we could on runway 21L. Now this could be the runway length, but the chart shows the runways having equal lengths, and the question specifies that we should assume they have the same slope. Of the explanations, there is only one which satisfies that category of 21R being more restrictive. We can quickly go through each explanation: "The runways are field-length-limited as each runway will have its own individual Field-Length-Limiting Take-Off Mass." The question says that the slope can be assumed to be the same, and we can see from the chart that the runways are practically the same length (only 1 metre different), so these runways would have the same FLLTOM, meaning this cannot be correct. "Runway 21L has more limiting close-in obstacles than runway 21R and requires a greater climb gradient in the second segment." Runway 21L has a less limiting departure, as the MATOM is higher, and also, we have no idea about exactly where any limiting obstacles exist, second segment, fourth segment, etc., we do not have that information. "More limiting obstacles are within the obstacle domain for runway 21R compared to runway 21L, requiring a greater climb gradient." Yes, this would explain the weights. Runway 21R could have more restrictive obstacles, requiring higher climb performance, therefore a lower maximum weight. "The runways are climb-limited with the obstacle domains being the same since the runways are close together with parallel thresholds." If the obstacle domains were the same, then the climb-limited take-off masses would be the same for both runways. Obviously this is not the case, as the maximum allowed take-off masses are different. For instance, they may have different departure routes or offset thresholds from each other.

options.C: the pressure altitude up to which a cabin altitude of 8000 ft can be maintained.
options.D: the pressure altitude at which the fuel flow is a maximum.

key_points: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed
As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range
The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed. As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range. The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change. Optimum altitude increases with reducing aircraft weight: the drag curve will move down and to the left as the weight decreases through fuel burn. Which means that the best range speed (1.32 VMD) decreases (along with the total drag) and, as a consequences, the aircraft needs to slow down to maintain the best range speed. The Mach number will decrease and the aircraft will be able to climb a little since it is not limited by the high Mach number and high drag. The aeroplane maximizes its specific range by remaining at the optimum altitude as it slowly increases (it must climb along the green line shown in the attached figure). As the optimum altitude increases, the specific range increases.

options.B: At the runway limited take-off mass for a balanced field there is a single speed for V1.

key_points: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length
Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length

BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition
learning.explanation: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length. Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length. BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition. The balanced field length is the shortest field length at which a balanced field take-off can be performed. A Balanced field length is used to simplify the field-length take-off mass. When applying this concept, TOD = ASD and V1 = V1 Balanced. And this means that we are using the minimum requirements in case of engine failure, thus increasing safety margins. When using stopway or clearway, extra distance will be available and V1 will vary. BALANCED V1 The first graph on the attached figure, helps understanding the impact of increasing or decreasing V1. Analyzing it, we can conclude the following: A Balanced V1 is a V1 speed which results in TODR equal to ASDR. Often called the “Ideal V1” as it gives the minimum field length required for a given weight and optimum performance. Any lower V1 (V1 < V1B) would increase TODR, as it would take longer for the aircraft to accelerate to V2 with OEI. As a result, the total field required increases. Any higher V1 (V1 > V1B) would increase ASDR due to a higher energy absorption by the brakes. As a result, the total field required would also increase. => In essence, Balanced V1 improves field length limited take-off performance. => Unbalanced V1 allows for higher take-off weights by taking advantage of any runway and clearway or stopway available in excess of balanced field length. Summary and extra info: If TOD = ASD, V1 = BALANCED, Balanced condition. If TOD > ASD, V1 < V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Clearway, no stopway = higher mass and lower V1 speed If TOD < ASD, V1 > V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Stopway, no clearway = higher mass and higher V1 speed. TORA (Take-Off Run Distance Available) => RUNWAY only (no STOPWAY or CLEARWAY) TODA (Take-Off Distance Available) => TORA + CLEARWAY ASDA (Accelarate-Stop Distance Available) => TORA + STOPWAY

content.question: Some of the certification requirements for large aeroplanes described in CS-25 are the performance data defined as gradients of the flight path and the net flight path. What is the difference between those two factors?

options.A: The flight path gradient is the actual path flown by the aeroplane, which is increased by safety factors to introduce a safety margin for the net flight path.
options.B: The flight path gradient includes safety factors and is based on the net flight path gradient, which is determined by flight testing.
options.C: The net flight path gradient is first established based on obstacle clearance, and this is reduced by a safety margin to establish the flight path gradient.
options.D: The net flight path gradient is the flight path gradient reduced by prescribed safety margins, which depend on the number of engines.

key_points: The question with the term "flight path" means the "the gross flight path"
The gross flight path is the average flight path flown by an aeroplane

Because there is only a 50:50 likelihood for an aircraft to meet the gross performance standards, when the obstacle clearance after take-off is considered, it is worked out against an hypothetical flight path, which is worse than the gross or average, with factors included for reduced climb gradients, which is called as the net take-off flight path (NTOFP)
learning.explanation: The question with the term "flight path" means the "the gross flight path". The gross flight path is the average flight path flown by an aeroplane. Because there is only a 50:50 likelihood for an aircraft to meet the gross performance standards, when the obstacle clearance after take-off is considered, it is worked out against an hypothetical flight path, which is worse than the gross or average, with factors included for reduced climb gradients, which is called as the net take-off flight path (NTOFP). Thus, for a Class A aircraft according to CS-25, assuming an engine failure at VEF during take-off, the expected or actual flight path will be the gross flight path and the net take-off flight path reduced by a safety margin depending on the number of engines. To convert the gross gradients into their equivalent net gradients a reduction or decrement has to be applied: 0.8% for 2-engined aeroplanes 0.9% for 3-engined aeroplanes 1% for 4-engined aeroplanes

content.question: Why are step climbs used?

options.A: To fly at the optimum altitude to improve range.
options.B: To fly at the optimum altitude to improve endurance.
options.C: To fly as close to the tropopause as possible.
options.D: To fly higher altitudes with stronger wind to improve range.

key_points: OPTIMUM ALTITUDE is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed
As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range
The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change
learning.explanation: OPTIMUM ALTITUDE is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed. As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range. The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change. STEP CLIMB means that the airplane climbs to about 2000 ft above the optimum altitude and levels off. As fuel is used and weight falls, the optimum altitude will increase to a point where it is again 2000 ft above the airplane’s current level. And thereafter the climb process can be repeated. This is the most common way of operating jets in real life. The step climb process can be repeated throughout the cruise and it helps to explain why the cruise altitudes at the end of the flight are higher than at the start. Remaining within 2000 ft of the optimum altitude ensures the range is 99% of the maximum specific range.

The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs
Secondary advantages include fuel savings and that, under certain circumstances, it may be possible to increase the maximum take-off weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust profile
learning.explanation: Advantages of using reduced take-off thrust Using reduced thrust lowers the jet engine's internal operating pressure and temperature. The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs. Secondary advantages include fuel savings and that, under certain circumstances, it may be possible to increase the maximum take-off weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust profile. Therefore, the main benefits are: Reduced stress and wear on the engine; Reduced cost on parts and mainenance; Increased engine life; Increased reliability, thus improving operating safety and efficency. As a result of the lower flight path, reduced take-off thrust may increase the airplane-to-ground noise level. Reduced thrust take-off must not be used in the following cases: Icy or very slippery runways Contaminated runways Anti-skid inop Reverse thrust inop Increased V2 procedure (improved climb) Engine Power Management Computer inop Not recommended in Windshear conditions

A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0,125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0,125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice
"Damp runway"
learning.explanation: EASA AIR OPS Annex I to VIII "Contaminated runway". A runway is considered to be contaminated when more than 25% of the runway surface area (whether in isolated areas or not) within the required length and width being used is covered by the following: (a) surface water more than 3 mm (0,125 in) deep, or by slush, or loose snow, equivalent to more than 3 mm (0,125 in) of water; (b) snow which has been compressed into a solid mass which resists further compression and will hold together or break into lumps if picked up (compacted snow); or (c) ice, including wet ice. "Damp runway". A runway is considered damp when the surface is not dry, but when the moisture on it does not give it a shiny appearance. "Dry runway". A dry runway is one which is neither wet nor contaminated, and includes those paved runways which have been specially prepared with grooves or porous pavement and maintained to retain "effectively dry" braking action even when moisture is present. "Wet runway." A runway is considered wet when the runway surface is covered with water, or equivalent, less than specified in subparagraph (a)(2) above or when there is sufficient moisture on the runway surface to cause it to appear reflective, but without significant areas of standing water.

content.question: After a new software update, the engineer has changed the crossover data from 250 kt / M0.75 to 250 kt / M0.78. The pilot now must make sure he/she does not exceed:

key_points: The Crossover Altitude is the altitude where a specific Indicated Airspeed (IAS) becomes a specific Mach number (M)
It is the altitude where a specified IAS and Mach number represent the same TAS
Below the Crossover Altitude, the climb/descent is performed maintaining a constant IAS
learning.explanation: The Crossover Altitude is the altitude where a specific Indicated Airspeed (IAS) becomes a specific Mach number (M). It is the altitude where a specified IAS and Mach number represent the same TAS. Below the Crossover Altitude, the climb/descent is performed maintaining a constant IAS. Whereas above the Crossover Altitude, the climb/descent is performed maintaining a constant Mach number. At the Crossover Altitude, there is one value of TAS which corresponds to the given Mach number and the given IAS at the same time. In this case, the crossover altitude of this aircraft has been incorrectly raised higher up. This is because the altitude where 250KIAS = M0.78 is higher than the altitude where 250 KIAS = 0.75. (Draw an ECTM graph or use the finger trick to prove this to yourself if necessary.) As this is a tricky question requiring a lot of thought, let us go through both the climb scenario and the descent scenario. In the climb scenario, before/below the CA (crossover altitude), we are flying at a constant IAS, with our Mach No. increasing as we climb. As the CA is now higher than it should be, it means we spend more time increasing our Mach No., and that means it may go over our MMO. We cannot breach our VMO here as we are flying at a constant IAS before the CA, and then a reducing IAS after the CA. In the descent scenario, we are initially descending with constant Mach No., but increasing IAS. As the CA is higher up than usual, we reach it earlier, and our IAS is not able to increase up to its usual value, so our descent below the CA may be at a lower speed, however, there is no chance of overspeed in the descent scenario, either by breaching the VMO or the MMO. We start with a constant Mach No., decreasing after the CA, and our IAS initially increases, but to a lower value than usual, then remains constant. So to conclude, the only opportunity for any type of overspeed here is by breaching MMO, and that would be possible when in the climb.

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct for a turbojet aeroplane climbing at a constant Mach number above the tropopause, assuming standard conditions?

options.B: IAS decreases and TAS remains constant
options.D: IAS remains constant and TAS decreases

key_points: In the standard atmosphere, the temperature reduces by 1
98o C per 1000 ft up to the tropopause at 36090 ft
Above the tropopause in the lower stratosphere, the temperature remains constant
learning.explanation: In the standard atmosphere, the temperature reduces by 1.98o C per 1000 ft up to the tropopause at 36090 ft. Above the tropopause in the lower stratosphere, the temperature remains constant. Having chosen a climbing speed, the pilot will maintain a constant IAS through the lower levels. But during the climb, both TAS and Mach No will be increasing. On most airliners, at around 27000 ft the Mach number will reach a point where, any further increase will start causing the problems associated with the high speed flight. At this point and thereafter, the pilot will switch to climbing at a constant Mach number, instead of IAS. If the constant IAS is maintained beyond this point, there is a risk of exceeding the aircraft's maximum Mach number, Mmo. From the Mach number formula: Mach No = TAS / LSS = TAS / 38.94√(temp in K), we get that the Local Speed of Sound decreases as the temperature decreases. But since above the tropopause the temperature remains constant, the TAS stops decreasing and remains constant too. But the continuous reduction of the air density means that, IAS continues to decrease, provided that a constant Mach number is maintained.

options.B: Increase landing distance by maintaining maximum autobrakes.

learning.explanation: Note: We believe that the question and available options are badly worded, and are open to interpretation. From recent feedback we think that this is the most representative of the real exam question, but we can only verify that with further feedback. We have assumed that the question means "MAXIMUM manual braking", but we can't be 100% sure that it say exactly that in the real exam. Please let us know if you see this question in the exam via the comments, or email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Autobrake is a system where the pilots do not press the aircraft brakes at all, the aircraft instead modulates its own brake pressure to maintain a selected rate of deceleration. There are multiple levels of braking available, for progressively shorter runways, requiring a progressively higher rate of deceleration. Anti-skid must be operative for autobrake to work. The autobrake cannot control the aircraft laterally, so it would be really bad if the wheels locked up (on a wet runway without anti-skid), and therefore it cannot be used at all if anti-skid is not available. EASA tend to refer to a "generic" autobrake system, and this always resembles the Boeing 737 autobrake system, where the autobrake modes are OFF, 1, 2, 3, MAX and RTO. Technically, the maximum rate of deceleration comes from maximum manual braking, or from autobrakes in the RTO mode, and the RTO mode is better in the event of a rejected take-off as it applies the brakes faster and more efficiently than the pilot could usually apply maximum manual braking. Autobrakes 1, 2 and 3 are simple, they produce set rates of deceleration, as does autobrake MAX. Contrary to its name though, autobrake MAX applies a high level of braking, but not quite the maximum brake pressure like max manual or RTO mode. However, autobrake MAX does apply the brakes quickly and efficiently after main gear touchdown, so provides initially a better deceleration than maximum manual braking, however overall, it would then be better to override with max manual to provide the small amount of extra brake pressure, if minimum stopping distance is what you want. Therefore, any landing autobrake setting (even MAX) gives a longer landing distance than using maximum manual braking. We have checked this using Boeing 737 performance figures and they agree with this statement, so we hope that this is what EASA means in this question.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
A flight crew of a performance class A aeroplane are preparing for departure. Only the Captain has run the performance figures using an application on their electronic flight bag (EFB), and has not crosschecked the results with the first officer, who is busy preparing the departure routing. That aircraft's take-off mass is 68 000 kg, so is under the MTOM with reduced thrust setting of 68 262 kg that the Captain has calculated. The V-speeds for departure can be seen on the annex above, which is a small extract from the EFB performance tool. The VMCG is 118 kt.
When inputting the V-speeds into the FMS, the Captain enters 140 kt for V1. During take-off, the pilot monitoring calls V1 at the FMS selected V1 speed, at which point an engine failure occurs. The engine failure is detected and acted upon at an airspeed of 143 kt.
What would be the most likely scenario in this event?

options.A: The pilot flying will continue the take-off as they are above V1 and the take-off distance required will be shorter than the one calculated by the EFB, but the pilots will be unable maintain the aeroplane within 30 ft of the runway centreline.
options.B: The Captain will reject the take-off because that is the recommended option when an engine fails during the take-off roll, but the accelerate-stop distance will be longer than the one calculated by the EFB.
options.C: The pilot flying will continue the take-off and the take-off distance required will be larger than the one calculated by the EFB, since the engine failure occurred at a speed below the correct V1.
options.D: The Captain will reject the take-off because the failure happens less than 2 seconds after V1, but the accelerate-stop distance required will be larger than the one calculated by the EFB.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.01.02.08: Explain the effect of an error in V1 on the resulting one-engine-out take-off distance. V1 is the take-off decision speed. Before V1 is called, any significant failure of the aircraft (such as an engine failure or fire) will require the take-off to be rejected. Above the V1 speed, though, any failure must be taken into the air, and the rest of the departure can be flown with one engine inoperative, but also, stopping on the runway is no longer an option. In this case, the calculated V1 is 150 kt, but the crew are using an incorrectly selected V1 of 140 kt. This means that a failure which is recognised and acted upon at 143 kt is after the "V1" call, so the pilot flying will continue the take-off. However, this means that the aircraft will have to perform the rest of the take-off on one-engine only, at a lower speed than was calculated. This will reduce the aircraft's take-off performance, and will lead to a longer take-off distance required.

content.question: Which of the following are to be taken into account for the runway in use for take-off?

options.A: Airport elevation, runway slope, outside air temperature, pressure altitude and wind components.
options.B: Airport elevation, runway slope, outside air temperature, standard pressure and wind components.
options.C: Airport elevation, runway slope, standard temperature, pressure altitude and wind components.
options.D: Airport elevation, runway slope, standard temperature, standard pressure and wind components.

key_points: Factors affecting ASD Aircraft mass A heavier aircraft is more difficult to accelerate, and the wheel drag is also increased
As mass increases, ASDR increases
Temperature An increase in temperature reduces engine thrust
learning.explanation: Factors affecting ASD Aircraft mass A heavier aircraft is more difficult to accelerate, and the wheel drag is also increased. As mass increases, ASDR increases. Temperature An increase in temperature reduces engine thrust. An increase in temperature also means that IAS for a required V1 will be achieved at a higher TAS and therefore at a higher groundspeed. As temperature increases, ASDR increases. Engine Bleed Air Any bleed air reduces the engine thrust available. With bleeds on, ASDR increases. Runway slope If the runway slopes downhill the aircraft will be easier to accelerate, assisted by the component of the aircraft weight acting downhill, reducing the accelerating distance to V1. Even though the aircraft will be also easier to stop, the acceleration phase have the greatest effect on the ASDR. The opposite applies for an upslope runway and ASDR increases. Runway surface If the runway is contaminated by snow, slush or standing water, there will be additional drag due to fluid resistance. If the take-off is rejected and braking is required, the coefficient of braking friction is severely reduced on a runway which is wet, icy or contaminated by snow or slush. Any contamination will increase ASDR. Pressure altitude A higher-pressure altitude reduces engine thrust. A higher pressure altitude also means that IAS for a required V1 will be achieved at a higher TAS and therefore at a higher groundspeed. A higher-pressure altitude increases, ASDR increases. Wind Headwinds will reduce the ground speed at the required take-off airspeed. A tailwind does the opposite to a headwind. Tailwinds will increase the ground speed and therefore increases the ASDR. Because temperature and pressure vary with time and position, both horizontally and vertically, it is necessary, in aviation, to have a standard set of conditions to give a common datum. This standard temperature is just a reference, but the aircraft performance will depend on the actual temperature and pressure conditions as well the aircraft pressure instruments reading. A higher airfield elevation means that the aircraft will be affected by a higher pressure altitude.

The purpose of the improved climb procedure is to achieve an increased V2 in order to be closer to VX, this will in turn improve climb performance. The low speed buffet boundary marks the onset of the pre-stall buffet and the high speed buffet boundary marks the onset of the Mach related buffet, normally the MMO, but sometimes slightly below that. Any change of the operating limits, as far as the Mach No is concerned, are affected and may also increase or decrease the MMO, because of the following factors: Load factor (turbulence) Weight CG position Altitude If the operating limits of an aircraft change from 0.74 to 0.78 M, because of a decreased load factor (less turbulence) and/or a reduced All-Up-Mass and forward CG displacement due to the fuel consumption and/or cruising at a lower altitude, then the MMO increases. VMO is an IAS limit. When climbing at high altitudes, our maximum IAS will have to steadily decrease to ensure that MMO is not exceeded, which would bring the risk of Mach buffet.
