content.question: What is the assumed pilot reaction time for recognising an engine failure during take-off?

key_points: For the performance calculations fo the take-off, if an engine failure is recognised before V1 then the take-off must be rejected, and if recognised after V1, the take-off must be continued

The recognition of an engine failure is expected to take 2 seconds (at least this is the time allowed by the performance calculations), so VEF (the worst possible speed for an engine failure in terms of performance) occurs 2 seconds before V1
Please see the legal definitions of this below, in the case of stopping (engine failure recognised before V1)
learning.explanation: For the performance calculations fo the take-off, if an engine failure is recognised before V1 then the take-off must be rejected, and if recognised after V1, the take-off must be continued. The recognition of an engine failure is expected to take 2 seconds (at least this is the time allowed by the performance calculations), so VEF (the worst possible speed for an engine failure in terms of performance) occurs 2 seconds before V1. Please see the legal definitions of this below, in the case of stopping (engine failure recognised before V1). CS 25.109 Accelerate-stop distance (See AMC 25.109) (a) (See AMC 25.109(a) and (b)) The accelerate-stop distance on a dry runway is the greater of the following distances: (1) The sum of the distances necessary to – (i) Accelerate the aeroplane from a standing start with all engines operating to VEF for take-off from a dry runway; (ii) Allow the aeroplane to accelerate from VEF to the highest speed reached during the rejected takeoff, assuming the critical engine fails at VEF and the pilot takes the first action to reject the take-off at the V1 for take-off from a dry runway; and (iii) Come to a full stop on a dry runway from the speed reached as prescribed in sub-paragraph (a)(1)(ii) of this paragraph; plus (iv) A distance equivalent to 2 seconds at the V1 for take-off from a dry runway. (2) The sum of the distances necessary to – (i) Accelerate the aeroplane from a standing start with all engines operating to the highest speed reached during the rejected take-off, assuming the pilot takes the first action to reject the take-off at the V1 for take-off from a dry runway; and (ii) With all engines still operating, come to a full stop on a dry runway from the speed reached as prescribed in sub-paragraph (a)(2)(i) of this paragraph; plus (iii) A distance equivalent to 2 seconds at the V1 for take-off from a dry runway.

content.question: Is the use of TOGA still possible when the FMS has been set-up for a reduced thrust take-off?

options.B: TOGA cannot be selected anymore once the take-off power is set.
options.C: Yes, TOGA is always available when doing a reduced thrust and/or a derated take-off.

key_points: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude
The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs

learning.explanation: A reduced thrust take-off is a take-off that is accomplished utilising less thrust than the engines are capable of producing under the existing conditions of temperature and pressure altitude. The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs. Secondary advantages include fuel savings. However, even when the FMS has been set-up for a reduced thrust take-off, TOGA will still be available. Using Maximum Take-Off Thrust Set (TOGA) will result in an increased take-off performance. Therefore, in order to increase the safety margin in case of any system failure, emergency or adverse weather conditions the pilot can decide to proceed with the normal configuration with the Maximum Take-Off Thrust Set (TOGA).

content.question: During your approach, ATC asks you to perform a circle-to-land manoeuvre due to an unexpectedly strong tailwind. After the downwind leg, you make the last turn to the final approach with a strong headwind. In comparison to an approach in still air, you should (1) _____ thrust to stay on the correct glide path, as the headwind will cause the aircraft's glide angle to (2) _____.

key_points: An aircraft on approach should be flown at a constant approach angle ("glide path")
Usually this is at or around 3º

To maintain this descent angle, the pilot should fly at the correct rate of descent for their ground speed, as rate of descent(fpm) = ground speed(kt) x descent gradient(%) (this formula is a rule of thumb, but is very close to the exact mathematical formula)
learning.explanation: An aircraft on approach should be flown at a constant approach angle ("glide path"). Usually this is at or around 3º. To maintain this descent angle, the pilot should fly at the correct rate of descent for their ground speed, as rate of descent(fpm) = ground speed(kt) x descent gradient(%) (this formula is a rule of thumb, but is very close to the exact mathematical formula). Therefore, with a very strong headwind, as per this scenario, the aircraft will have a lower groundspeed than normal, so the aircraft will have a steeper descent angle than normal. Therefore the pilot must increase the thrust, to reduce the rate of descent, in order to maintain the correct glide path.

Beyond a certain altitude Mach number gets too high and MMO could be exceeded. To avoid this at the crossover or changeover altitude the climb profile is changed to a constant Mach number climb. The descent profile is almost the reverse of the climb profile. content.question: Field length is balanced when…

options.A: one engine acceleration from V1 to VLOF and flare distance between VLOF and 35 feet are equal.
options.B: calculated V2 is less than 110% VMCA and V1.
options.C: one engine inoperative take-off distance equals one engine inoperative accelerate stop distance.
options.D: all engine acceleration to V1 and braking distance for rejected take-off are equal.

key_points: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length
Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length

BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition
learning.explanation: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length. Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length. BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition. The balanced field length is the shortest field length at which a balanced field take-off can be performed. A Balanced field length is used to simplify the field-length take-off mass. When applying this concept, TOD = ASD and V1 = V1 Balanced. And this means that we are using the minimum requirements in case of engine failure, thus increasing safety margins. When using stopway or clearway, extra distance will be available and V1 will vary. BALANCED V1 The first graph on the attached figure, helps understanding the impact of increasing or decreasing V1. Analyzing it, we can conclude the following: A Balanced V1 is a V1 speed which results in TODR equal to ASDR. Often called the “Ideal V1” as it gives the minimum field length required for a given weight and optimum performance. Any lower V1 (V1 < V1B) would increase TODR, as it would take longer for the aircraft to accelerate to V2 with OEI. As a result, the total field required increases. Any higher V1 (V1 > V1B) would increase ASDR due to a higher energy absorption by the brakes. As a result, the total field required would also increase. => In essence, Balanced V1 improves field length limited take-off performance. => Unbalanced V1 allows for higher take-off weights by taking advantage of any runway and clearway or stopway available in excess of balanced field length. Summary and extra info: If TOD = ASD, V1 = BALANCED, Balanced condition. If TOD > ASD, V1 < V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Clearway, no stopway = higher mass and lower V1 speed If TOD < ASD, V1 > V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Stopway, no clearway = higher mass and higher V1 speed. TORA (Take-Off Run Distance Available) => RUNWAY only (no STOPWAY or CLEARWAY) TODA (Take-Off Distance Available) => TORA + CLEARWAY ASDA (Accelarate-Stop Distance Available) => TORA + STOPWAY

content.question: You are flying an airplane during descent with a constant Mach number. From the following speeds, which one would be the first to be exceeded if no action was taken?

As the local speed of sound increases, it allows the TAS to increase with the Mach number remaining the same
VNO (velocity normal operating) - Maximum structural cruise speed is the maximum normal operating cruise speed and must not exceed VC and 0
learning.explanation: Descending at a constant Mach number will allow CAS to increase as the density and temperature increase. As the local speed of sound increases, it allows the TAS to increase with the Mach number remaining the same. VNO (velocity normal operating) - Maximum structural cruise speed is the maximum normal operating cruise speed and must not exceed VC and 0.89 x VNE VNE - Never exceed speed is maximum VD to allow for speed upsets, operational 0.9 x VD. The primary advantage of the use of reduced take-off thrust is cost savings through increased engine life and reduced overhaul costs. Secondary advantages include fuel savings and that, under certain circumstances, it may be possible to increase the maximum take-off weight for a specific runway by using a reduced thrust profile. Therefore, the main benefits are: Reduced stress and wear on the engine; Reduced cost on parts and mainenance; Increased engine life; Increased reliability, thus improving operating safety and efficency. Instead, we want our tyres to be going just slightly slower than our groundspeed, to provide the greatest braking efficiency, especially in low traction conditions, and this is what anti-skid does

learning.explanation: Anti-skid is the system that stops our wheels "locking up" - primarily in wet or slippery runway conditions, as that would only damage our tyres, remove our controllability and provide a reduced braking performance. Instead, we want our tyres to be going just slightly slower than our groundspeed, to provide the greatest braking efficiency, especially in low traction conditions, and this is what anti-skid does. Anti-skid is used all the time (except when inoperative, of course) in commercial aviation, due to its many benefits. It can be used when manual braking and when the aircraft is using autobrake. If the antiskid is operative, this means an aircraft can apply the maximum braking available for those conditions without locking the wheels, hydroplaning, skidding, etc. This increases maximum braking capability in almost all cases, and therefore increases the maximum mass aircraft can land with, as their stopping performance is better, so they can land on the same runway with a higher weight and speed.

content.question: Before a departure with a Performance Class A twin-jet aeroplane, the pilots calculate the take-off performance. As the Actual Take-off Mass is less than the performance limiting masses for the existing conditions, it is decided to use reduced (FLEX) thrust. An air temperature of 45°C is used for the performance calculation, but the actual OAT is 20°C. Compared to the calculated take-off distance using 45°C, the actual take-off distance will be…

options.A: shorter. The engines will produce slightly greater thrust at 20°C, and the take-off speeds expressed in TAS will be lower at that OAT.
options.B: longer. The take-off thrust will be reduced because an assumed temperature 25°C higher than the OAT is used, while the take-off speeds expressed in IAS will be the same in both cases.
options.C: the same. The engines will produce the same thrust at 20°C and 45°C. and the take-off speeds expressed in IAS will be the same in both cases.
options.D: the same. The engines will be producing greater thrust at 20°C, but this will be counteracted by the higher take-off speeds expressed in TAS at that OAT.

key_points: This question is very complex to read and understand, so we will explain it better now

The crew have calculated the takeoff performance for the real OAT, decided that they have more performance than required, so then done another calculation using an air temperature of 45ºC, which is within limits, so they have selected an assumed temperature (FLEX temp
) on their engine control unit of 45ºC
learning.explanation: This question is very complex to read and understand, so we will explain it better now. The crew have calculated the takeoff performance for the real OAT, decided that they have more performance than required, so then done another calculation using an air temperature of 45ºC, which is within limits, so they have selected an assumed temperature (FLEX temp.) on their engine control unit of 45ºC. Of course, they are then going to depart with an actual OAT of 20ºC. The question then asks whether the actual takeoff distance will be shorter/longer/the same as the 45ºC performance calculation. Once the question has been understood, it is a lot more simple. Even with the assumed (FLEX) temperature set to 45ºC, the engines will produce very slightly more thrust when operating in a low temperature due to the colder, denser air. This is not usually mentioned, as it is only a small increase, but it will cause a small reduction in the actual takeoff distance, in comparison with the 45ºC performance calculation. The lower air temperature will also contribute to a lower density altitude, meaning that the takeoff speeds (which are fixed IAS values) will have lower true airspeed (TAS) values, so the aircraft does not actually have to accelerate as much to obtain the same takeoff speeds in the actual OAT. This causes a further reduction in the actual takeoff distance, in comparison with the 45ºC performance calculation. Therefore, the actual takeoff distance is shorter than the performance calculation.

content.question: For an aircraft climbing at a constant IAS and a constant mass the drag will:

key_points: The Airspeed Indicator (ASI) measures the dynamic pressure, producing an Indicated Airspeed (IAS) Output, determined by the value of that dynamic pressure
Meaning that, every time, the ASI sense a particular value of dynamic pressure, it indicates the same IAS
IAS or Dynamic Pressure = 1⁄2 ρV2 This means that if we climb at constant IAS, we must climb at a constant dynamic pressure
learning.explanation: The Airspeed Indicator (ASI) measures the dynamic pressure, producing an Indicated Airspeed (IAS) Output, determined by the value of that dynamic pressure. Meaning that, every time, the ASI sense a particular value of dynamic pressure, it indicates the same IAS. IAS or Dynamic Pressure = 1⁄2 ρV2 This means that if we climb at constant IAS, we must climb at a constant dynamic pressure. As we climb, density decreases. In order to maintain a constant IAS => TAS must increase. Lift = CL 1/2ρ Vsquared S Drag = CD 1/2ρ Vsquared S => Both CD and CL are determined by angle of attack. If we assume that the weight of our aircraft remains constant, then as we climb at constant IAS (which also means constant dynamic pressure) we must keep the angle of attack constant to maintain constant lift to match the constant weight. This in turn means that the CD will remain constant. So as we climb we have a situation in which CD and 1/2ρ Vsquared are both constant, so (unless our surface area (S) changes), we must have constant drag. So climbing at constant IAS produces constant drag.

content.question: What effect will lineup loss have on the V1 speed?

options.A: V1 reduces if departing from an unbalanced field.

key_points: Note: we only have partial feedback for this question, and therefore are requesting any further information about it if you see it in the exam, thank you

SHORT EXPLANATION Because the runway length decreases for all scenarios, rejected take off, engine failure on V1, normal take-off, the weight may need to reduce due to lineup loss, but the V1 will remain the same (always for a balanced runway, and only very slight changes possible with an unbalanced runway, increase vs decreases depends on the type of unbalance), but the "V1 is unchanged" answer is by far the most correct answer with these options
FULL EXPLANATION V1 is the take-off decision speed, the speed at which pilots have to either decide to stop, or take a potential problem into the air
learning.explanation: Note: we only have partial feedback for this question, and therefore are requesting any further information about it if you see it in the exam, thank you. SHORT EXPLANATION Because the runway length decreases for all scenarios, rejected take off, engine failure on V1, normal take-off, the weight may need to reduce due to lineup loss, but the V1 will remain the same (always for a balanced runway, and only very slight changes possible with an unbalanced runway, increase vs decreases depends on the type of unbalance), but the "V1 is unchanged" answer is by far the most correct answer with these options. FULL EXPLANATION V1 is the take-off decision speed, the speed at which pilots have to either decide to stop, or take a potential problem into the air. If the words V1 are said in the cockpit and no action has yet been made to slow the aircraft, the aircraft must take-off. It splits two different worst case scenarios, which are engine failures just before V1 and just after V1 (actually VEF is the real name for the assumed engine failure speed, but we do not need to go into that in this question). The "STOP" scenario is where a failure occurs just before V1, is recognised in time, and the aircraft begins stopping just after V1. This would produce the maximum possible accelerate-stop distance. The "GO" scenario is where an engine failure happens at V1 and the aircraft now has to accelerate the rest of the way until V2 and screen height with only 1 engine, so an early engine failure like this is the worst-case scenario, where the aircraft will have the worst possible performance. Increased weight is bad for all scenarios, it is bad for acceleration and climb out performance and for accelerate-stop performance, requiring an increased distance for both. For a balanced field (TODA = ASDA), there is a graph where the STOP and GO scenarios are compared to find the maximum weight at which there is 1 speed where the two change over, from "cannot go" to "cannot stop", and we call that the balanced V1. Even when we are lighter than this maximum weight (the FLLTOM), we usually use the balanced V1 anyway, to give best safety margins on either scenario. V1 can sometimes be increased or decreased by the addition of clearways or stopways, and it increases the maximum weight for the take-off too, by offsetting the V1 to favour either the "STOP" or the "GO" scenario, as the other scenario might require lower performance due to the extra distance available. For instance, with an extra length of stopway, we can accelerate for longer before needing to begin stopping, so our V1 can increase, and therefore our "GO" scenario becomes easier to do (higher speed engine failure), so we add extra weight to fill in the excess performance. Lineup loss is the loss of runway length remaining due to our aircraft using some of it to get onto and align with the runway centreline before take-off. It reduces all runway lengths, TORA, TODA and ASDA, as we are just starting slightly further down the runway. It therefore might reduce our take-off weight slightly, due to reduced performance, but our V1 will most likely stay the same. A balanced V1 would always stay the same after lineup loss, and unbalanced V1s could increase or decrease very slightly (by much less than 1 knot - so we do not really care in practice), depending on the type of unbalance, but on the whole, V1 will be unchanged.

key_points: Engine Failure and Drift Down In the case of an engine failure, the remaining thrust is not sufficient to balance the drag force and the cruise speed cannot be maintained
The only solution is to descend to a lower flight altitude, where the remaining engine can provide enough thrust to balance the drag and allow level flight

learning.explanation: Engine Failure and Drift Down In the case of an engine failure, the remaining thrust is not sufficient to balance the drag force and the cruise speed cannot be maintained. The only solution is to descend to a lower flight altitude, where the remaining engine can provide enough thrust to balance the drag and allow level flight. As the airplane descends into the lower atmosphere where density is greater, the remaining engine can develop more thrust which will equal the drag force, this is the GROSS level-off altitude, but would give no performance margin. So the DRIFT DOWN PROCEDURE is continued to a lower altitude, the NET level-off altitude. The main purpose of the drift down procedure is to bring the aircraft to an altitude where the aircraft can generate enough trust with the remaining to balance the drag. The level-off altitude is determined by the actual air density.

content.question:
The same manufacturer builds two airplanes with basically the same construction, with the main difference being that airplane (1) is single-engine and airplane (2) is multi-engine. Compare both airplanes in terms of performance, considering that airplane (1) is flying with its engine running and that airplane (2) is flying with a single engine.
The data for both aircraft is:
(1) single-engine airplane with 1 x 160 hp piston engine and a maximum mass of 1300 kg.
(2) Multi-engine airplane with 2 x 160 hp piston engines and a maximum mass of 1990 kg.

options.A: If the airplanes are flown at their maximum masses, the performance of airplane (2) is significantly worse than that of airplane (1) because airplane (2) has a significantly lower power-to-weight ratio.
options.B: If the airplanes are operated at the same mass, e.g., 1250 kg, performance will be the same because the remaining engine of airplane (2) will have the same engine power as airplane (1).
options.C: Airplane (2) will have a mass restriction of 1300 kg when flying on a single engine to ensure it has a performance equal to a single-engine aircraft such as airplane (1).
options.D: If the airplanes are operated at the same mass, e.g., 1250 kg, the performance of airplane (2) will be better than that of airplane (1) because one of the benefits of multi-engine airplanes is better performance.

key_points: The question asks us to compare the power-to-weight ratio for the case where the multi-engine plane (2) has only one engine operating
The power-to-weight ratio can be calculated by dividing the engine power by the mass
The single-engine airplane (1) has a piston engine with 160 horsepower (hp) and a mass of 1 300 kg
learning.explanation: The question asks us to compare the power-to-weight ratio for the case where the multi-engine plane (2) has only one engine operating. The power-to-weight ratio can be calculated by dividing the engine power by the mass. The single-engine airplane (1) has a piston engine with 160 horsepower (hp) and a mass of 1 300 kg. The power-to-weight ratio is approximately 0.123 hp/kg. The multi-engine aircraft (2) with one engine running is effectively operating as a single-engine aircraft. In this case, we should only consider the power of the remaining engine, which is 160 hp, and the mass of 1,990 kg. As a result, the power-to-weight ratio is roughly 0.080 hp/kg. In this case, we can observe that the multi-engine aircraft (2) with one engine running has a lower power-to-weight ratio than the single-engine aircraft (1). Therefore, the single-engine aircraft has more power per unit of weight. Generally speaking, an aircraft will perform better if its power-to-weight ratio is higher. Increased acceleration, climb rate, maneuverability, and overall performance characteristics can be attained by having an aircraft with a higher power-to-weight ratio. In this scenario, other performance considerations can be made, for example, regarding the failed engine on the multi-engine aircraft. With an engine failure, not only will the power-to-weight ratio be reduced, but the increased drag will also affect the aircraft's performance. So even if both aircraft are operated at the same weight, the extra drag from the failed engine will cause a decrease in performance.

content.question: What is the primary advantage of increasing the V2 speed on takeoff?

options.B: Associated screen height with the new V1 speed is situated further down the runway.
options.C: The time to reach optimum altitude is reduced.
options.D: Safety margin of field limited takeoff mass increases.

key_points: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass
At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass
It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2
learning.explanation: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass. At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass. It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed. V2 is considerably slower than the best angle of climb speed, which is VX. Climbing with a speed closer to the best angle of climb greatly enhance the climb performance. If runway available it would be possible to stay on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed, this will ensure that at the screen height, a faster V2 will be reached, closer to VX. As a result of the improved climb performance, the climb limit mass can be increased.

options.B: an increased field-length-limited take-off mass and a reduced V1.
options.C: an increased field-length-limited take-off mass and an increased V1.
options.D: an increased obstacle-limited take-off mass and an increased V1.

key_points: This can be thought of quite intuitively
For this question we consider the two most limiting events that can happen during the take-off
Engine failure just before V1 (STOP scenario) and engine failure at V1 (GO scenario)
learning.explanation: This can be thought of quite intuitively. For this question we consider the two most limiting events that can happen during the take-off. Engine failure just before V1 (STOP scenario) and engine failure at V1 (GO scenario). The all-engines take-off is almost never limiting. The stop scenario sets the length of the ASDR (Accelerate-Stop Distance Required). The higher the V1 or the higher the weight, the greater the ASDR. The GO scenario sets the length of the TODR (Take-off Distance Required - distance to get to screen height - engine fails at V1). The lower the V1 or the higher the weight, the greater the TODR. The V1 being lower means that the aircraft has to perform more of its total acceleration with an engine failed, which uses more time and runway distance. We often want to maximise the amount of weight that we can take-off with. This means setting the best possible V1 that allows our ASDR and TODR to fit exactly within the runway we have got, no unused runway. Realistically we want to calculate it so our ASDR equals the ASDA (available) and our TODR equals the TODA. On a balanced field, the ASDA (available) and TODA are the same, so you end up getting a “balanced V1”, which is a great starting point, and allows for easy calculations. This will correspond to a certain FLLTOM (field length limiting take-off mass) which uses up the whole runway in both cases. This is also the most effective use of space, but it is not always possible to build runways like this. If you were to add some available stopway, then with the previous balanced V1, you wouldn't use any of the stopway in the STOP scenario, however, we could decide to use it to squeeze in some extra weight by increasing the V1 (to use up all the stopway in the STOP scenario), and this means that the aircraft is closer to the required climb speed in the GO scenario as well, which means that it helps both scenarios, even without increasing the TODA. This means we can add weight as we have extra margin in both cases by using a lower V1. In the other direction, we could add a clearway to the original runway to make it “unbalanced” in the other way. In this case, we could use the extra clearway to reduce the V1, as the aircraft has some extra space to get to the screen height now, so we can afford to lose the engine earlier in the take-off roll and still GO. This lower V1 means that we won't use up all the runway in the STOP case though, so we can increase the weight until both required distances match the available distances. Summary and extra info: If TOD = ASD, V1 = BALANCED, Balanced condition. If TOD > ASD, V1 < V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Clearway, no stopway = higher mass and lower V1 speed If TOD < ASD, V1 > V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Stopway, no clearway = higher mass and higher V1 speed. TORA (Take-Off Run Distance Available) => RUNWAY only (no STOPWAY or CLEARWAY) TODA (Take-Off Distance Available) => TORA + CLEARWAY ASDA (Accelarate-Stop Distance Available) => TORA + STOPWAY

content.question: How does runway slope affect allowable take-off mass, assuming other factors remain constant and not limiting?

options.A: A downhill slope increases allowable take-off mass.
options.B: Allowable take-off mass is not affected by runway slope.
options.C: An uphill slope increases the allowable take-off mass.
options.D: A downhill slope decreases allowable take-off mass.

key_points: If the runway is sloping, a component of the weight will act along the longitudinal axis of the airplane
This will either augment thrust, or augment drag which will increase or decrease the accelerating force
A downhill slope will increase the accelerating force, and reduce the take-off distance, whereas an uphill slope will reduce the accelerating force and increase the take-off distance
learning.explanation: If the runway is sloping, a component of the weight will act along the longitudinal axis of the airplane. This will either augment thrust, or augment drag which will increase or decrease the accelerating force. A downhill slope will increase the accelerating force, and reduce the take-off distance, whereas an uphill slope will reduce the accelerating force and increase the take-off distance. V1 can be increased and consequently the TOM for the same TODA. Even though it is an uphill slope and the aircraft will come to stop within a shorter distance, the aircraft will need a longer distance to accelerate to V1. The acceleration needed to achieve V1 has a major impact in the ASDR calculation. In case of a downhill slope the ASDR decreases.

content.question: One of the advantages of a higher V2 is...

options.A: The longer take-off distance and the ability to pass close in obstacles.
options.B: The shorter take-off distance and the ability to pass close in obstacles.

key_points: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass
At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass
It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2
learning.explanation: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass. At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass. It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed. V2 is considerably slower than the best angle of climb speed, which is VX. Climbing with a speed closer to the best angle of climb greatly enhance the climb performance. If runway available is long enough, it would be possible to stay on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed to a higher V1, this will ensure that at the screen height, a faster V2 will be reached, closer to VX. As a result of the improved climb performance, the climb limit mass can be increased.

options.A: improves the climb gradient due to the lower pressure altitude.
options.B: decreases the take off roll due to the lower True Air Speed TAS.
options.C: increases the take off roll due to the decrease in thrust available.
options.D: increases the obstacle margin due to the difference between the local QNH and 1013.2 hPa.

key_points: In aviation, pressure altitude is the height above a standard datum plane (SDP), which is a theoretical level where the weight of the atmosphere is 29
921 inches of mercury (QNH 1013=1,013
2 mbar; 14
learning.explanation: In aviation, pressure altitude is the height above a standard datum plane (SDP), which is a theoretical level where the weight of the atmosphere is 29.921 inches of mercury (QNH 1013=1,013.2 mbar; 14.696 psi) as measured by a barometer. Examples would be landing at a high altitude or near sea level under conditions of exceptionally high air pressure. Pressure altitude is primarily used in aircraft-performance calculations and in high-altitude flight The higher an aerodrome’s pressure altitude (high-altitude), the longer the TODR. This is because the air is less dense, which affects both the engine thrust and actual speed at rotation. The reduction in air density reduces the engine mass flow and, therefore, thrust (increases the take off roll), which results in slower acceleration. Second, the reduced air density results in a faster TAS for the same calibrated airspeed VR.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the speeds VMO and VC?

options.A: VMO must be equal to VC.
options.B: VMO must be equal to or greater than VC.
options.C: VMO must NOT be greater than VC.
options.D: VMO must NOT be greater than 0.8 x VC.

key_points: Note: This is a Principles of Flight (081) question which has been reported to come up in Performance exams
All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds
In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes
learning.explanation: Note: This is a Principles of Flight (081) question which has been reported to come up in Performance exams. All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds. In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes. There is a diagram for the maximum load factors (positive and negative) that an aircraft can sustain, whether that limit was to do with a stall limit, or a structural load factor limit. There is also a limiting gust envelope diagram for the maximum gusts an aircraft must be able to handle at various speeds, see annex above. This creates some set design speeds for the aircraft, such as VA, VB, VC and VD. VA - Manoeuvring Speed, the speed where the aircraft will stall at exactly the limiting load factor (2.5 G for CS-25 aircraft). VB - Design Speed for Maximum Gust Intensity, the speed where an aircraft must be able to manage a gust of up to 66 fps. VC - Design Cruise Speed, the maximum speed an aircraft is able to cruise at, giving sufficient safety margin to VD, and means the aircraft will not exceed VD if a particular disturbance occurs when cruising at VC. It is also the point where gusts of up to 50 fps should be managed by the airframe. VC should not be more than 0.8 x VD. VD - Design Dive Speed, the maximum speed that the aircraft can handle in a dive, often limited by vibrations, buffet or flutter. This is the absolute speed limit of the airframe, and the aircraft should be able to manage 25 fps gusts at this speed. To keep the aircraft within safe operation, the VMO (maximum operating speed) must be kept below VC. This is still very fast, and should not be exceeded in normal operations.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Which of the following is a potential hazard associated with the higher V1 speed when performing the increased V2 procedure on take-off?

options.A: The climb gradient is reduced, and obstacle clearance could be reduced to below the required minimum.
options.B: The stopping margins for a rejected take-off are reduced.
options.C: The safety margins for a rejected take-off could be reduced to below the required minima.
options.D: The braking capability during a rejected take-off is reduced.

key_points: Note: This question is very similar to Q329997, with slightly different answers
Both have been reported in exams
Increased V2 Procedure This procedure is used to increase the aircraft's climbing capability after take-off (to increase the climb limited mass or obstacle limited mass)
learning.explanation: Note: This question is very similar to Q329997, with slightly different answers. Both have been reported in exams. Increased V2 Procedure This procedure is used to increase the aircraft's climbing capability after take-off (to increase the climb limited mass or obstacle limited mass). At the minimum V2 the climbing performance is poor and may limit the maximum take-off mass. It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed. V2 is considerably slower than the best angle of climb speed, which is VX. Climbing with a speed closer to the best angle of climb will greatly enhance the climb performance. If extra runway length is available it is sometimes possible to stay on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed to a higher V1, this will ensure that at the screen height, a faster V2 will be reached, closer to VX. As a result of the improved climb performance, the climb/obstacle limited masses can be increased. "The climb gradient is reduced, and obstacle clearance could be reduced to below the required minimum." No, in fact the climb gradient is increased, and nothing will drop below the required minimum, otherwise the procedure would not be allowed. "The stopping margins for a rejected take-off are reduced." Correct. The faster V1 increases the ASDR (Accelerate-Stop Distance Required), and whilst this will not go out of the legal limits (as the procedure would then not be allowed), the extra safety margin will be reduced. "The safety margins for a rejected take-off could be reduced to below the required minima." No, as mentioned just above, the safety margins must always remain at or above the required minima, otherwise the procedure is not allowed. "The braking capability during a rejected take-off is reduced." This requires a little more thought, but is incorrect. The braking capability of the aircraft should not be affected, the brakes should work perfectly well from this higher V1 if a stop is required, and whilst braking will take longer, that is expected from a higher speed. The only things that could really affect the braking capability are brake fade due to overheating and the subsequent melting of fusible plugs, but the aircraft's maximum brake energy will be checked from the higher V1 and should not be high enough to cause either of these to occur outside of normal limits.

content.question: If bleed-air systems are used during take-off, the take-off distance is...

options.A: the same, as it does not on impact engine performance.
options.B: increased, as less thrust is available.
options.C: decreased, due to the lower acceleration.
options.D: decreased, as more fuel is burnt.

key_points: ENGINE BLEED AIR Whenever bleed air is extracted from an engine, and the value of the thrust setting parameter is appropriately reduced, the amount of thrust the engine generates is reduced

Therefore, the use of engine bleed air for air conditioning/pressurization reduces the airplane’s potential takeoff performance for a given set of runway length, temperature and altitude conditions => Consequently, take-off distance increases
Additionally, some of the air which passes through the turbine engine is used to cool the combustion chamber and turbine
learning.explanation: ENGINE BLEED AIR Whenever bleed air is extracted from an engine, and the value of the thrust setting parameter is appropriately reduced, the amount of thrust the engine generates is reduced. Therefore, the use of engine bleed air for air conditioning/pressurization reduces the airplane’s potential takeoff performance for a given set of runway length, temperature and altitude conditions => Consequently, take-off distance increases. Additionally, some of the air which passes through the turbine engine is used to cool the combustion chamber and turbine. If the air flowing through the engine reduces, it will result in a lower cooling capacity and higher Exhaust Gas Temperature (EGT).

content.question: The climb limited take-off mass can be increased by

options.B: a lower flap setting for take-off and selecting a higher V2

key_points: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed
As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient)
This will reduce the take-off run
learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce (degraded climb performance). Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean. INCREASED V2 TAKE-OFF In case of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed and is significantly slower than Vx. The purpose of the improved climb procedure is to achieve an increased V2 in order to be closer to Vx, this will in turn improve climb performance. Consequently, the climb limit mass can increase, increasing the performance limited take-off mass. The aircraft is held on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed. However, this is only possible when there is an excess of available field length due to the increased take-off distance required. => Based on the above, we can conclude that the Climb Limited Take Off Mass will increase when using a lower flap setting (improved climb performance) and selecting a higher V2 speed.

VSR is the reference stall speed.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
Taking off from Lanzarote Airport with reported surface wind of 030/10. There are two runways available for take-off, both with no slope.
RWY 03: Facing the mountains with a TORA of 2 400 m. The aircraft will need to clear an obstacle 297 ft above threshold elevation which is 4 330 m away.
RWY 21: Facing the ocean with a TORA of 2 400 m. There are no obstacles in the climb path.
RWY 03 RTOM: 82 tonnes
RWY 21 RTOM: 84 tonnes
Why is the RTOM for RWY 03 more limiting?

options.A: RWY 03 is climb limited because only 50% of the headwind is accounted for, which has a lesser effect than, for runway 21, 150% of the tailwind component.
options.B: RWY 03 is obstacle-limited and even with the headwind the limiting obstacles have more influence than taking off on runway 21 with a tailwind.
options.C: RWY 03 is climb limited with the obstacle for runway 03 having a greater influence even if it is further away compared to the obstacle for runway 21.
options.D: RWY 03 is field-length limited and even with a headwind it will be more limiting than the field length for runway 21.

key_points: RTOM (Regulated Take-off Mass) is the final figure used for dictating the maximum allowable mass for a particular take-off
It is the lowest of the Performance Limited Take-Off Mass (PLTOM) and the Maximum Structural Take-Off Mass (MSTOM)
As the MSTOM is constant for an aircraft, an aircraft with two different RTOMs for different direction runways must be performance limited in some way
learning.explanation: RTOM (Regulated Take-off Mass) is the final figure used for dictating the maximum allowable mass for a particular take-off. It is the lowest of the Performance Limited Take-Off Mass (PLTOM) and the Maximum Structural Take-Off Mass (MSTOM). As the MSTOM is constant for an aircraft, an aircraft with two different RTOMs for different direction runways must be performance limited in some way. The PLTOM is the lowest of the Climb Limited Take-Off Mass (CLTOM), Obstacle Limited Take-Off Mass (OLTOM) and the Field-Length Limited Take-Off Mass (FLLTOM). The lowest mass of those is the most limiting factor. So in this question, the take-off from RWY 03 must be more limited in some way, to warrant a lower RTOM, which must come from a lower PLTOM. Lets consider each possible limitation. FLLTOM - RWY 03 is the same length as RWY 21 with no slope to account for, but there is a 10 kt headwind to RWY 03, and a 10 kt tailwind to RWY 21, which would cause the FLLTOM to be significantly higher for RWY 03, as that is where there is better take-off performance. As this is not reflected in the RTOM difference, the take-off is not field-length limited. CLTOM - The climb limit is based solely on whether the aircraft can maintain the legal climb gradients. In particular, the second take-off segment with one engine inoperative requires a 2.4% still air climb gradient for a 2-engined aeroplane. It is a still air gradient, so wind is not to be accounted for. This will mean that there are no differences relevant to CLTOM between the two runways, so the CLTOMs would be the same. Therefore, this is not what has caused the difference in RTOM. OLTOM - The only one remaining. The aircraft is taking off towards the mountains on RWY 03, as opposed to the ocean, and a specific obstacle has been identified which will require a particular angle of climb to clear, so this checks out with the RTOM being lower. After considering all possibilities, it must be that the aircraft is obstacle limited on RWY 03.

The horizontal distance travelled, with all engines operating, to reach a screen height of 35 ft multiplied by 1

The horizontal distance from BRP to the point at which the airplane attains 35 ft, assuming the critical power unit fails at VEF on a dry, hard surface. One engine inoperative (wet runway). The horizontal distance from BRP to the point at which the airplane attains 15 ft, assuming the critical power unit fails at VEF on a wet or contaminated hard surface, achieved in a manner consistent with the achievement of V2 by 35 ft.

content.question: You are the pilot of a transport category aeroplane and have just started a precision approach. You can recognise that you are too high and too fast on the descent path. You are flying in a (clean) aircraft configuration, which means that the landing gear is up and the flaps are retracted. What should you do?

options.A: Decrease airspeed to below VLO and extend the landing gear, followed by flaps , to increase drag and get back on the descent path and speed profile.
options.B: Decrease your airspeed and rate of descent to get back on your descent path. When back on the descent path, reduce your airspeed and start extending flaps and landing gear on schedule.
options.C: Decrease your airspeed and rate of descent to get back on your descent path. When back on the descent path, plan for a flaps-up approach with a higher airspeed.
options.D: Increase your airspeed, which will result in an increase in your rate of descent, allowing you to get back on the descent path.

key_points: Since the aircraft is "too high", the pilot must increase the descent angle (steeper descent path)
The descent angle is given by the formula: Sin γ = (D - T) / W
Thus, so as to increase the descent angle, the excess drag (D - T) must be increased, assuming that thrust is constant at ground idle and weight does not change significantly during descent
learning.explanation: Since the aircraft is "too high", the pilot must increase the descent angle (steeper descent path). The descent angle is given by the formula: Sin γ = (D - T) / W. Thus, so as to increase the descent angle, the excess drag (D - T) must be increased, assuming that thrust is constant at ground idle and weight does not change significantly during descent. The excess drag can be increased during descent in a precision approach with the landing gear down and the flaps extended. High lift devices, such as flaps, change the wing area and shape to potentially increase lift, but they also increase the parasite drag. But before that, the airspeed must be decreased to below the maximum speed at which the landing gear can be operated, VLO, which is always lower than the maximum safe speed to fly with landing gear extended, VLE, and will assist to reduce the already increased aircraft's airspeed, since it is "too fast".

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question:
What is the correct sequence of descent speeds for a turbojet aeroplane starting at top of descent? (Assume idle thrust and clean configuration and ignore compressibility effects).
Initially, descend maintaining a constant:

options.A: TAS in the first part of descent and then at a constant Mach number in the second part of the descent.
options.B: Mach number in the first part of the descent and then at a constant TAS in the second part of the descent.
options.C: Mach number in the first part of the descent and then at a constant IAS in the second part of the descent.
options.D: IAS in the first part of descent and then at a constant Mach number in the second part of the descent.

key_points: At cruising altitude an airliner will be flying Mach number, so the operational limit is the MMO (Maximum Operating Mach Number)
The aircraft would initially descend maintaining a constant mach number
At the crossover altitude, the limiting speed will become VMO, from which point, the aircraft should be flown at a constant IAS
learning.explanation: At cruising altitude an airliner will be flying Mach number, so the operational limit is the MMO (Maximum Operating Mach Number). The aircraft would initially descend maintaining a constant mach number. At the crossover altitude, the limiting speed will become VMO, from which point, the aircraft should be flown at a constant IAS. If the aircraft was to keep descending at a constant Mach, the TAS and IAS would keep increasing, leading to a VMO overspeed situation. Therefore, at the changeover altitude, the flight crew must stop flying at a Mach number and fly at constant IAS. The climb is carried out in two phases: the first at a constant IAS and the second at a constant Mach Number, after the crossover altitude. The descent is carried out in two phases: the first at a constant Mach Number and the second at a constant IAS, after the crossover altitude.

The total of the gross distance from the start of the take-off run to the point at which VLOF is reached, plus one half of the gross distance from VLOF to the point at which the airplane reaches 35 ft, all factored by 1
15 to obtain the net TORR

The total of the gross distance from the start of the take-off run to the point at which VLOF is reached, plus one half of the gross distance from VLOF to the point at which the airplane reaches 35 ft, all factored by 1.15 to obtain the net TORR. The horizontal distance from the brake release point (BRP) to a point equidistant between VLOF and the point at which the airplane reaches 35 ft with the critical power unit inoperative. One power unit inoperative (wet runway). The horizontal distance from the brake release point (BRP) to the point at which the airplane is 15 ft above the take-off surface, achieved in a manner consistent with the attainment of V2 by 35 ft, assuming the critical power unit inoperative at VEF.

content.question: Performance Class A, Take-Off. In comparison to a conventional take-off, the improved climb take-off results in a:

options.A: Reduced V1 to get an earlier lift-off which leads to more obstacle clearance.
options.B: Reduced flap setting to enhance the climb performance.
options.C: Higher flap setting to enhance the climb performance.
options.D: Higher V1 and more take-off distance required.

key_points: Increased V2 Take-Off In case of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2
However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed and is significantly slower than VX
The purpose of the improved climb procedure is to achieve an increased V2 in order to be closer to VX, this will in turn improve climb performance
learning.explanation: Increased V2 Take-Off In case of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed and is significantly slower than VX. The purpose of the improved climb procedure is to achieve an increased V2 in order to be closer to VX, this will in turn improve climb performance. If the runway is long enough, the aircraft may accelerate to a higher V1, VR and V2 so that V2 is as close as possible to the best-angle-of-climb speed (which is the minimum drag speed for a jet aircraft). This means that unused runway is traded off for better climb.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: The second segment begins...

options.A: when acceleration starts from V1 to the speed for flap retraction.
options.B: when landing gear is fully retracted.

key_points: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: 1
The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative
On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15'
learning.explanation: Segments of the Take-off Climb For a class A aircraft, the T/O climb is divided into 4 segments: 1. The take-off flight path starts once the take-off is complete, at 35 ft with the airplane at V2 with one engine inoperative. On a wet runway, the screen height is reduced to 15'. Operating engines are at takeoff thrust, the flaps/slats are in takeoff configuration and landing gear retraction is initiated once safely airborne with positive climb. The first segment ends when the landing gear is fully retracted. 2. Begins when the landing gear is fully retracted. Engines are at takeoff thrust and the aircraft is accelerated in level flight. Slats/flaps are retracted on speed. Once this has happened, thrust can be reduced from maximum take-off thrust, TOGA, to maximum continuous thrust, MCT. 4. Starts when the flaps are retracted, the final segment speed is achieved, and the thrust is set to maximum continuous thrust. From this point the airplane is climbed to above 1500 ft where the take-off flight path ends. EFFECT OF FLAPS ON TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. It is a technique employed to preserve engine life or reduce the noise generated at take-off. This technique can only be used when the available distance greatly exceeds that which is required. The maximum reduction in thrust permitted is 25% of that required for a normal take-off. 2.8.1 Restrictions A reduced thrust take-off is not permitted with: • icy or very slippery runways • contaminated runways • anti-skid unserviceable • reverse thrust unserviceable • increased V2 procedure • the PMC off. 2.8.2 Calculation Procedure It is first necessary to determine the most limiting performance condition. The only common parameter to enable comparison is that of temperature. Thus the maximum permissible temperature must be calculated for the actual take-off mass from each of the following: • field limit graph • climb limit graph • tyre-speed limit graph • obstacle limit graph From these temperatures, select the lowest and ensure that it does not exceed the environmental limit. content.question: At a tropical airfield during the rainy season, heavy rain showers often cause the runways to be very wet. Which of the following landing techniques should be used when landing on these runways?

options.A: The pilot should maintain normal approach and landing technique but use a slower approach and landing speed compared to dry runway operations.
options.B: Positive landings with prompt full application of all retardation devices and maximum brake/autobrake with anti-skid.
options.C: Landings should be made with light touchdowns, maximum air brake and reverse thrust but minimum anti-skid braking.
options.D: Use of reverse thrust should be kept to a minimum to avoid water spray and ingestion; anti-skid braking should be applied slowly to avoid hydroplaning.

key_points: In wet runway operations, or main issues are with braking
Due to hydroplaning, the water on the runway can create a slippery layer between the runway and the tyres
This has very low friction, so the tyre will have no traction available to applying braking force, the wheel will "lock up" and the tyre will just skid on a "wedge of water"
learning.explanation: In wet runway operations, or main issues are with braking. Due to hydroplaning, the water on the runway can create a slippery layer between the runway and the tyres. This has very low friction, so the tyre will have no traction available to applying braking force, the wheel will "lock up" and the tyre will just skid on a "wedge of water". This is why it is important to land firmly and apply as much braking as possible immediately, including reverse thrust and speedbrakes. Speedbrakes are particularly useful as they will remove lots of the aircraft's lift and force it into the ground quite hard, to allow better braking. Hydroplaning occurs differently whether the tyres are spinning or not, and the speed it occurs at is governed by the following two formulas. Tyres are not spinning when the aircraft touches down, hence the increased risk of hydroplaning. (non-rotating wheel) Hydroplaning speed = 7.7 x √(tyre pressure (psi)) (rotating wheel) Hydroplaning speed = 9 x √(tyre pressure (psi))

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: The CS-25 regulations published by EASA specify definitions regarding climb gradients and net climb gradients. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The net climb gradient is based on flight tests and does not account for safety margins.
options.B: The net climb gradient is based on the gross climb gradient, reduced to account for safety margins based on the number of engines.
options.C: The climb gradient is based on the net climb gradient, increased to account for a safety margin.
options.D: The net climb gradient is based on flight tests only.

key_points: When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more
There are different types of performance categorisation
Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification
learning.explanation: When aircraft are being certified, the manufacturer must test the aircraft in many different ways to define certain levels of performance for many phases of flight, such as take-off distance, maximum rate of climb, landing distance and many more. There are different types of performance categorisation. Measured Performance is the performance achieved by the manufacturer under test conditions for certification. It utilises new aeroplanes and the test pilots, and is therefore not representative of the actual performance that any single aircraft might be able to achieve in normal circumstances, flown by a normal pilot. Gross Performance is the expected fleet average of aeroplanes, given that they are sufficiently maintained and flown as per the techniques detailed in the flight manuals, by a normal pilot. This means that any aircraft in the fleet has a 50% chance of exceeding this performance, but also a 50% chance of not meeting this performance. Net Performance is the gross performance, reduced by the safety margin, to account for various possibilities that could commonly cause reduced performance, such as variations in pilot technique, below-average aircraft performance, etc. The safety margin is set so that the chance of an aircraft not meeting the net performance level is extremely low. The safety margin is not fixed, It depends on the likelihood of the situation occurring, and is set to make sure that the total probability of an incident or accident occurring is at least lower than 1 in 1 million, when a passenger buys their ticket (known as their “remote probability”). This might mean that the safety margin (between gross and net performance) is large for likely events such as a take-off with all engines operating, but the safety margin is very low or even zero for unlikely events such as an engine failure at V1. The amount of engines directly affects the likelihood of an engine failure occurring during take-off or climb out, so the net take-off flight paths have different safety margins, depending on the amount of engines. For take-off, CS-25 specifies a reduction from the actual take-off flight path gradient of: 0.8% for two-engined aeroplanes; 0.9% for three-engined aeroplanes; and 1.0% for four-engined aeroplanes.

content.question: In case of performance Class A aeroplane, why would you consider performing a derated thrust take-off on a contaminated runway?

options.A: There will be an additional safety margin, and maximum take-off power (TOGA) can be selected at any time during take-off.
options.B: New minimum control speeds can be established, which might lead to better take-off performance.
options.C: VMCG and VMCA will be equal, leading to better take-off performance.
options.D: V1 can be lowered below VMCG, leading to better take-off performance.

key_points: A derated thrust take-off is considered to be a normal take-off and therefore can be carried out both on dry and on wet and contaminated runways, always subject to the Aircraft Flight Manual data and other operating restrictions

Because the take-off speeds are calculated at the lower thrust, the derated thrust setting is considered to be a limit and therefore full thrust or TOGA thrust cannot be selected, even in an emergency, until the hazard area for VMCG and VMCA is well passed

The primary advantage of the derated thrust take-offs, compared to flex take-offs, is that the lower rated thrust will lead to lower values of VMCG and VMCA and this fact may avoid a VMCG limited take-off, in some circumstances, leading to a greater MTOM at a lower thrust setting
learning.explanation: A derated thrust take-off is considered to be a normal take-off and therefore can be carried out both on dry and on wet and contaminated runways, always subject to the Aircraft Flight Manual data and other operating restrictions. Because the take-off speeds are calculated at the lower thrust, the derated thrust setting is considered to be a limit and therefore full thrust or TOGA thrust cannot be selected, even in an emergency, until the hazard area for VMCG and VMCA is well passed. The primary advantage of the derated thrust take-offs, compared to flex take-offs, is that the lower rated thrust will lead to lower values of VMCG and VMCA and this fact may avoid a VMCG limited take-off, in some circumstances, leading to a greater MTOM at a lower thrust setting. The requirement is that V1 must be greater than VMCG, so a lower value of VMCG may allow a higher limiting TOM. NOTE: Remember that flexible or reduced thrust take-offs are not permitted on contaminated runways and offer no VMC advantage, because it is possible and permitted to increase to TOGA thrust at any point during the take-off, so no reduction in VMCG is possible and a greater distance to V1 will result. This is why flexible thrust is not permitted when anything causes a reduction in aircraft performance (e.g. contamination) or an increase on take-off run required (e.g. increased V2).

content.question: For a Performance Class A aircraft, the Net Take-Off Flight Path begins at a height of (1) _____ above the reference zero point and ends at a height of (2) _____ at least.

key_points: The Class A Net Take-Off Flight Path (NTOFP) may be divided into segments and each segment being defined by a change in configuration, thrust or speed
The loss of an engine at VEF means that the aircraft will not be able to both climb and accelerate and so must level-off to retract the flaps-slats at some stage
The level-off height is sometimes called as "gross level-off height" or "altitude" or "acceleration altitude"
learning.explanation: The Class A Net Take-Off Flight Path (NTOFP) may be divided into segments and each segment being defined by a change in configuration, thrust or speed. The loss of an engine at VEF means that the aircraft will not be able to both climb and accelerate and so must level-off to retract the flaps-slats at some stage. The level-off height is sometimes called as "gross level-off height" or "altitude" or "acceleration altitude". The four conventional segments of the Class A NTOFP are the following: The first segment lasts from the end of the TODR, at which point the aircraft is at 35 ft above the reference point at the screen height, to when the gear is up. It is flown at V2 with take-off thrust setting and flaps-slats extended. The second segment lasts from gear retracted to the gross level-off height. It is also flown at V2 with take-off thrust set and flaps-slats extended. The third segment is a level flap retraction segment ending once the aircraft is clean and has accelerated to the final segment climb speed. At the end of the third segment, the thrust is reduced on the remaining engine(s) to the Max Continuous Thrust (MCT). The fourth segment is a climb from the flap retraction height to at least 1500 ft. The speed would be the VX clean.

Compressed snow being an exception - only ASD will be affected
learning.explanation: CONTAMINATED RUNWAY Contaminants such as water, snow, slush or ice will affect both the take-off and landing distances. The take-off distance typically increases due to the increased rolling resistence and reduced acceleration. Compressed snow being an exception - only ASD will be affected. Solid contaminants are those contaminants that an airplane’s tire will remain on top of and not break through. Compacted snow and ice are solid contaminants. metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: When V1 has to be reduced because of a wet runway the one engine out obstacle clearance / climb performance:

key_points: When compared to a dry runway, V1 for a wet runway decreases
The obstacle clearance and climb performance calculations are based on the assumption that the critical engine will fail at V1
At a slower V1, the acceleration from V1 to VLOF with OEI takes longer and, consequently, increases the take-off distance required
learning.explanation: When compared to a dry runway, V1 for a wet runway decreases. The obstacle clearance and climb performance calculations are based on the assumption that the critical engine will fail at V1. At a slower V1, the acceleration from V1 to VLOF with OEI takes longer and, consequently, increases the take-off distance required. As a result, the aircraft will lift-off further down on the runway (closer to the obstacle) and V2 and 35 ft will be reached at a later point during take-off. A reduction of screen height from 35 ft to 15 ft is allowed in order to reduce weight penalties => the obstacle clearance will be reduced. The Climb performance, however, will remain constant as the selection of a lower V1 does not affect the initial take-off climb performance and it is already calculated for OEI case.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: A FLAT RATED jet engine will give:

options.A: decreasing thrust as temperature decreases below a cut-off value
options.B: increasing thrust as temperature increases above a cut-off value
options.C: a constant thrust for temperatures above a cut-off value
options.D: a constant thrust for temperatures below a cut-off value

key_points: The Flat Rating Concept The rating of a jet engine is the thrust performance that is guaranteed by the manufacturer for a new engine under specific operating conditions such as, take off, maximum continuous, climb, cruise
Some non Prat and Whitney (P&W) engines are rated to a constant compressor speed (RPM)
P&W rates there engines to a constant exhaust gas temperature (EGT)
learning.explanation: The Flat Rating Concept The rating of a jet engine is the thrust performance that is guaranteed by the manufacturer for a new engine under specific operating conditions such as, take off, maximum continuous, climb, cruise. Some non Prat and Whitney (P&W) engines are rated to a constant compressor speed (RPM). P&W rates there engines to a constant exhaust gas temperature (EGT). This is referred to as the flat rating concept. To get your head around this concept you must understand the following principle. The temperature and density of the ambient air vary inversely. Lower temperature = > Higher Density Higher Temperature = >Lower Density The amount of airflow (lbs/sec) through the engine is a function of compressor speed and air density. It is greater when the compressor speed and density are high. The compressor speed is a function of the energy available to the compressors turbine. That energy comes from the combustion or air and fuel, so the turbine turns faster when the fuel flow rate is greater. The compressor speed is also a function of the airflow through the compressor. Higher rates of air flow reduce the speed of the compressor. The compressors rotational speed and the amount of airflow through the compressor are independent, they affect each other though. The turbine inlet temperature is proportional to the energy available to turn the turbine. The exhaust temperature is proportional to the turbine inlet temperature. So a higher EGT corresponds to a larger amount of energy to the turbine so it can turn the compressor faster. When EGT is held constant, or lowered the result is a prolonged hot section life and at the same time provides the thrust to meet the certification requirements.

content.question: What are the effects of using a clearway on both the Allowed Take-Off Mass and the associated V1? The Allowed Take-Off Mass…

With a longer distance available to stop the aircraft after an aborted take-off, the V1 decision speed can be increased
All the speeds are related with reference stall speed, which is a function of the aircraft mass
learning.explanation: V1 AND STOPWAY/CLEARWAY STOPWAY is an area beyond the take-off runway, no less wide than the runway and centered upon the extended center line of the runway, able to support the airplane during an aborted take-off, without causing structural damage to the airplane, and designated by the airport authorities for use in decelerating the airplane during an aborted take-off. With a longer distance available to stop the aircraft after an aborted take-off, the V1 decision speed can be increased. All the speeds are related with reference stall speed, which is a function of the aircraft mass. A higher allowed V1 permits a higher take-off mass. CLEARWAY is an area beyond the paved runway, free of obstructions and under the control of the airport authorities. The length of the clearway may be included in the length of the takeoff distance available. If TORA = TODA then the mass is limited by TODA because the aircraft must be at 35ft at the end of TODA with an engine out. (The V1 will be established on TODA and ASDA) If we now have a clearway then TODA is increased and the aircraft does not need to be at 35 ft until a later point at the end of TODA. The FLLTOM increases. As the ASDA has stayed the same then the V1 must be reduced in the event of a rejected take-off.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Compared to a dry V1 speed, a wet V1 is:

options.A: Higher, because on a wet runway an aircraft requires a shorter distance to stop in the event of an aborted take-off.
options.B: Lower, because on a wet runway an aircraft takes longer to stop in the event of an aborted take-off.
options.C: Lower, because aircraft can reach higher speeds on wet runways.
options.D: The V1 speed is the same for both runways.

key_points: A dry (maximum) V1 is the normal decision speed that following an engine failure allows the take-off to be continued safely within the TODA or to be stopped safely within the ASDA
A wet (minimum) V1 is the maximum speed for abandoning a take-off on a contaminated runway

A wet V1 improves the stopping capabilities (final stop point) back to the dry conditions level but degrades the takeoff chances with a reduced screen height in the event of a take-off being continued
learning.explanation: A dry (maximum) V1 is the normal decision speed that following an engine failure allows the take-off to be continued safely within the TODA or to be stopped safely within the ASDA. A wet (minimum) V1 is the maximum speed for abandoning a take-off on a contaminated runway. A wet V1 improves the stopping capabilities (final stop point) back to the dry conditions level but degrades the takeoff chances with a reduced screen height in the event of a take-off being continued. A recommended wet V1 for contaminated conditions is the dry V1 - 10 knots. Thus wet V1 is a lower speed than dry V1. Note: Due to lower friction and consequently reduced braking action on a wet runway, longer braking distances are experienced, V1 must be decreased.

content.question: A crew preparing their FMC for departure selects an assumed temperature of 45°C for their take-off thrust. The OAT is 20°C. What will this difference between actual temperature and assumed temperature mean for their take-off performance?

options.A: Taking off with a selected temperature of 45°C and an actual OAT of 20°C would result in improved performance than if a selected temperature of 20°C were to be selected.
options.B: Taking off with a selected temperature of 45°C and an actual OAT of 20°C would result in the same performance as if the OAT were 20°C.
options.C: There are no tangible differences between selecting an assumed temperature of 20°C or 45°C.
options.D: Taking off with a selected temperature of 45°C and an actual OAT of 20°C would result in the same performance as if the OAT were 45°C.

key_points: Sometimes it is operationally useful to reduce an aircraft's thrust for take-off, in order to run the engines less hard; reducing maintenance costs, increasing engine life, etc
This is possible when the aircraft is neither field-length nor climb or obstacle limited, and there is effectively performance to spare
This does not save any fuel, due to the increased time to get to more efficient altitudes
learning.explanation: Sometimes it is operationally useful to reduce an aircraft's thrust for take-off, in order to run the engines less hard; reducing maintenance costs, increasing engine life, etc. This is possible when the aircraft is neither field-length nor climb or obstacle limited, and there is effectively performance to spare. This does not save any fuel, due to the increased time to get to more efficient altitudes. There are two ways to do this. Reduced take-off thrust (FLEX) or through a fixed de-rate. The main difference being that a de-rate limits the total engine thrust, but FLEX take-off just limits how much of the engine we use, and we could select TO/GA thrust at any time and use the whole amount of thrust. There are reasons that either, or even both may be used. The question is talking about a reduced thrust (FLEX) take-off, where we tell the engine to perform as it would in a higher temperature condition. That leads the engine to believe that it is operating in a temperature limited (TGT limited) scenario, so it only produces a lower thrust. The temperature that we want it to mimic is called the assumed or FLEX temperature. Therefore, the performance we can expect with an assumed temperature of 45ºC is the same as we would receive if the OAT was 45ºC. The take-off run would be slightly better than if the OAT was 45ºC, though, as the lift under the wings is still that of 20ºC. This does not change the final answer, though, it is still most correct.

learning.explanation: Among others, one of the factors affecting the take-off and the accelerate-stop distance required is the runway slope. If the runway slopes downhill, the aircraft will be easier to accelerate, assisted by a component of the aircraft weight acting downhill and the distance to V1 and to rotate will be reduced. While, an uphill slope increases the take-off distance. If the runway slopes downhill, it will be harder to stop, but the acceleration phase has the greatest effect and, overall, the accelerate-stop distance required decreases. If the runway slopes uphill, the reverse is true, the accelerate-stop distance required increases.
