content.question: Which is the correct sequence of speed during take-off?

key_points: V2 take-off safety speed, or the speed at the screen height, with the critical engine inoperative
This speed cannot be lower than VMC, otherwise it would be impossible to control the airplane when the critical engine suddenly becomes inoperative with the remaining engine(s) at take-off thrust
VMCG is the minimum speed on the ground at which the take-off can be safely continued, when the critical engine suddenly becomes inoperative with the remaining engine(s) at take-off thrust
learning.explanation: V2 take-off safety speed, or the speed at the screen height, with the critical engine inoperative. This speed cannot be lower than VMC, otherwise it would be impossible to control the airplane when the critical engine suddenly becomes inoperative with the remaining engine(s) at take-off thrust. VMCG is the minimum speed on the ground at which the take-off can be safely continued, when the critical engine suddenly becomes inoperative with the remaining engine(s) at take-off thrust. V1 is defined as being the maximum speed at which the pilot must take the first action in order to stop the airplane within the remaining accelerate-stop distance. V1 cannot be allowed to be less than VMCG because engine failure below VMCG means the airplane is uncontrollable and the definition of V1 is that the take-off can be continued following engine failure. Rotation speed, VR, is the speed at which the pilot initiates action to raise the nose gear off the ground, with the intention of becoming airborne. VR may not be less then decision speed V1. VMBE is the maximum speed on the ground from which an airplane can safely stop within the energy capabilities of the brakes. V1 must not be greater than VMBE. At V1 the airplane must be able to stop or continue the take-off, but above VMBE it is impossible to bring the airplane safely to a stop.

content.question: A large jet transport aircraft is cruising at FL280. 10 minutes before their planned TOD, the pilots get a clearance to climb to their optimum altitude of FL320. Why might the pilots not accept this clearance?

options.A: Insufficient fuel remains, as the aircraft is near its destination.
options.B: The arrival is more complicated to perform from FL320 than FL280.
options.C: A climb would require more fuel than a short cruise at FL280 to the TOD.
options.D: The optimum altitude will decrease in the following 10 minutes and be closer to FL280.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.03.06.08: Explain the reasons why a step climb may not be used (e.g. for short sectors, advantageous winds, avoiding turbulence, and due to air traffic restrictions). Jet aircraft have much better fuel efficiency at high altitudes, and pilots endeavour to spend the vast majority of their time at high cruising altitudes to take advantage of that efficiency. During flight, as an aircraft burns fuel, it becomes lighter, and therefore is able to fly at a higher altitude, which in turn provides even greater efficiency. This means that the optimum altitude gradually increases over the course of a flight. To follow this optimum altitude, pilots can request step climbs or a cruise climb. Step climbs are where the pilots start at or above their optimum altitude, then the optimum altitude goes above them, and after a certain amount, they request another climb to the next suitable flight level, and the process begins again. For some aircraft on routes with little traffic, they can be cleared to make a cruise climb which allows the aircraft to follow its optimum altitude exactly, climbing continuously. As per the learning objective above, sometimes it is inefficient to make the last step climb of a journey, if there is only going to be a short time spent at the new altitude, as the extra fuel burnt climbing to that altitude will negate the extra efficiency.

content.question: In order to carry out the Increased V2 Procedure the length of runway required is (1)_____ and this helps to (2)_____ obstacle clearance by (3)_____ the take-off run.

key_points: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass
At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass
It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2
learning.explanation: Take-off with Increased V2 Speed This procedure is used when the performance limited mass is the climb limit mass. At V2 the climbing performance is poor and limits the maximum take-off mass. It is important to understand that in the event of engine failure, the initial climb out speed is V2. However, V2 is not the best climb angle speed. V2 is considerably slower than the best angle of climb speed, which is VX. Climbing with a speed closer to the best angle of climb greatly enhance the climb performance. If runway available is long enough, it would be possible to stay on the runway for longer during the take-off to build up more speed to a higher V1, this will ensure that at the screen height, a faster V2 will be reached, closer to VX. As a result of the improved climb performance, the climb limit mass can be increased.

content.question: The latest model of an aircraft changed the long range performance climb speeds from 250kt / 0.74 to 250kt / 0.78. Which of the following changes to operational limits would cause this?

key_points: Aircraft certified under CS-25 (and some aircraft certified under CS-23) have a VMO and an MMO
VMO is the maximum operating speed, and is an indicated airspeed (IAS)
MMO is the maximum operating Mach Number
learning.explanation: Aircraft certified under CS-25 (and some aircraft certified under CS-23) have a VMO and an MMO. VMO is the maximum operating speed, and is an indicated airspeed (IAS). MMO is the maximum operating Mach Number. It is usually the limiting factor when flying above the crossover/change-over altitude, where the aircraft goes from flying using IAS to flying using Mach Numbers. Standard crossover altitudes are around 28 000 ft, and are dependent on the climb speed schedule. The question gives two separate climb speed schedule, 250kt/0.74 and 250kt/0.78. This means that the old model of aircraft changed over to Mach Numbers in the climb at the altitude where 250 KIAS equals M0.74, and this has changed to where 250 KIAS equals M0.78 (which will be a higher altitude). If this has changed due to an "operational limit", as it is worded in the question, then that must be one of the speed limits mentioned above. As it is the Mach Number component that has increased, then it must mean that the MMO has increased, and the climb speed schedule has changed to allow higher Mach Numbers because of this. Certainly, from the available options, this is the only possible correct one.

content.question:
The flight crew of an MRJT aeroplane have calculated the following landing performance figures for each of the aircraft's allowable landing flap settings...
Flap settings: Flaps 5 Flaps 15 Flaps 30
Landing climb limited mass: 56 430 kg 55 500 kg 50 300 kg
Approach climb limited mass: 57 400 kg 56 140 kg 52 740 kg
Runway length limited mass: 51 780 kg 54 100 kg 56 000 kg
Actual landing mass: 53450 kg
Maximum structural landing mass: 56000 kg
Select the correct flap setting to use for landing.

key_points: Often, an aircraft's relative performance is measured by how heavy the aircraft could be whilst staying within safe limits
If an aircraft has higher performance, it can do the same procedure or manoeuvre at a higher maximum weight (and remain within safe limits)
The flap settings that an aircraft use make a big difference to its take-off and landing
learning.explanation: Often, an aircraft's relative performance is measured by how heavy the aircraft could be whilst staying within safe limits. If an aircraft has higher performance, it can do the same procedure or manoeuvre at a higher maximum weight (and remain within safe limits). The flap settings that an aircraft use make a big difference to its take-off and landing. For landing, a higher flap setting decreases the landing distance (due to slower approach speed), but decreases climb gradient, due to higher drag. This means that the field length landing performance is excellent with higher flap settings (therefore higher maximum weight), but the climb performance is worse (therefore lower maximum weights). All we have to do in these questions is look at which flap setting satisfies our requirements for all possibilities (landing climb, approach climb, and field length). This just means we are looking for a column where all the maximum masses are not less than the actual landing mass. The only column where the masses remain above our actual landing mass is the middle one, for flaps 15. That is therefore the only one that fulfils our requirement.

content.question: A commercial jet aeroplane is performing a straight descent at a constant Mach number with constant mass. The operational speed limit that may be exceeded is:

key_points: The Mach number is defined as the ratio between the TAS and the LSS (Local speed of sound)
It is an indication of how fast an aircraft is travelling with relation to the sound waves that surround it
The Mach number may be calculated as follows: M= TAS/LSS = (TAS(kt)) / (38
learning.explanation: The Mach number is defined as the ratio between the TAS and the LSS (Local speed of sound). It is an indication of how fast an aircraft is travelling with relation to the sound waves that surround it. The Mach number may be calculated as follows: M= TAS/LSS = (TAS(kt)) / (38.95∗√(T(K))) The speed of propagation of small pressure waves depends upon the temperature of the air ONLY. Effect on Mach Number of Climbing at a Constant IAS: - Temperature decreases with increasing altitude, so the speed of sound will decrease as altitude is increased. - If altitude is increased at a constant IAS, the TAS increases. - Therefore, the Mach number will increase if altitude is increased at a constant IAS. This is because TAS gets bigger and LSS gets smaller. As the climb continues, an altitude will be reached at which the flight crew must stop flying at a constant IAS and fly at a constant Mach number, to avoid accidentally exceeding MMO. Effect on TAS of descending at a constant Mach Number: - Temperature increases with decreasing altitude, so the speed of sound will increase as altitude is decreased. - If altitude is decreased at a constant Mach Number, the TAS increases. This is because LSS gets bigger. As the descent continues, an altitude will be reached at which the flight crew must stop flying at a constant Mach Number and fly at a constant IAS, to avoid accidentally exceeding VMO.

Learning Objective 032.02.03.01.05: Describe the effects of brake release before take-off power is set on the TOD and ASD. content.question: When compared to a "balanced" condition, taking into account a Stopway leads to a…

options.A: higher Take-Off Mass and decreased V1.
options.B: higher Take-Off Mass and increased V1.
options.C: lower Take-Off Mass and decreased V1.
options.D: lower Take-Off Mass and increased V1.

key_points: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length
Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length

BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition
learning.explanation: BALANCED FIELD LENGTH When the Accelerate-stop Distance Available (ASDA) is equal to the Take-off Distance Available (TODA), this is known as a Balanced Field Length. Likewise, when the ASDA and TODA are different lengths, this is known as an Unbalanced Field Length. BALANCED FIELD TAKE-OFF A balanced field take-off is performance based and is a condition where the Accelerate-stop Distance Required (ASDR) is equal to the Take-off Distance Required (TODR) for the aircraft weight, engine thrust, aircraft configuration and runway condition. The balanced field length is the shortest field length at which a balanced field take-off can be performed. A Balanced field length is used to simplify the field-length take-off mass. When applying this concept, TOD = ASD and V1 = V1 Balanced. And this means that we are using the minimum requirements in case of engine failure, thus increasing safety margins. When using stopway or clearway, extra distance will be available and V1 will vary. BALANCED V1 The first graph on the attached figure, helps understanding the impact of increasing or decreasing V1. Analyzing it, we can conclude the following: A Balanced V1 is a V1 speed which results in TODR equal to ASDR. Often called the “Ideal V1” as it gives the minimum field length required for a given weight and optimum performance. Any lower V1 (V1 < V1B) would increase TODR, as it would take longer for the aircraft to accelerate to V2 with OEI. As a result, the total field required increases. Any higher V1 (V1 > V1B) would increase ASDR due to a higher energy absorption by the brakes. As a result, the total field required would also increase. => In essence, Balanced V1 improves field length limited take-off performance. => Unbalanced V1 allows for higher take-off weights by taking advantage of any runway and clearway or stopway available in excess of balanced field length. Summary and extra info: If TOD = ASD, V1 = BALANCED, Balanced condition. If TOD > ASD, V1 < V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Clearway, no stopway = higher mass and lower V1 speed If TOD < ASD, V1 > V1 BALANCED, Unbalanced condition. Stopway, no clearway = higher mass and higher V1 speed. TORA (Take-Off Run Distance Available) => RUNWAY only (no STOPWAY or CLEARWAY) TODA (Take-Off Distance Available) => TORA + CLEARWAY ASDA (Accelarate-Stop Distance Available) => TORA + STOPWAY

content.question: What should the pilot do if he/she experiences dutch roll?

options.A: The pilot should damp it heavily with rudder.
options.B: It should be counteracted with roll damper.
options.C: The speed and altitude should be decreased.
options.D: The angle of attack should be increased.

key_points: Note: This is a Principles of Flight question and there is no corresponding learning objective in Performance
Please let us know if you see this in the Performance exam
DUTCH ROLL
learning.explanation: Note: This is a Principles of Flight question and there is no corresponding learning objective in Performance. Please let us know if you see this in the Performance exam. DUTCH ROLL. This is an oscillation involving roll, yaw and sideslip. Because of these characteristics of the Dutch roll oscillation, lateral dynamic stability has always been more of a problem than longitudinal dynamic stability. With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This is called Dutch roll. Dutch roll might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. Therefore, the moments involved are roll and yaw. With increasing altitude (decreasing density) or increasing Mach number, the possibility of a Dutch roll increases. The CG position has little influence on the lateral stability, but an aft CG will reduce the directional stability because the Moment Arm of the stabilizing moment from the fin will decrease and thus increasing the likelihood of a Dutch roll. To reduce the aircraft tendency to Dutch roll, either the lateral stability should be decreased or the directional stability increased => anhedral would decrease the lateral stability. Aircraft with a tendency to Dutch roll are also fitted with yaw damper. This automatically displaces the rudder proportional to the rate of yaw to damp out the oscillation.

But since the thrust is determined by mass, not the volume of air, any increases in its density increases the mass and thus the thrust. VMCA is defined as the minimum speed, whilst in the air, that directional control can be maintained with one engine inoperative (critical engine on two engine aerolanes), operating engine(s) at takeoff power and a maximum of 5 degrees of bank towards the good engine(s). The operative engine requires more rudder authority to maintain directional stability due to the increase in thrust, the airplane maintains directional authority at a higher indicated airspeed. Therefore VMCA increases with increasing air density. V2 speed is always greater than VMCA. Therefore, V2 must also increase.

content.question:
Which of the following configuration characteristics of a Performance Class A turbojet aeroplane are correct, when describing the second segment of the net take-off flight path ?
1. Landing gears are retracted.
2. Maximum continuous thrust is applied on the remaining engine(s).
3. Flaps and slats are extended.
4. The speed for this segment is the best lift-to-drag ratio speed.

key_points: The Class A Net Take-Off Flight Path (NTOFP) may be divided into segments and each segment being defined by a change in configuration, thrust or speed
The loss of an engine at VEF means that the aircraft will not be able to both climb and accelerate and so must level-off to retract the flaps-slats at some stage
The level-off height is sometimes called as "gross level-off height" or "altitude" or "acceleration altitude"
learning.explanation: The Class A Net Take-Off Flight Path (NTOFP) may be divided into segments and each segment being defined by a change in configuration, thrust or speed. The loss of an engine at VEF means that the aircraft will not be able to both climb and accelerate and so must level-off to retract the flaps-slats at some stage. The level-off height is sometimes called as "gross level-off height" or "altitude" or "acceleration altitude". The four conventional segments of the Class A NTOFP are the following: The first segment lasts from the end of the TODR, at which point the aircraft is at 35 ft, to when the gear is up. It is flown at V2 with take-off thrust setting and flaps-slats extended. The second segment lasts from gear retracted to the gross level-off height. It is also flown at V2 with take-off thrust set and flaps-slats extended. The third segment is a level flap retraction segment ending once the aircraft is clean and has accelerated to the final segment climb speed. At the end of the third segment, the thrust is reduced on the remaining engine(s) to the Max Continuous Thrust (MCT). The fourth segment is a climb from the flap retraction height to at least 1500 ft. The speed would be the VX clean.

key_points: An aircraft's speed profile dictates what speeds it is most efficient to fly in the climb, cruise and descent phases of flight

Cost index is a value used by many aircraft manufacturers to provide the operator a way to fly most efficiently, based on their individual fuel costs and other operating costs (crew, aircraft leasing, maintenance, etc
learning.explanation: An aircraft's speed profile dictates what speeds it is most efficient to fly in the climb, cruise and descent phases of flight. Cost index is a value used by many aircraft manufacturers to provide the operator a way to fly most efficiently, based on their individual fuel costs and other operating costs (crew, aircraft leasing, maintenance, etc.). A high cost index is used to make an aircraft fly faster, but burning more fuel, when fuel is less costly and/or the other operating costs are high. A low cost index makes the aircraft fly slower, burning less fuel, when fuel is more expensive and/or the other operating costs are lower. Therefore, an aircraft's speed schedule is proportional to the cost index selected, high cost index, high speed, and vice-versa. The speed below FL100 in many airspace types is maximum 250 kt, so if the optimum speed profile in the climb or descent is higher than this, then it is a limitation, hence why it is written in the speed profile for this question. Also to note is that the aircraft flies a fixed IAS below the crossover altitude, and a fixed Mach number above the crossover altitude. Using a lower cost index will reduce the speeds in the profile (but not the 250kt below FL100, that remains the same), so the only correct option is 250 kt (below FL100) / 280 kt / M.78

content.question: The optimum altitude...

options.A: increases as mass decreases and is the altitude at which the specific range reaches its maximum.
options.B: is the altitude at which the specific range reaches its minimum.
options.C: is the altitude up to which cabin pressure of 8 000 ft can be maintained.

key_points: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed
As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range
The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change
learning.explanation: Optimum Altitude Optimum altitude is defined as the pressure altitude for the best possible fuel efficiency in cruise, at which a given thrust setting results in the corresponding maximum range speed at a given weight and speed. As a result, if flown at a higher or lower pressure altitude than the optimum altitude will decrease the aircraft range. The optimum altitude is not constant and changes over the period of a long flight as atmospheric conditions and the weight of the aircraft change. Optimum altitude increases with reducing aircraft weight: the drag curve will move down and to the left as the weight decreases through fuel burn. Which means that the best range speed (1.32 VMD) decreases (along with the total drag) and, as a consequences, the aircraft needs to slow down to maintain the best range speed. The Mach number will decrease and the aircraft will be able to climb a little since it is not limited by the high Mach number and high drag. The aeroplane maximizes its specific range by remaining at the optimum altitude as it slowly increases (it must climb along the green line shown in the attached figure). As the optimum altitude increases, the specific range increases.

content.question: The ATC clears the crew of a jet aircraft to perform a Continuous Descent Approach (CDA). During the descent, a higher than forecast headwind is experienced, putting the aircraft below the descent profile. What action should be taken by the crew?

options.A: Reduce the rate of descent to regain the descent profile.
options.B: Contact with ATC to inform for the vertical deviation and request new instructions.

key_points: It is generally considered that the optimum descent profile is a continuous or near continuous descent avoiding prolonged periods of operation at low altitude or steps in the descent

While this cannot always be achieved, particularly at busy international airports where you can expect some time in the pattern at low level, it is planned for, as far as it is possible, by managing the kinetic and potential energy of the aircraft, so that it does not end up either too high and fast, or too low and slow
This is called as "Continuous Descent Approach (CDA)"
learning.explanation: It is generally considered that the optimum descent profile is a continuous or near continuous descent avoiding prolonged periods of operation at low altitude or steps in the descent. While this cannot always be achieved, particularly at busy international airports where you can expect some time in the pattern at low level, it is planned for, as far as it is possible, by managing the kinetic and potential energy of the aircraft, so that it does not end up either too high and fast, or too low and slow. This is called as "Continuous Descent Approach (CDA)". The key to obtaining a CDA is to start the descent at the correct place. The Rate of Descent is given by the formulae: ROD = (Power required - Power available) / Weight or (D - T) x TAS / Weight. A stronger headwind would mean that, the groundspeed is lower than expected. A decrease in groundspeed will mean that, it takes longer to travel the horizontal ground distance from Top of Descent to the bottom of the descent. If your rate of descent remains unchanged, the aircraft will arrive at the required level before the bottom of the descent position and, therefore, the rate of descent should be reduced by increasing the thrust. The deployment of the speedbrakes would increase the rate of descent by increasing the drag and may be used for emergency descents (e.g. decompression), where the aircraft must lose altitude as quickly as possible.

content.question: Choose the correct statement with regards to maximum landing mass (MLM).

options.A: Higher OAT decreases MLM because the groundspeed is higher.
options.B: Higher OAT decreases MLM because the CAS is higher.
options.C: Higher QNH increases MLM because the CAS is higher.
options.D: Higher QNH increases MLM because the groundspeed is higher.

key_points: Density altitude is the altitude in an ISA atmosphere where a particular air density would occur
The higher the density altitude, the lower the air density
For take-off and landing, higher density altitude causes low air density, which decreases performance
learning.explanation: Density altitude is the altitude in an ISA atmosphere where a particular air density would occur. The higher the density altitude, the lower the air density. For take-off and landing, higher density altitude causes low air density, which decreases performance. For landing, this comes as a longer landing distance, and a lower gradient of climb after a balked landing (which is a criteria that must be considered as part of the legal performance calculation). A higher density altitude therefore means having a lower maximum landing mass (MLM). Compared to an airfield at sea level, a high field elevation, low pressure system and high temperature decreases the air density. As approaches are made with reference to a constant IAS/CAS, this reduced air density would cause a higher TAS on approach, and means that an aircraft will cross the threshold at a higher groundspeed on landing, and will therefore take a longer distance to decelerate from that higher speed. To combat this, the maximum landing mass is reduced, allowing for a lower approach speed and less energy to slow down during landing. A higher QNH would lead to higher air pressure at the airfield, giving higher air density (lower density altitude) which would lead to a lower groundspeed.

Because the dynamic pressure increases as the density and TAS increase whilst descending at a constant Mach No, which allows for a reduction in AOA to maintain the lift for the same mass (Coefficient of Lift reduces)

options.B: The flight controls may have jammed.
options.C: Ice has built on the elevator preventing full effectiveness.
options.D: Ice being injected by the engine intakes.

key_points: Icing on the wings will disturb the airflow and induce separation, resulting in a lower critical alpha and a higher stall speed
Tailplane icing will reduce lift and CLMAX on the tailplane
The longitudinal static and dynamic stability depends on the effectiveness of the tailplane, so icing will make the aircraft less stable in the longitudinal sense
learning.explanation: Icing on the wings will disturb the airflow and induce separation, resulting in a lower critical alpha and a higher stall speed. Tailplane icing will reduce lift and CLMAX on the tailplane. The longitudinal static and dynamic stability depends on the effectiveness of the tailplane, so icing will make the aircraft less stable in the longitudinal sense. Tailplane icing can also reduce the elevator authority, making a nose-up attitude more difficult and, in the extreme case, icing can cause the horizontal stabiliser to stall completely with potentially catastrophic results. If tailplane stall occurs it will result in an abrupt and/or un-commanded nose down pitching manoeuvre that may be preceded or accompanied by sudden forward control column movement or snatch.

content.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Long Range Cruise (LRC) speed, when compared to the maximum range speed?

options.A: It corresponds to a higher Cost Index (CI).
options.B: It has a higher angle of attack.
options.C: A longer flight time is required to cover a given distance.

key_points: The advantage of flying at the maximum range speed is simply that the airplane will use the least amount of fuel and therefore have the least fuel cost for a given distance
Operationally a faster “long range cruise” is often used
This speed is used because getting to destination more quickly, more revenue earning flights can be carried out for a given period
learning.explanation: The advantage of flying at the maximum range speed is simply that the airplane will use the least amount of fuel and therefore have the least fuel cost for a given distance. Operationally a faster “long range cruise” is often used. This speed is used because getting to destination more quickly, more revenue earning flights can be carried out for a given period. For a given time period, 4% more flights can be carried out with only a per-mile fuel consumption increase of 1%. LRC is NOT more efficient than max range, it is 1% less fuel efficient, mile per mile, so if time were not a factor, maximum range would be best, but as airlines pay a lot of other costs (crew, aircraft usage, maintenance, etc.) per minute of flight time, the extra 4% of speed is quite useful to reduce their other operating costs. These days the speed calculation is mostly a function of the Cost Index, which is a calculation of other operating costs (crew, aircraft lease, maintenance, etc.) divided by the fuel cost. Inputting a high cost index into the aircraft FMC gives a high speed (fuel cheap, other costs expensive, let's get there fast), and a low cost index gives a slow speed (fuel is the most expensive cost, save as much as possible). Without calculating for wind (headwind and tailwind change the aircraft speed schedule for each CI, but are not accounted for in the LRC calculation, which only accounts for weight), a cost index of 0 should be maximum range speed, for highest fuel efficiency. A somewhat higher cost index would give the same speed as LRC, which is faster than max range speed.

options.A: Be possible during the approach, but NOT during a potential go-around.

key_points: VMCL is the minimum control speed during the approach and landing
It covers the situation where an aircraft is making an approach, in trim and with all engines operating, and then has to initiate a go-around at which point one engine fails
The immediate situation is that the live engine is at full go-around power and producing powerful yawing moments before the pilot has had time to re-trim the aircraft for that conditions
learning.explanation: VMCL is the minimum control speed during the approach and landing. It covers the situation where an aircraft is making an approach, in trim and with all engines operating, and then has to initiate a go-around at which point one engine fails. The immediate situation is that the live engine is at full go-around power and producing powerful yawing moments before the pilot has had time to re-trim the aircraft for that conditions. CS 25.149 Minimum control speed (f) (See AMC 25.149 (f)) VMCL, the minimum control speed during approach and landing with all engines operating, is the calibrated airspeed at which, when the critical engine is suddenly made inoperative, it is possible to maintain control of the aeroplane with that engine still inoperative, and maintain straight flight with an angle of bank of not more than 5º. VMCL must be established with – (1) The aeroplane in the most critical configuration (or, at the option of the applicant, each configuration) for approach and landing with all engines operating; (2) The most unfavourable centre of gravity; (3) The aeroplane trimmed for approach with all engines operating; (4) The most unfavourable weight, or, at the option of the applicant, as a function of weight; (5) For propeller aeroplanes, the propeller of the inoperative engine in the position it achieves without pilot action, assuming the engine fails while at the power or thrust necessary to maintain a 3 degree approach path angle; and (6) Go-around power or thrust setting on the operating engine(s).

content.question: A jet aeroplane is climbing at a constant IAS and maximum climb thrust, how will the climb angle / the pitch angle change?

key_points: The balance of forces in a steady climb shows that thrust is acting upwards and an element of weight is adding to the drag
As thrust assists the lift, the lift required is less than in level flight
For a steady speed to be maintained, the trhust and the two retarding effects of aerodynamic drag and the weight element must be equal: T = D + W Sin Climb Angle
learning.explanation: The balance of forces in a steady climb shows that thrust is acting upwards and an element of weight is adding to the drag. As thrust assists the lift, the lift required is less than in level flight. For a steady speed to be maintained, the trhust and the two retarding effects of aerodynamic drag and the weight element must be equal: T = D + W Sin Climb Angle. The formula transported for climb angle, becomes: Sin Climb Angle = (T - D) / W or Sin Climb Angle = Excess Thrust / Weight. As altitudes increases during climb, thrust available decreases, thus excess thrust decreases. As a result from the above formula, the Climb angle decreases, too. Also, during climb, to maintain the IAS constant with the maximum climb thrust power setting, while the available thrust decreases progressively, the nose attitude must be lowered. i.e. the pitch angle must be decreased, in order to reduce the angle of attack and drag.

content.question: After commencing the descent, the pilot of a jet aircraft is instructed by the ATC to keep the speed high and issues an altitude restriction up to FL120 at a waypoint 50 NM before the planned position. The pilot realizes that he/she will not be able to meet the restriction with the current rate of descent. What action(s) should he/she do?

options.A: Decrease the rate of descent while increasing IAS to below VMO and keep this speed until reaching FL120. If needed, deploy speed brakes to remain on the descent profile.
options.B: Increase the rate of descent while increasing MACH speed to below MMO and keep this speed until reaching FL120. If needed, deploy speed brakes to remain on the descent profile.
options.C: Increase the rate of descent while increasing MACH speed to below MMO until the crossover altitude, after which continues with an IAS below Vmo. If needed, deploy speed brakes to remain on the descent profile.
options.D: Decrease the rate of descent and keep the calculated descent speed. If needed, deploy speed brakes to remain on the descent profile.

key_points: The Rate of Descent (ROD) depends on the descent angle and the True Airspeed according to the formula: ROD = Sin Descent angle x TAS
The most shallow descent angle will be at or very near to VMD, where the ratio CD/CL is at its minimum
As the speed increases above VMD, the descent angle will become steeper, the TAS will increase and the ROD will increase, too
learning.explanation: The Rate of Descent (ROD) depends on the descent angle and the True Airspeed according to the formula: ROD = Sin Descent angle x TAS. The most shallow descent angle will be at or very near to VMD, where the ratio CD/CL is at its minimum. As the speed increases above VMD, the descent angle will become steeper, the TAS will increase and the ROD will increase, too. The correct path, which permits a steep descent and a prior to the scheduled bottom of descent (50 NM), would be to hold a Mach number, just under MMO to the crossover altitude, then switch over to a constant IAS, just below VMO with a reducing Mach number for the remainder down to FL120. Also, the Rate of Descent is given by the formulae: ROD = (Power required - Power available) / Weight or (D - T) x TAS / Weight. The deployment of the speedbrakes would increase the drag more, thus the rate of descent would increase as well, steepening the descent, if it is required to do so as to remain on the descent profile.

content.question: The standard climb speeds for a Medium Range Jet Transport are 250 kts below 10 000 ft and subsequently 300 kts/0.80M. Choose the speed profiles you may expect if you entered a lower than usual Cost Index into the FMC:

key_points: The Cost Index (CI) is calculated as the ratio of time costs to fuel costs: Cost Index = Time costs/Fuel costs The lower the CI, the more "importance" the machinery places on saving fuel
Low cost indexes will result in lower climb speed, (both indicated and mach), lower cruise speed, a generally higher cruise altitude, a later descent and a slower descent mach/speed
The higher CI's will result in the opposite
learning.explanation: The Cost Index (CI) is calculated as the ratio of time costs to fuel costs: Cost Index = Time costs/Fuel costs The lower the CI, the more "importance" the machinery places on saving fuel. Low cost indexes will result in lower climb speed, (both indicated and mach), lower cruise speed, a generally higher cruise altitude, a later descent and a slower descent mach/speed. The higher CI's will result in the opposite. In this case: The first speed 250 kt below 10 000 ft is an ATC restriction, therefore it must remain unchanged. metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: The crew of a jet aircraft, approaching to the destination airport, is informed that a holding procedure is expected, because of high traffic. What action should be taken by the crew to increase the maximum endurance?

options.A: Cruise with VMD in order to minimise the fuel flow.
options.B: Cruise with VMAX RANGE in order to increase the fuel mileage.
options.C: Climb to the optimum altitude in order to increase specific range.
options.D: Request a continuous descent in order to reduce the thrust setting.

key_points: Maximum Endurance is the maximum flight time that an aircraft can remain airborne burning the available fuel
This depends entirely on the fuel flow, which is a product of the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC), and Drag
SFC is the ratio of fuel mass consumed to produce a unit of thrust per unit of time
learning.explanation: Maximum Endurance is the maximum flight time that an aircraft can remain airborne burning the available fuel. This depends entirely on the fuel flow, which is a product of the Specific Fuel Consumption (SFC), and Drag. SFC is the ratio of fuel mass consumed to produce a unit of thrust per unit of time. The lower the SFC, the better. The maximum (optimum) endurance will be increased, if flying at a speed where the minimum drag is produced, at VMD, where the SFC is at its lowest. On a holding procedure, the crew’s major concern is the endurance and not the range. Thus, during holding, it is recommended to reduce the cruise speed and maintain a holding speed equal to the VMD.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: An aeroplane is descending from FL390 to ground level at maximum speed. The limit(s) in speed is (are)…

options.A: MMO only during all the descent.
options.B: VMO only during all the descent.
options.C: initially MMO, then VMO below a given flight level.
options.D: initially VMO, then MMO below a given flight level.

key_points: In cruise, and generally at higher levels, for the same VMO, the TAS and Mach number increase due to the decrease in density
Therefore, at high levels, it is very unlikely that you reach the VMO
But let’s suppose you’re trying to reach the VMO (just to illustrate this relationship)
learning.explanation: In cruise, and generally at higher levels, for the same VMO, the TAS and Mach number increase due to the decrease in density. Therefore, at high levels, it is very unlikely that you reach the VMO. But let’s suppose you’re trying to reach the VMO (just to illustrate this relationship). By accelerating to reach the VMO, which is an IAS, your TAS and your Mach number will increase, and you will most likely reach your MMO before the VMO. In the same way, at low levels close to the ground, the IAS and the TAS are very close because of the higher density, therefore the VMO becomes the limiting speed. To reach the MMO at a low level, you will need to drastically increase your TAS, which is impossible as you will reach the VMO and damage your structure way before.

content.question: Compared to your previous approach to the aerodrome, the runway condition has changed from WET to slush (depth 6mm). Assuming an approach to the same runway with the same aircraft mass, and with the same wind direction and speed, you should expect the quality of the braking action to (1) _____ and your landing distance to (2) _____.

key_points: An aircraft's landing performance (how quickly the aircraft stops) is primarily linked to the braking of the aircraft
Aerodynamic drag and reversers can contribute some deceleration, but braking is by far the most important factor on the majority of landings
The runway condition has a large influence on an aircraft's traction, and therefore its braking performance
learning.explanation: An aircraft's landing performance (how quickly the aircraft stops) is primarily linked to the braking of the aircraft. Aerodynamic drag and reversers can contribute some deceleration, but braking is by far the most important factor on the majority of landings. The runway condition has a large influence on an aircraft's traction, and therefore its braking performance. A dry runway will give the best possible traction, and therefore the best braking, but a wet runway will reduce the maximum braking available, due to hydroplaning and loss of tyre-to-surface contact. Usually worse than a wet runway is a contaminated runway, which is a runway that is more than 25% covered in contaminants greater than 3mm deep, such as water, snow, slush, ice, etc. In this case, going from a wet runway to a runway covered with 6mm deep slush will cause a massive reduction in braking action, and therefore a large increase in landing distance.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Occasional movements by aircraft with an ACN of 50 should not adversely affect the pavement if the reported PCN is at least:

key_points: Aircraft Classification Number (ACN) is a value assigned to an airplane to show its load force
Operation on the pavement is permissible if the ACN is less than or equal to the pavement classification number (PCN) of an aerodrome

Because the PCN includes a safety factor, a 10% increase of ACN over PCN is generally acceptable for pavements that are in good condition and occasional use by aircraft with ACNs up to 50% greater than the PCN may be permitted
learning.explanation: Aircraft Classification Number (ACN) is a value assigned to an airplane to show its load force. Operation on the pavement is permissible if the ACN is less than or equal to the pavement classification number (PCN) of an aerodrome. Because the PCN includes a safety factor, a 10% increase of ACN over PCN is generally acceptable for pavements that are in good condition and occasional use by aircraft with ACNs up to 50% greater than the PCN may be permitted. In such circumstances the movement of the aircraft must be very closely monitored for damage to the aircraft and pavement. The first part is the PCN numerical value, indicating the load-carrying capacity of the pavement. This is always reported as a whole number, rounded from the determined capacity. The only letter that you need to interpret is the first letter of the second part: The second part is a letter: either an R or an F, depending on whether the pavement itself is of a rigid (most typically concrete) or a flexible (most typically asphalt) design. Solution: The exercise is asking the minimum usable PCN, considering an allowable 10% increase; 47 x 1.1 = 51.7 > ACN 50 Annex 14 — Aerodromes (ATT A-28) 19. The aircraft classification number-pavement classification number (ACN-PCN) method of reporting pavement strength 19.1 Overload operations 19.1.1 Overloading of pavements can result either from loads too large, or from a substantially increased application rate, or both. Loads larger than the defined (design or evaluation) load shorten the design life, whilst smaller loads extend it. With the exception of massive overloading, pavements in their structural behaviour are not subject to a particular limiting load above which they suddenly or catastrophically fail. Behaviour is such that a pavement can sustain a definable load for an expected number of repetitions during its design life. As a result, occasional minor overloading is acceptable, when expedient, with only limited loss in pavement life expectancy and relatively small acceleration of pavement deterioration. For those operations in which magnitude of overload and/or the frequency of use do not justify a detailed analysis, the following criteria are suggested: a) for flexible pavements, occasional movements by aircraft with ACN not exceeding 10 per cent above the reported PCN should not adversely affect the pavement; b) for rigid or composite pavements, in which a rigid pavement layer provides a primary element of the structure, occasional movements by aircraft with ACN not exceeding 5 per cent above the reported PCN should not adversely affect the pavement; c) if the pavement structure is unknown, the 5 per cent limitation should apply; and d) the annual number of overload movements should not exceed approximately 5 per cent of the total annual aircraft movements. 19.1.2 Such overload movements should not normally be permitted on pavements exhibiting signs of distress or failure. Furthermore, overloading should be avoided during any periods of thaw following frost penetration, or when the strength of the pavement or its subgrade could be weakened by water. Where overload operations are conducted, the appropriate authority should review the relevant pavement condition regularly, and should also review the criteria for overload operations periodically since excessive repetition of overloads can cause severe shortening of pavement life or require major rehabilitation of pavement.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: A jet aircraft is experiencing buffet whilst flying at its aerodynamic ceiling (coffin corner). What is the recommended recovery for this?

options.A: Maintain current thrust setting and descend. Increasing TAS is acceptable, but a decreased TAS will cause a stall.
options.B: Reduce thrust, maintain IAS and descent. Any increase or decrease in IAS could increase the buffet.
options.C: Reduce thrust, maintain current TAS and descend. Either increasing or decreasing TAS could cause high-speed or low-speed buffet.
options.D: Maintain thrust and commence a turn at a 30º bank angle. The drag increase will cause a descent without significantly affecting the manoeuvre margins.

key_points: Buffet Margin / Aerodynamic Ceiling An altitude can be reached where there is only one speed at which the aircraft can fly
In the case of a 1g manoeuvring (i
e
learning.explanation: Buffet Margin / Aerodynamic Ceiling An altitude can be reached where there is only one speed at which the aircraft can fly. In the case of a 1g manoeuvring (i.e. straight level flight), this altitude is called the ‘Aerodynamic Ceiling’. Operating an aircraft at its aerodynamic ceiling would leave no safety margin. In 1g flight the aircraft would be constantly on the point of both low speed stall and high speed buffet/shock stall. Regulations require an aircraft to be operated with a minimum buffet margin of 0.3g. This is called "coffin corner", and the way to escape it is just to descend. As the aircraft descends, the stalling IAS decreases (that is a compressibility effect of high TAS at high altitude only). The high speed buffet is based on Mach No., and therefore descending at a constant Mach No. would keep you at the high speed buffet boundary, however descending at a constant IAS/CAS would mean the aircraft's Mach No. decreases (see ECTM graph above), increasing the margin from high speed buffet. Therefore, reducing thrust and descending at a constant IAS will increase the margin from both the low speed buffet and the high speed buffet simultaneously. Looking a bit closer, descending at a constant TAS would also increase both low and (sometimes) high speed buffet margins (dependent on the atmospheric conditions - i.e. not an inversion or isothermal layer), but we never fly to a constant TAS, and it would not be recommended to do so in this case either. Therefore, constant TAS is not correct (also it doesn't work above the tropopause where this is most likely to happen, anyway).

content.question: How does TAS vary in a constant Mach number climb in the troposphere (under ISA conditions)?

options.D: TAS is not related to Mach number.

key_points: Descent at a Constant Mach Number in Standard Conditions During a descent, LSS will be increasing, as temperature increases
Therefore, if Mach number is being kept constant the TAS must be increasing (Mach number = TAS/LSS)
During the descent air density increases TAS is increasing and CAS also increases at a greater rate (Dynamic Pressure = 1⁄2 ρ V2)
learning.explanation: Descent at a Constant Mach Number in Standard Conditions During a descent, LSS will be increasing, as temperature increases. Therefore, if Mach number is being kept constant the TAS must be increasing (Mach number = TAS/LSS). During the descent air density increases TAS is increasing and CAS also increases at a greater rate (Dynamic Pressure = 1⁄2 ρ V2). Similarly, in a climb at constant Mach number the TAS and CAS both reduce.

options.C: the increased airspeed may lead to over&rotation.
options.D: V1 may be too high resulting in the initial climb performance decreasing.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: Which of the following statements best describes the effect of altitude on the high and low speed buffet margins?

options.A: An increase in altitude leads to an increase in the low speed buffet margin and a decrease in the high speed buffet margin.
options.B: An increase in altitude leads to a decrease in the low speed and high speed buffet margins.
options.C: A decrease in altitude leads to an increase in the low speed buffet margin and a decrease in the high speed buffet margin.
options.D: A decrease in altitude leads to a decrease in the low speed and high speed buffet margins.

key_points: The ‘buffet boundary’ is the speed range between the high-speed buffet and the low-speed buffet, which decreases with increased altitude
The separation of the cruising speed from the buffet-onset speed is called the ‘buffet margin
’ There is a low-speed margin and a high-speed margin
learning.explanation: The ‘buffet boundary’ is the speed range between the high-speed buffet and the low-speed buffet, which decreases with increased altitude. The separation of the cruising speed from the buffet-onset speed is called the ‘buffet margin.’ There is a low-speed margin and a high-speed margin. As the aircraft climbs higher, the low speed buffet boundary increases, as the IAS for a given Mach number decreases, and the IAS stall speed increases due to compressibility effects at high true air speeds. The high speed buffet boundary (shock stall) either stays the same (in terms of Mach Number) or decreases slightly. This means that, with increasing altitude, the two get closer together, and form what is called Coffin Corner up at high altitudes, where only a small speed range is safe to fly within. This means that an increase in altitude leads to a decrease in both low and high speed buffet margins, as the buffet speeds get closer to the aircraft's cruising speed. Remember that this question is talking about buffet margins, not the actual speed that the buffet occurs at.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: A new aircraft variant with enhanced speed capability (IAS 250 kt Mach 0.78) has replaced an older variant of the same aircraft type (IAS 250 kt Mach 0.75). What change has occurred?

key_points: A large aircraft's maximum speed is measured in two different ways, its maximum IAS (indicated airspeed) and its maximum Mach No
At lower altitudes (up to the crossover altitude), the speed is limited by IAS, a structural consideration due to the aerodynamic forces
At higher altitudes above the crossover altitude, the maximum speed is limited by the Mach No
learning.explanation: A large aircraft's maximum speed is measured in two different ways, its maximum IAS (indicated airspeed) and its maximum Mach No. At lower altitudes (up to the crossover altitude), the speed is limited by IAS, a structural consideration due to the aerodynamic forces. At higher altitudes above the crossover altitude, the maximum speed is limited by the Mach No., which is an aerodynamic consideration based on the transonic speed regime, Mach effects, shock stalls, etc. The maximum IAS is called the VMO and the maximum Mach No. is called the MMO. In the question, we can see that the VMO of 250 kt has not changed with the new aircraft variant, but the MMO of M0.75 has increased to M0.78. This will allow the aircraft to fly faster at higher altitudes, but not at lower altitudes. It will also increase the height of the crossover altitude for maximum speed.

metadata.topic: 25/Applicable Operational Requirements Performance Class A – Theory

content.question: What possible hazards should be considered when using the increased V2 procedure to allow a higher RTOM (Regulated Take-Off Mass)?

options.B: The climb gradient will be worse than when using a normal V2 speed.
options.C: The thrust setting will be less than maximum, which will result in a reduced climb gradient.
options.D: Maximum tyre speed and VMBE will have to be re-checked due to increased V1, VR and V2.

key_points: Learning Objective 032
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 032.04.01.14.03: Explain the hazards of the fast V1 and VLOF speeds associated with the increased V2 procedure and how they can be managed. The increased V2 procedure exists because V2, the take-off safety speed, is actually very slow, and an aircraft can get much better climb performance by climbing at a higher speed, closer to VMD. Therefore, if the conditions exist where the aircraft can safely use a faster V2, then the climb performance can be drastically improved in the event of an engine failure, and the obstacle/climb limited take-off masses can be increased. This would only be used when a runway is longer than required. A very long runway would allow lots of safety margin in terms of field length, which we can use up, to give us higher climb out speed and climb performance after take-off. This is particularly useful if obstacle clearance after departure is an issue at an airport. So in summary, this is a technique most often used on long runways with high terrain nearby. The increased V2 procedure will increase V1 and VR also, and the aircraft will remain on the ground, accelerating for a longer time. The increased speeds might mean that either V1 or VR could reach their upper limits, which are hazards that must be considered and checked to remain within limits. An upper limit of V1 is the VMBE speed, the speed for maximum brake energy. Above VMBE, it is not assured that the aircraft brakes will be able to absorb all the aircraft's kinetic energy in the event of a rejected take-off, so V1 can never be over VMBE, as the highest speed a stop could commence. An upper limit of VR is the maximum tyre speed (VMAX TYRE). VR is the speed when rotation begins, and must be made so that VLOF (lift-off speed) never exceeds the VMAX TYRE, as the tyres may overspeed otherwise, and cause issues such as blowouts. VR is not directly limited by VMAX TYRE, but VR dictates VLOF which is directly limited by the maximum tyre speed.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
A pilot is considering the possibility of having to land on a flooded runway and is evaluating the aircraft configuration and the selection of the landing speeds. Given the following information, choose the lowest possible flap setting that would avoid dynamic hydroplaning on landing.
Landing Mass: 45 000 kg
Tyre pressure: 200 psi

key_points: Dynamic hydroplanning is a phenomenon at which a certain speed has been reached where the bow wave built up in front of the wheel, by the slush and water, disappears, wheel rotation slows or stops and the tyre slithers or planes on a layer of contaminant

The point at which the aircraft starts to plane is called "Hydroplaning Speed" or "Aquaplaning Speed" (Vp or Vρ) and it can be approximated from the following formulae: Vp (KT) = 9 √P, for a rotating wheel, i
e
learning.explanation: Dynamic hydroplanning is a phenomenon at which a certain speed has been reached where the bow wave built up in front of the wheel, by the slush and water, disappears, wheel rotation slows or stops and the tyre slithers or planes on a layer of contaminant. The point at which the aircraft starts to plane is called "Hydroplaning Speed" or "Aquaplaning Speed" (Vp or Vρ) and it can be approximated from the following formulae: Vp (KT) = 9 √P, for a rotating wheel, i.e. on take-off Vp (KT) = 7.7 √P, for a non-rotating wheel, i.e. on landing, where P the tyre pressure in PSI. The flap setting that would avoid dynamic hydroplaning on landing is that, which allows a landing VREF less than the Hydroplaning Speed to by followed. For this question, the Hydroplaning speed is: Vp = 7.7 x √200 = 109 kt. Thus, the flap settings that can be selected and allow a VREF less than 109 kt to avoid hydroplaning on landing are: Flaps 40 and 30. And the lowest possible one is Flaps 30.

Wing Anti-ice: OFF
A/C: AUTO (HIGH)

key_points: This graph shows the level-off altitude of an aircraft with 1 engine inoperative, dependent on the mass of the aircraft
We are told in the question that the MSA (Minimum Safe Altitude) is 12 100 ft

learning.explanation: This graph shows the level-off altitude of an aircraft with 1 engine inoperative, dependent on the mass of the aircraft. We are told in the question that the MSA (Minimum Safe Altitude) is 12 100 ft. Therefore, enter the graph on the right at 12 100 ft, go across to the interpolated position of ISA +14ºC, just to the right of the "+15ºC" line, as that is our ISA deviation. Below 17 000 ft level-off altitude, the A/C is assumed to be off, however, this aircraft has the A/C on AUTO (HIGH), which requires a mass reduction, to achieve the same level-off altitude. The mass reduction is (-) 2 500 kg. 61000 - 2500 = 58 500 kg, closest answer 58 400 kg. If the aircraft were any heavier, it would not be able to maintain the MSA with one engine inoperative.

content.question:

OAT: ISA +20ºC

A/C: Auto (High)

key_points: If an engine fails in the cruise, then the remaining engine is set to Maximum Continuous Thrust (MCT), in an attempt to maintain height

At cruise altitudes above the operating altitude for one-engine-inoperative, the attempt to maintain height usually fails, because of inadequate thrust on the remaining engine and the aircraft will descend down to a height at which it is able to stabilise
This is called "driftdown" and it is a "power on" descent
learning.explanation: If an engine fails in the cruise, then the remaining engine is set to Maximum Continuous Thrust (MCT), in an attempt to maintain height. At cruise altitudes above the operating altitude for one-engine-inoperative, the attempt to maintain height usually fails, because of inadequate thrust on the remaining engine and the aircraft will descend down to a height at which it is able to stabilise. This is called "driftdown" and it is a "power on" descent. The Figure 4.24 helps to find the flight time travelled, the ground distance covered and the fuel burned during the driftdown, with the following manner: No mass correction is required for the bleed configuration or for A/C at Auto mode. From the upper-right corner section of the table, correct the Gross Mass at engine failure for ISA +20ºC to get the equivalent Gross Mass at engine failure. Enter with 50 000 kg, follow the gridlines to the right hand side until ISA +20ºC to find 53 000 kg. From the graph below, enter with the pressure altitude 21 000 ft and move horizontally until crossing the hypothetical 53 000 kg equivalent Gross Mass at engine failure curve to get the fuel burned during the driftdown, 800 kg. Proceed vertically down to read the flight time during the driftdown, 27 minutes and continue until the wind reference line. Follow the gridlines until the 50 kt headwind component. Continue vertically down to read the Ground distance covered during the driftdown, 126 NM, which is close to 124 NM.

content.question:
Refer to figure or CAP698 file 4.31.
The crew of an aircraft is planning a landing onto runway 24 with the following information in order to calculate their minimum turn-around time according to the brake cooling schedule. Assuming taxi distance is negligible, what will be the minimum turn-around time?
Landing mass: 50 000 kg
VREF: 128 kt
Wind: 060°/4 kt (use 50% of headwind component or 150% of tailwind component as applicable)
Airport elevation: 1 000 ft
QNH: 1013 hPa
OAT: +25°C

options.A: 1-2 minutes, using NO reverse with autobrake #1 or #2.
options.B: 72 minutes, using reverse #2 detent with autobrake #1 or #2.
options.C: 17 minutes, using NO reverse with autobrake #1 or #2.
options.D: 17 minutes, using reverse #2 detent with autobrake #1 or #2

key_points: The figure shown is that of the minimum turnaround time/brake cooling schedule
After any significant braking, due to landing or a rejected take-off, the aircraft brakes will be hot, and may need some time to cool down before being usable again
We use this graph to calculate the brake energy, and required cooling
learning.explanation: The figure shown is that of the minimum turnaround time/brake cooling schedule. After any significant braking, due to landing or a rejected take-off, the aircraft brakes will be hot, and may need some time to cool down before being usable again. We use this graph to calculate the brake energy, and required cooling. Entering the graph near the top on the left with 50 000 kg landing weight (in the "Landing Mass" section, not RTO mass), go across until the point referencing the relevant brakes on speed. Now in this question we only know the VREF, which is the speed over the threshold, and we add 150% of the 4 kt tailwind, so 6 kt, to this speed. This means we can assume our brakes on speed is 128 + 6 = 134 kt. Of course there will be some deceleration in the flare, but the question will specify an amount to reduce the VREF by if they want you to do so, so we can leave it in this question. Going across to the interpolated position of 134 kt, then directly down to the pressure altitude section. As the QNH is exactly standard pressure setting (1013 hPa), no pressure correction is required, and we can use 1 000 ft pressure altitude, moving the line slightly to the right. Going down to the OAT section, account for the temperature being 25ºC, the line goes to the right again. Then head down to the reference line for the autobrake/reversers section. The level of reverse thrust is shown on the right hand side (either "no reverse" or "normal reverse #2 detent" can be used). For each of these options, there is a line each the autobrake selection, going downwards; Autobrake Max, #3, #1 and #2. Using the line from above, evaluate each option to find which scenario matches to the correct cooling time. In this case, it is 17 minutes cooling time, using normal reverse #2 detent with autobrake #1 or #2.

We end up with Column B. The table appropriate to flaps 15º is in Figure 4.9. Enter the V-speed tables at Column B and at the actual take-off mass of 62 800 kg. We can interpolate between 60 and 65 000 kg. 2800/5000 = 0.56, so 56% of the way from 60 000 kg to 65 000 kg. V1: Difference is 7 kt; 7 x 0.56 = 3.92; round to 4, 138 + 4 = 142 kt VR: Difference is 6 kt; 6 x 0.56 = 3.36; round to 3, 140 + 3 = 143 kt V2: Difference is 5 kt; 5 x 0.56 = 2.8; round to 3; 146 + 3 = 149 kt Correct V1 for slope and/or wind component by entering the table at the top of the page: At this weight, -2 kt for each 2% downslope, so for 0.8%, the closest whole number correction is -1 kt The wind correction is -3 kt for every 15 kt tailwind, so a 5 kt tailwind component gives a further correction of -1 kt Therefore, the V-speeds are V1 = 140 kt, VR = 143 kt and V2 = 149 kt.

content.question:
Refer to figure or CAP 698 figure 4.23.
Given the following information:
Mass: 43 500 kg
OAT: ISA +10°C
Engine anti-ice: ON
Wing anti-ice: OFF
A/C: Auto (High)
Airport 1 pressure altitude: 24 000 ft
Airport 2 pressure altitude: 23 000 ft
Airport 3 pressure altitude: 20 000 ft
Airport 4 pressure altitude: 19 500 ft
Which two airports are the most appropriate for a pilot to choose for an approach and landing?

key_points: The premise of this question is that an aircraft is 1 engine inoperative and trying to find a suitable airport to land at

It does not mention this in the question, but the figure attached is the 1 engine inoperative level off graph, and the question asks about which airports are appropriate for landing, so it can be deduced
Of course, when we are looking for a place to make an emergency landing, we want to be able to fly level, and hopefully, have somewhat of a hope at making a go-around
learning.explanation: The premise of this question is that an aircraft is 1 engine inoperative and trying to find a suitable airport to land at. It does not mention this in the question, but the figure attached is the 1 engine inoperative level off graph, and the question asks about which airports are appropriate for landing, so it can be deduced. Of course, when we are looking for a place to make an emergency landing, we want to be able to fly level, and hopefully, have somewhat of a hope at making a go-around. We therefore need to be below the one engine inoperative level off altitude, as the lower we are, the higher the climb performance, and above the level off altitude, we cannot even maintain altitude. Already, we can see that the two lowest airports will be the correct answers, 3 and 4. If you really want to use the graph, then we have to use it backwards, to go from our weight to the level off altitude. We therefore have to apply the corrections first, and have to reverse their direction, so a negative correction is actually an addition to weight. The only addition we need to make is for engine anti-ice ON, which is an extra 1950 kg, making the mass 45 450 kg to enter the graph (just by looking at where the line will go, we can tell that we do not have to apply the correction for A/C AUTO (HIGH) under 17 000 ft. Entering the graph at 45 450 kg at the bottom, going up to the line for ISA +10°C and below, and going to the left gives us 21 900 ft as our level off altitude. This means that Airport 3 and Airport 4 are below our maximum altitude with one engine inoperative, so are usable, but Airport 1 and Airport 2 are above the climb ceiling, so are much less appropriate for a single engine landing.

content.question:
Refer to figure or to CAP 698 figure 4.31.
An MRJT (Medium Range Jet Transport) aircraft is performing circuits as part of pilot training. So far, 17.6 Million foot-pounds of energy have been absorbed by the brakes, and the pilots now want to make a final landing without any reverse thrust, which shall add a further 10 Million foot-pounds of energy. Which of the following is the best procedure to follow?

options.A: Land, then cool the brakes for no more than 80 minutes before the next take-off.
options.B: Fly around with the gear up for 30 minutes, then land.
options.C: Land as soon as required, there is no brake cooling requirement.
options.D: Fly around with the gear down for 6 minutes, then land. Park the aircraft for at least 60 minutes.

key_points: Note: This question has been reported a couple of times with varying levels of feedback
Different values of brake energy have been seen on some counts of feedback, but so far this is the most reliable version of this question we can make

Please don't hesitate to let us know if you saw any differences in the real exam, thank you! This scenario can happen during the base training for new pilots to gain a type rating on a jet aircraft, where multiple circuits are performed
learning.explanation: Note: This question has been reported a couple of times with varying levels of feedback. Different values of brake energy have been seen on some counts of feedback, but so far this is the most reliable version of this question we can make. Please don't hesitate to let us know if you saw any differences in the real exam, thank you! This scenario can happen during the base training for new pilots to gain a type rating on a jet aircraft, where multiple circuits are performed. Brake usage due to touch and goes, stop and goes, and taxiing can lead to high temperatures. In this case, the pilots want to perform a final landing without reverse thrust, which requires a lot of energy to be absorbed through the brakes. Looking at the brake cooling schedule on figure 4.31 of CAP 698, the 17.6 Million foot-pounds of brake energy already accumulated is within region II, where cooling is recommended, and if another 10 Million foot-pounds are added, the energy is well within region IV, where the fuse plugs are expected to melt. This is therefore very undesirable so the pilots should cool the brakes in the air, by leaving the gear down for the 6 minutes required by the cooling schedule. This should bring the brake energy down to approximately 8 Million foot-pounds remaining, the bottom of region II, and then the aircraft can land safely without reverse thrust, which should bring the total energy back up to around 18 Million foot-pounds, still within region II. As the aircraft remains in Area II after landing, there is a requirement to cool the brakes for about 60 minutes on the ground before another take-off. To look at the other options: Landing now is likely to cause a fuse plug melt, and cooling would have to be greater than 85 minutes after landing anyway. Flying around with the gear up can cool the brakes, but 60 minutes would be required to cool the brakes sufficiently. Again, landing immediately is likely to cause a fuse plug melt, and a possible brake fire.

key_points: A Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) table is a simplified form of table to use and is produced for a specific aircraft type on a particular runway and shows MTOM and speeds for a variety of temperatures and pressure altitudes, sometimes giving different configuration options
First of all, the wind direction 050o is exactly opposite to the runway 05L, so the wind speed of 16 kt is a headwind
The questions asks to take the most conservative data and not interpolate, so, enter the RTOW table from the "+ 10 kt" column
learning.explanation: A Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) table is a simplified form of table to use and is produced for a specific aircraft type on a particular runway and shows MTOM and speeds for a variety of temperatures and pressure altitudes, sometimes giving different configuration options. First of all, the wind direction 050o is exactly opposite to the runway 05L, so the wind speed of 16 kt is a headwind. The questions asks to take the most conservative data and not interpolate, so, enter the RTOW table from the "+ 10 kt" column. In each box, the Maximum Take-off Mass is at top left. Move vertically down through the "+10 kt" column, until you reach at MTOM just over the Actual TOM given, 71 480 kg. We find this at 71.8 tonnes, which corresponds to an OAT of 59°C. In the same box, the numbers "38-38-43" correspond to the speeds: V1 (138 kt), VR (138 kt) and V2 (143 kt), accordingly. Then we must apply any corrections as necessary. The QNH is 5 hPa lower than standard (1013), so we must apply one whole correction for "QNH (per -10 hPa)" as no interpolation is allowed. The weight correction of -80kg only takes the RTOW for that assumed temperature down to 71 720 kg, which is still higher than 71 480 kg, so it is acceptable. There is no change to the assumed/flex temperature for this correction. Apply the correction: +1 kt only to the V2 speed, giving a V2 of 144 kt Thus, the appropriate assumed/FLEX temperature is 59°C and the associated take-off speeds are: V1 = 138 kt, VR = 138 kt, V2 = 144 kt.

Track horizontally to the left until you intersect your first line. The result is in excess of 68 000 kg. Note: V1 exceeds VMBE, therefore a correction should be applied. learning.explanation: A Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) table is a simplified form of table to use and is produced for a specific aircraft type on a particular runway and shows MTOM and speeds for a variety of temperatures and pressure altitudes, sometimes giving different configuration options. There is no row for -3°C, so interpolate between -7°C and +3°C rows. Entering from the top with CONF 1+F/ HEADWIND 10 KT, the corresponding Performance-Limited TOMs are: 83 300 kg (83.3) for -7°C and 82 800 kg (82.8) for +3°C, decreases 50 kg for each 1°C increase. Thus, the Performance-Limited TOM for -3°C is: 83 300 kg - (4°C x 50 kg) = 83 100 kg. Apply the correction for the QNH difference (1013 hPa - 999 hPa = 14 hPa) to the Performance-Limited TOM: The weight must be reduced by 800 kg (-0.8) for every 10 hPa lower than 1013 hPa, so for 14 hPa lower, the weight reduction must be 1 120 kg (800 kg x 1.4). No corrections for Air conditioning and runway condition are required. Therefore, the Performance-Limited TOM at -3°C will be: 83 100 kg - 1 120 kg = 81980 kg, which is very close to 82 000 kg. NOTE: The interpretation of the data provided by the the "INFLUENCE" boxes, is depicted at the bottom left corner box "LABEL FOR INFLUENCE".

key_points: VMBE is the maximum brake energy speed
It is the speed which an aircraft can safely stop from, without overloading the brakes with energy

The brakes take the vast majority of an aircraft's kinetic energy in as heat, so will have a limit on the temperature they can withstand, which equates to a maximum energy they can stop, before overheating and causing effects like brake fade, brake fires and melting thermal fuses
learning.explanation: VMBE is the maximum brake energy speed. It is the speed which an aircraft can safely stop from, without overloading the brakes with energy. The brakes take the vast majority of an aircraft's kinetic energy in as heat, so will have a limit on the temperature they can withstand, which equates to a maximum energy they can stop, before overheating and causing effects like brake fade, brake fires and melting thermal fuses. VMBE obviously varies a lot on weight, and the heavier an aircraft is, the more kinetic energy it has at the same speed, so the lower the VMBE. It is an upper limit of V1, the take-off decision speed. For this question, they have given us the conditions, and are asking at what point VMBE will begin to limit the MTOM. Effectively, we want to find the weight at which the VMBE becomes equal to (or below) the V1 in the question. Firstly though, we have to make a couple of corrections for wind and slope. Usually, a pilot would take the uncorrected VMBE using the graph, then apply corrections to it to get the actual VMBE to compare against the V1. We are going to go the other way, taking the V1 and reversing those corrections to get an uncorrected VMBE which we can enter the graph with. With 0.5% upslope, the VMBE would increase by 1 kt, and with 10 kt headwind, the VMBE would increase by a further 3 kt, so we are going to take 4 kts away from our V1 to get our uncorrected VMBE. 149 - 4 = 145 kt (uncorrected VMBE which can be used in the graph) Entering the graph from the top left with the pressure altitude of 111 ft (QNH = 1013 hPa so no pressure correction) and going down at the OAT of 41ºC gives us a vertical line, which we can match up with a horizontal line from 145 kt at the bottom right of the graph. It shows us that the MTOM where the VMBE becomes limiting is much higher than the 68 000 kg shown on the chart. Therefore, the answer is "In excess of 68 000 kg".

QNH: 1003 hPa
Runway: WET
Engine anti-ice: OFF
Packs: OFF
Take off mass: 67050 kg
Assumed/Flex T°: 63°C

key_points: A Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) table is a simplified form of table to use and is produced for a specific aircraft type on a particular runway and shows MTOM and speeds for a variety of temperatures and pressure altitudes, sometimes giving different configuration options
First of all, the wind direction 050o is exactly in line with the runway 23L, so the wind speed of 6 kt is a tailwind
The question asks to take the more conservative data points and not interpolate, so enter the RTOW chart from the "-10 kt column"
learning.explanation: A Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) table is a simplified form of table to use and is produced for a specific aircraft type on a particular runway and shows MTOM and speeds for a variety of temperatures and pressure altitudes, sometimes giving different configuration options. First of all, the wind direction 050o is exactly in line with the runway 23L, so the wind speed of 6 kt is a tailwind. The question asks to take the more conservative data points and not interpolate, so enter the RTOW chart from the "-10 kt column". In each box, the Maximum Take-off Mass is at the top left. Move vertically down the "-10 kt column", until you reach at MTOM just over the Actual TOM given, 67050 kg. We find this at 67.1 tonnes, which corresponds to an OAT of 63°C and is equal to the Assumed/FLEX T° given. In the same box, the numbers "29-29-33" correspond to the speeds: V1 (129 kt), VR (129 kt) and V2 (133 kt), accordingly. QNH is 1003 hPa, so apply the corrections: 0, 0, +1 to the above speeds for "QNH 1013 -10 hPa". Additionally, apply the corrections: -6, -3, -2 to the above speeds for Wet runway. No corrections are required for Engine anti-ice and Packs. Finally, after applying the required corrections, the speeds for a "reduced thrust take-off" on the 23L dry runway will be: V1 = 129 - 6 = 123 kt VR = 129 - 3 = 126 kt V2 = 133 + 1 - 2 = 132 kt

Landing climb limit mass: 38 300 lb
Field length limit mass: 34 500 lb
