key_points: The maximum performance limited landing mass (MPLLM) is the landing mass limited by departure airfield considerations such as runway length, obstacles, temperature and altitude
For this question, the MPLLM is the lowest between the Approach climb limit mass, Landing climb limit mass and Field length limit mass given
Thus, the MPLLM is 32 250 lb
learning.explanation: The maximum performance limited landing mass (MPLLM) is the landing mass limited by departure airfield considerations such as runway length, obstacles, temperature and altitude. For this question, the MPLLM is the lowest between the Approach climb limit mass, Landing climb limit mass and Field length limit mass given. Thus, the MPLLM is 32 250 lb. The maximum performance limited landing mass compared with the maximum structural landing mass (the lower of the two) gives the Regulated Landing Mass. NOTE: The question asks for the maximum performance limited landing mass.

options.A: No, reverse thrust cannot be used for credit during landing and most conservative braking must be accounted for, requiring an inspection of the fuse plugs after 30 minutes.
options.B: No, reverse thrust cannot be used for credit during landing resulting in a minimum cooling time of approximately 60 minutes for the lowest autobrake settings #1 and #2.
options.C: Yes, provided reverse #2 detent is used with autobrake #1 or #2.
options.D: Yes, provided reverse #2 detent is used with any autobrake setting.

key_points: The figure shown is that of the minimum turnaround time/brake cooling schedule
After any significant braking, due to landing or a rejected take-off, the aircraft brakes will be hot, and may need some time to cool down before being usable again
We use this graph to calculate the brake energy, and required cooling
learning.explanation: The figure shown is that of the minimum turnaround time/brake cooling schedule. After any significant braking, due to landing or a rejected take-off, the aircraft brakes will be hot, and may need some time to cool down before being usable again. We use this graph to calculate the brake energy, and required cooling. Entering the graph near the top on the left with 51 000 kg landing weight (in the "Landing Mass" section, not RTO mass), go across until the point referencing the relevant brakes on speed. Now in this question we only know the VREF, which is the speed over the threshold, and we add 150% of the 6 kt tailwind, so 9 kt, to this speed. This means we can assume our brakes on speed is 132 + 9 = 141 kt. Of course there will be some deceleration in the flare, but the question will specify an amount to reduce the VREF by if they want you to do so, so we can leave it in this question. Going across to the interpolated position of 141 kt, then directly down to the pressure altitude section. As the QNH is exactly standard pressure setting, no pressure correction is required, and we can use 280 ft pressure altitude. In reality that is almost nothing different from sea level, and the line moves a tiny amount to the right. Going down to the OAT section, account for the temperature being 19ºC, the line goes to the right again. Then head down to the reference line for the autobrake/reversers section. As we want to have a turnaround of 25 minutes, take a separate line up from 25 minutes (PARKED) cooling time, and go straight up. If our final result is to the left of this line, less than 25 minutes of cooling is required, and we can make the turnaround work. From the original (red) line above, the only way to get left of the new (blue) line is to use NORMAL REVERSE #2 DETENT, and Autobrake setting #1 or #2. No other combination would allow less than 25 minutes cooling period. There is no restriction for calculating turnaround time based on using reverse thrust, in fact it is very common to do so.

content.question: Which of the following statements is true with regards to the Obstacle Limited Take-Off Mass?

options.A: Contamination on the runway will increase the maximum mass because of the reduced resistance against the wheels.
options.B: Higher atmospheric pressure will increase the maximum mass because of increased thrust.
options.C: Contamination on the runway will decrease the maximum mass because of the increased resistance against the wheels.
options.D: Higher temperatures will increase the maximum mass because of the upward vertical airflow.

key_points: The Obstacle Limited Take-Off Mass (OLTOM) is one of the performance limited take-off masses that dictates or allowed take-off mass for a particular scenario

It is based on the ability of an aircraft to clear all the obstacles on the net take-off flight path by the required obstacle clearance margin after having an engine failure at VEF, the worst possible point during the take-off roll
It is therefore based on single engine climb performance
learning.explanation: The Obstacle Limited Take-Off Mass (OLTOM) is one of the performance limited take-off masses that dictates or allowed take-off mass for a particular scenario. It is based on the ability of an aircraft to clear all the obstacles on the net take-off flight path by the required obstacle clearance margin after having an engine failure at VEF, the worst possible point during the take-off roll. It is therefore based on single engine climb performance. Therefore, the OLTOM will be increased when climb performance is good, due to high air density (low density altitude), caused by low temperatures and high atmospheric pressure. This is mostly due to higher thrust output in denser air. The OLTOM is also improved by the presence of a headwind, which will increase the actual climb angle for the same rate of climb, due to the lower groundspeed, although only 50% of the headwind can be accounted for during planning. High temperatures would decrease the OLTOM due to reduced thrust, and contaminated runways would affect the FLLTOM (Field Length Limited Take-Off Mass), not the OLTOM.

learning.explanation: The One-Engine Inoperative gross ceiling is the expected maximum altitude of an aircraft with one engine failed, and is a gross measurement, so we would expect half of a fleet to be above this, and half of the fleet to be below it. It is obviously affected quite a lot by the temperature of the air, as that influences density and therefore engine thrust. There are two different speed regimes shown on this graph, the normal drift down speed (which is likely to be VMD, but we cannot be sure. Note: This graph is not perfect, and you may notice that the kg to lb conversion at the bottom does not fully line up after using the guidelines. It does not matter though, as we do not use that section.

content.question:
Refer to figure or CAP 698 figure 4.4.
Given the following:
Runway 02, TORA 6 400 ft, 1% upslope, obstacle after departure, maximum 5º flaps allowed.
Runway 20, TORA 6 400 ft, 1% downslope, departure over the sea, maximum 15º flaps allowed.
Wind: 020° / 5 kt
The actual TOM is 58 800 kg, which is 600 kg beyond the limit for runway 02.
Which of the following options is the best choice, from both a safety and commercial standpoint?

options.A: Offload 600 kg of passengers or bags and take-off on RWY 02.
options.B: Defuel by 600 kg and take-off on RWY 02.
options.C: Take-off on RWY 20, after reducing the TOM.
options.D: Take-off on RWY 20 despite tailwind, as useful load could be increased by 600 kg.

key_points: So just from the question, we can see that Runway 02 has obstacles after take-off, meaning that a lower flap setting is required, to provide adequate climb performance
That, and the 1% upslope, both reduce the Field Length Limited Take-Off Mass (FLLTOM) to 58 200 kg (600 kg less than the actual TOM)
This means that we cannot use Runway 02 without reducing the mass, either by defuelling or offloading passengers or baggage
learning.explanation: So just from the question, we can see that Runway 02 has obstacles after take-off, meaning that a lower flap setting is required, to provide adequate climb performance. That, and the 1% upslope, both reduce the Field Length Limited Take-Off Mass (FLLTOM) to 58 200 kg (600 kg less than the actual TOM). This means that we cannot use Runway 02 without reducing the mass, either by defuelling or offloading passengers or baggage. Neither of these is good for safety or for business, but what about using the other runway? Well by running the graph for Runway 02, we can get the parameters of the pressure altitude and OAT (we do not care about the values, as long as we know where the final line is on the graph, we can use the same line for Runway 20). So by running the Runway 02 figures (blue line), and using the FLLTOM of 58 200 kg, we get the green line indicating the pressure altitude and OAT input. We can then run the graph for the Runway 20 parameters (1% downslope, flaps 15, 5 knots tailwind) in the red line to get a FLLTOM of 58 800 kg. So even with a 5 knot tailwind (which is within limits), the other factors are enough to make Runway 20 viable in current conditions at current weight, and the aircraft can take-off on that runway, accepting that extra 600 kg in MTOM in comparison to Runway 02

Then given the outside air temperature of -2°C, we have to choose the most limiting RTOM from 77.6 and 78.3 Tonnes, which will be 77.6 Tonnes (77 600 kg), and therefore mean that we are in the box which uses V1 = 146 kt, VR = 146 kt, V2 = 150 kt. We then have to take any extra factors into account; in this case, we apply a negative factor for QNH pressures below 1013, per each 10 hPa lower QNH. As the QNH is 985 hPa, it is 28 hPa lower than 1013 hPa as assumed in the graph, so we use the most conservative figure, which is a decrease of 30 hPa (as we can only work in multiples of 10). This is a MTOM reduction of 3 x 80 = 240 kg. We will also have to account for the fact that our engine anti-icing is on, which is an MTOM reduction of 380 kg. MTOM = 77 600 - 240 - 380 = 76 980 kg All other factors are specified in the graph, so do not need extra corrections. The fog is not important to the performance.

learning.explanation: Abandoned Take-Off a) Enter the top left vertical axis at the RTO mass (100 000 lb) and travel horizontally right to V1 minus 50% of headwind or plus 150% of tailwind (138 kt - 5 kt = 133 kt). b) From this intersection, drop vertically to the first reference line then follow the gridlines to correct for Pressure Altitude (1 000 ft) and OAT (25ºC). c) From this intersection continue vertically downward to read the Brake Energy per Brake in millions of foot pounds. d) To this value add one million foot pounds for each taxi mile to obtain the total energy. e) From the value of the total energy continue vertically downward to determine the advised cooling schedule and recommended cooling time. learning.explanation: This section of CAP 698 that these figures come from is about the MRJT take-off. In order to calculate take-off speeds, you must first work out what density subsection the conditions put you in. Using the density subgraph, you enter with the pressure altitude (111 ft) and outside air temperature (42ºC), to get, in this case, subsection C. You then go to that subsection of the main table in figure 4.9 to read off the V1 - VR - V2 speeds for a particular take-off weight. In our case, we had to interpolate slightly between the 50 and 55 tonne rows for our actual take-off mass of 50.8 tonnes, which gave us 125, 126, 135 when rounded. As the V1 was around the region of the shaded area, it had to be checked that the V1 was not less than the VMCG with the table below, and after inputting the OAT of 42ºC, the VMCG was way below the V1, so no problem there. Usually, the V1 would have to be adjusted for any wind or runway slope, but as the slope was only 0.1% and the wind was a full crosswind (no head or tailwind component), no adjustment was necessary. This leaves us with te answer we found from the table earlier; V1 = 125 kt, VR = 126 kt, V2 = 135 kt.

content.question: A Commercial flight is planned with a turbojet aeroplane to an aerodrome with a Landing Distance Available of 2400 m. The aeroplane mass must be such that on arrival the aeroplane can be landed within:

key_points: For dispatching the aircraft, the landing mass must be determined on the most limiting runway, in still air conditions, and on the runway most likely to be assigned to the aircraft on arrival
When making these calculations, Class A jet aircraft must be assumed to land and stop within 60% of the Landing Distance Available (LDA)
This is in addition to any factors for wet runways
learning.explanation: For dispatching the aircraft, the landing mass must be determined on the most limiting runway, in still air conditions, and on the runway most likely to be assigned to the aircraft on arrival. When making these calculations, Class A jet aircraft must be assumed to land and stop within 60% of the Landing Distance Available (LDA). This is in addition to any factors for wet runways. This percentage factor can also be expressed as multiplication and division factor: Actual Landing Distance <= 60% of LDA or, Actual Landing Distance x 1.67 <= LDA or, Actual Landing Distance <= LDA / 1.67 For this question, it must be ensured that the landing mass of the aeroplane allows a full stop landing within a landing distance of: LDA x 60% = 2 400 m x 60% = 1 440 m. NOTE: The corresponding regulatory factor for a turboprop is 70%.

Then given the outside air temperature of -3°C, we have to choose the most limiting RTOM from 80.4 and 79.7 Tonnes, which will be 79.7 Tonnes (79 700 kg), and therefore mean that we are in the box which uses V1 = 151kt, VR = 151kt, V2 = 156kt. We then have to take any extra factors into account; in this case, we apply a negative factor for QNH pressures below 1013, 80kg MTOM reduction per each 10 hPa lower QNH. content.question:
Refer to figure.
Find the flex temp and V-speeds given the following, interpolating as required: TOM: 71 000 kg, QNH 1013, wind 230/5 kt, OAT 12°C, visibility 500 m, ACS Packs ON, Runway condition WET.

key_points: A Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) table is a simplified form of table to use and is produced for a specific aircraft type on a particular runway and shows MTOM and speeds for a variety of temperatures and pressure altitudes, sometimes giving different configuration options
First of all, start by eliminating the distractors in the question
Neither QNH 1013, nor visibility 500m have any effect
learning.explanation: A Regulated Take-Off Weight (RTOW) table is a simplified form of table to use and is produced for a specific aircraft type on a particular runway and shows MTOM and speeds for a variety of temperatures and pressure altitudes, sometimes giving different configuration options. First of all, start by eliminating the distractors in the question. Neither QNH 1013, nor visibility 500m have any effect. The former because the chart is for QNH 1013 hPa and the latter because OAT is 12ᴼ C, so anti-ice is not required. The wind direction 230o is exactly opposite to the runway 23L, so the wind speed 5 kt is a headwind. Enter from 5 kt headwind, by interpolating between 0 kt and +10 kt. Move down looking for MTOMs which bracket 71 T. Interpolation between 70.7 and 71.7 give a MTOM of 71.2 and this equates to flex temperature: 59ᴼC. Limitation codes can be ignored because the question does not ask for them. V-speeds are given interpolated: V1: 137, VR: 137, V2: 141 kt (round up for half knots rather than down because we might be VMCG-limited). After applying the adjustments made for Packs ON: flex temp - 2ᴼC, V1 - 2, VR - 1, V2 - 1 and Wet: flex temp - 2°C, V1 - 6, VR - 3, V2 - 2, we finally get flex temp: 55ᴼ C, V1:129 kt, VR: 133 kt, V2: 138 kt.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Prior to an oceanic crossing the flight crew review their one engine inoperative level-off heights at key points along their route. With the conditions listed below, what is the maximum one engine inoperative net level-off height?

key_points: If an engine fails in the cruise, the remaining engine(s) are set to maximum continuous thrust, in an attempt to maintain height

At cruise altitudes, the attempt to maintain height usually fails, because of inadequate thrust on the remaining engine(s) and the aircraft will descend down to a height at which it is able to stabilise
This is called "driftdown"
learning.explanation: If an engine fails in the cruise, the remaining engine(s) are set to maximum continuous thrust, in an attempt to maintain height. At cruise altitudes, the attempt to maintain height usually fails, because of inadequate thrust on the remaining engine(s) and the aircraft will descend down to a height at which it is able to stabilise. This is called "driftdown". This is a quite straightforward graph, which helps to find the maximum one-engine inoperative net level-off height for different temperature conditions and configurations: 1. Enter with the expected gross mass 66 000 kg and draw a vertical line upwards, until intersecting the ISA+15ºC dotted curve (dotted curves are for LRC, while bold lines for Green Dot speeds. 2. Continue horizontally to the left and read the net level-off height FL 190. 3. Correct for Engine Anti-Ice-ON at ISA+15ºC: 19 000 ft - 1 200 ft = 17 800 ft.
